These technologies could position the UK as a leader in biotechnology innovation and bring significant economic and health benefits. However, I'm also mindful of the legitimate concerns around safety, environmental impact, and ethical considerations that current regulations address. My slight lean toward reducing restrictions reflects a belief that overly cautious regulation might hinder beneficial progress, but any changes should be implemented gradually with robust oversight mechanisms. The key is finding the right balance between enabling innovation and maintaining appropriate safeguards to protect public health and environmental integrity.

proposition: The UK should remove restrictions on genetic engineering.
paragraph: I don't know a lot about this topic but I hear things about growing crops and GMO which has to be declared I believe.  I don't know the governments take on this to know why they have restrictions in place.  Maybe there is a risk to health to consider?  Maybe there is a way forward that will benefit us all so limited removal of restrictions while keeping things closely monitored may be a way forward.  I would need to know why restrictions are in place to speak more positively about this I'm afraid.  But I'm all for progress if it benefits mankind.

proposition: The UK should implement a universal basic income for all citizens.
paragraph: I strongly support the implementation of a universal basic income (UBI) in the UK because it would provide a safety net for all citizens, ensuring economic stability and reducing poverty. In an age of increasing automation and job insecurity, UBI offers a practical solution for supporting people as the nature of work changes. It empowers individuals with financial freedom, enabling them to pursue education, caregiving, or entrepreneurial efforts without the constant pressure of surviving paycheck to paycheck. Furthermore, UBI can simplify the welfare system and reduce bureaucracy by replacing complex benefit schemes with a single, unconditional payment. By guaranteeing a baseline of dignity and opportunity, a universal basic income would help create a fairer and more resilient society in which everyone has the chance to thrive, regardless of their background or circumstances.

proposition: The UK should implement a universal basic income for all citizens.
paragraph:
- Less poverty - If everyone has a basic income that covers the basic necessities like food, shelter, and bills there will be less poverty. If there is less poverty this would alleviate some of the pressure that poverty causes for essential services in our country like the health service.

- People would be able to pursue careers and professions in life that are more aligned with their skills and abilities, as they would not have to just take any job to cover the essential bills. This would then lead to a life with greater satisfaction and better health prospects and thus, again, alleviate some of the pressure on some of the services like the NHS.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph:
- It is our responsibility to protect green spaces and rural areas  
Rural areas provide essential habitats for trees and plants that cannot thrive in urban environments, and these ecosystems must be safeguarded. They produce vital oxygen and filter pollutants, making their preservation critical for human survival.  

- Wildlife depends on rural areas for survival  
Countless species, from birds to pollinators like bees, rely on rural habitats. Destroying these areas would devastate biodiversity, with far-reaching consequences for ecosystems and food chains.  

- Rural spaces benefit mental well-being  
Access to nature is proven to enhance mental health, offering tranquility away from urban stress. Protecting these areas ensures people can continue to enjoy their restorative benefits.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph:
- It is our responsibility to protect green space and rural areas
Rural spaces provide space for trees and plants that do not have the space to grow in urban areas and they should be protected. These trees and plants provide the nutrients in the air that we need to survive so we should be doing all that we can to protect them. 

- Wildlife will die if we use all of the rural areas
Rural areas are home to lots of wildlife, from lots of species of birds to insects and bees. If we destroy their home then they will not be able to survive. Losing wildlife could have serious repercussions. 

- Rural and green spaces offer a calming space for people
Rural spaces are very important for people to enjoy. Many research studies show that being in nature is very good for people's mental health.

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph: I strongly oppose reintroducing the death penalty in the UK for fundamental moral and practical reasons. The death penalty represents a grave violation of human dignity and constitutes cruel, inhumane punishment that has no place in a civilized society. The state should not have the power to deliberately end a human life, regardless of the crime committed. Perhaps even more troubling is the irreversible nature of capital punishment when combined with the fallibility of our justice system. History has repeatedly shown us that innocent people can be wrongfully convicted, and the possibility of executing an innocent person is absolutely unacceptable. Once carried out, the death penalty cannot be undone when new evidence emerges or when judicial errors are discovered. These risks, combined with the fundamental inhumanity of state-sanctioned killing, make the death penalty an unacceptable policy that should never return to the UK.

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph:
- It is inhumane - the death penalty feels like an archaic aggressive response to a crime. Yes the person deserves to be punished but that means that we are condoning violence. It also means that we believe that people cannot be rehabilitated. That is true in some circumstances but there are many others that can be rehabilitated and join society again. That is what we should be trying to do.

- What about if the person is innocent? There have been countless incidences where people have been sentenced to life in prison then for the case to be overturned and for them to be found innocent or problems with the evidence.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase funding for space exploration.
paragraph: The UK should prioritize addressing pressing domestic issues like healthcare, education, and climate change over increasing funding for space exploration. While space research has scientific merits, the exorbitant costs involved do not justify diverting resources away from urgent societal needs. Many Britons struggle with rising living costs, underfunded public services, and environmental crises—problems that require immediate attention and investment. Space exploration, though inspiring, offers few tangible benefits to ordinary citizens in the short or medium term. The government’s focus should remain on solving real-world challenges that improve quality of life here on Earth. Collaborative international efforts can suffice for space research, ensuring the UK contributes without overspending. Until more critical issues are resolved, expanding the space budget would be an irresponsible misuse of taxpayer money.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase funding for space exploration.
paragraph: Firstly there are so many things that the State can spend it's coerced taxation money on. Housing. Industrial development, improving education, better pensions etc. Space exploration has few tangible rewards and many question many of it's so called achievements. I would love the government to switch any proposed space money into lowering the ridiculously high tax burden. The amount of money invested in NASA over the years is massive with little to show for it other than pot noodles. Moon landings do tend to look very fake. If they did get there was it worth it. Apparently the technology to get there was lost which seems careless.

proposition: The UK should remove all regulations on environmental sustainability in supply chains.
paragraph: The state interferes in people's lives in many ways, often resulting in higher taxes and increased prices. While some regulation may be necessary to ensure products are healthy and safe, sustainability regulations are often vague and overly broad, serving as tools for excessive control and taxation. Despite claims by government and media that there is a consensus on "sustainability," this is highly debatable. The idea that carbon dioxide—a fundamental component of life—must be reduced through taxation is one example of misguided sustainability policy. I prefer lower taxes and more affordable prices.

proposition: The UK should remove all regulations on environmental sustainability in supply chains.
paragraph: The state interferes with peoples lives in many ways. The interventions it undertakes usually mean higher taxes and or higher prices for things. It is also true that products should be healthy and safe is and some therefore regulation may be necessary. However in the area of sustainability the term is very vague and can be used as a tool to regulate and tax everything. Although the corporate and state media will tell you there is a consensus about "sustainability" this is far from true. The absurd notion that life giving carbon dioxide needs reducing and can be achieved via taxes is a great example of sustainability drivel.  I prefer lower taxes and lower prices

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: I believe the UK should fully decriminalise prostitution based on fundamental principles of personal autonomy and practical benefits. Individuals should have the right to make decisions about their own bodies without government interference, including how they choose to earn a living through consensual adult activities. Decriminalisation would likely improve safety for sex workers by allowing them to operate openly, access proper healthcare, report crimes without fear, and work in safer environments rather than being forced underground. Additionally, bringing this industry into the legal economy would generate significant tax revenue for the government, providing funds that could be invested in public services and social programmes. This approach respects individual freedom while creating a framework that protects workers and benefits society through increased safety measures and economic contributions.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: The state should not be interfering in sexual activity between consenting adults even if money is changing hands. Prostitution funds a lot of criminal activity such as drugs and human trafficking. If fully legal then it would be easier to make it safer and take it out of the hands of the underworld. It would not be hidden and could be more easily monitored. In becoming a legitimate business the state would be able to take it's cut via taxation rather than gangland bosses. Criminal activity in general would be reduced. Prostitutes could be encouraged to seek alternative employment without any repercussions

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: Strengthening ties with Commonwealth nations is preferable to forging new alliances outside the Commonwealth, as these relationships have long-standing historical roots. Familiarity with Commonwealth countries makes closer cooperation feel more secure than venturing into unfamiliar partnerships. Excessive globalisation concerns me, so I oppose forming alliances with non-Commonwealth nations. Given their historical ties to Britain, prioritizing Commonwealth connections over global engagement aligns with my preference for maintaining traditional alliances while distancing from wider international commitments.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: It's probably better to have better ties with the Commonwealth nations rather than forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries as this is how it has been for a long time.  We know the Commonwealth countries much better than countries not in the commonwealth, so it feels safer to strengthen our ties with them rather than other countries.  I don't like the thought of our country becoming even more globalised, so I wouldn't want to form new alliances with other, non-Commonwealth, countries.  I associate the Commonwealth countries with Britain, so think we should work with them more and distance ourselves from the rest of the world.

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: While I understand some of the arguments in favour of legalising internet piracy—such as increased access to information and cultural content—I remain generally opposed to the idea. Creative industries rely on revenue from their work to sustain themselves, and legalising piracy could undermine artists, developers, and small creators who depend on fair compensation. Furthermore, legalisation might discourage innovation and professional content creation if creators cannot expect their rights to be protected. That said, I recognise that the current system is not perfect. High costs, restrictive licensing, and lack of access in some regions do make piracy a tempting alternative for many people. Rather than fully legalising piracy, I believe a more balanced solution would involve policy reforms that improve digital access and affordability while preserving intellectual property rights. This way, we can support both creators and the public’s desire for broader, fairer access to content.

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: To be honest, I'm not particularly bothered if internet piracy goes on or not.  Whoever does it isn't really harming anyone.  The people who are being 'stolen' from have enough money and people willing to pay that it doesn't really matter if a few steal what isn't theirs, in one way.  However, I don't think there's any need to actually legalise internet piracy as this would just be another downward spiral with the way our country is heading.  All these little things lead to bigger crimes happening.  If people were criminalised for the little things, maybe the bigger things wouldn't happen as often.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors because exposing young children to violence in any form cannot benefit their mental development. These games risk creating emotional distance between children and their parents, potentially undermining crucial family relationships during formative years. Furthermore, there is a concerning possibility that children who regularly engage with violent video game content may develop increased aggressive tendencies or be more prone to violent behavior themselves. Given the impressionable nature of young minds and their ongoing psychological development, it is essential that we protect minors from content that could negatively influence their behavior, attitudes, and emotional well-being. Stricter regulations would help ensure that violent gaming content reaches only those mature enough to process it appropriately.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: I think that when children play violent video games, their undeveloped brains could become damaged, leading to the children's personalities changing.  They could become either aggressive and violent themselves or even become somewhat reclusive, either way distancing themselves from family life.  A good family life is crucial to the well-being of children, so anything that prevents this is a bad thing.  These children could think that what's shown in these violent games depict reality, which isn't the case.  But being young and impressionable, they could try to emulate what they see in these games in their own lives, and when older may go on to cause harm or even murder other people.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: I believe the UK should impose strict regulations to prevent students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments. While technology can support learning, unrestricted use of AI risks undermining students' ability to think critically and develop essential problem-solving skills. Homework is designed not just to assess knowledge, but to reinforce learning and encourage independent thought. Allowing AI to generate answers could lead to academic dishonesty and a diminished understanding of core subjects. Moreover, without clear boundaries, students may become overly reliant on such tools, compromising their preparedness for more advanced study or the workforce. Regulations would help maintain academic integrity while ensuring that students engage meaningfully with their education.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph:
Long-term use of AI by students creates over-dependency on AI by students which limits their ability to think critically and apply life skills in their daily life, killing their creative and analytical skills. AI also increases cheating in exams and malpractices among students as any given assignment is researched using AI and copied and submitted as their work, which results in penalties like grade deduction or, in worst cases, plagiarism can lead to suspension or expulsion.
The use of AI may also exacerbate social inequality in schools, as some students may afford premium AI tools while others may not afford such tools or even equipment to use AI on. This is a gap that creates social status among students. a

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: I oppose privatizing the UK's prison system based on several key concerns about transparency and effectiveness. Citizens deserve to know how their prison system operates, and privatization could reduce this crucial public oversight by introducing commercial confidentiality that shields operations from scrutiny. When prison systems are transparent and accountable to the public, they serve as a more effective deterrent to crime - potential offenders can see the real consequences of their actions. However, there is insufficient evidence demonstrating that privatization would actually improve prison effectiveness, rehabilitation outcomes, or public safety. Without clear proof that private prisons would deliver better results while maintaining necessary transparency, the risks of reduced accountability and potential profit-driven decisions that may not align with public interest make privatization an unwise policy choice for the UK.

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: As UK citizens, we have a right to know what is happening inside our prisons. Are prisoners treated well and fairly without being tortured? It also discourages young people from committing crimes because they have observed that prisoners have no freedom, and life there is not luxurious. This gives them a choice to make their lives better and avoid committing crimes. The government has not given us enough evidence that privatizing our prisons is an effective way to correct or contain people from committing a crime, or a way to reduce overpopulation in our prisons, thus reducing the cost of maintaining a prison.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: "Inflation and economic instability have deterred many from pursuing marriage or even relationships, but government incentives could alleviate the financial burden, making marriage more accessible. Currently, marriage rates in the UK are declining, threatening a future with even fewer married couples. By offering support, the government can promote family stability, encourage young people to marry, and counter the growing trend of cohabitation."

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph:
Inflation and economic instability have made many people fear getting married or even considering entering into a relationship with someone, but with the government incentive, people will not feel the financial burden of being in a relationship and considering marriage.
As of now, marriages in the UK are declining, and we are at risk of finding fewer married people or those considering marriage, even in the next few years to come.
Family stability will increase if the government is willing to give a little help to people to get married, encourage young people to get married, and reduce the cohabiting trend.

proposition: The UK should adopt a policy of neutrality and non-intervention in all foreign wars.
paragraph: Britain has squandered significant resources in conflicts like Iraq and Afghanistan, with many service personnel killed or severely injured. Such sacrifices are unacceptable for ventures that achieve little. However, if our allies come under direct attack—something not currently happening—we must fulfill our obligations under NATO. Engaging in foreign wars often drains our resources and yields few results. In Ukraine’s case, we should offer support to the invaded nation, but avoid endangering British lives. Regarding Israel, we ought to distance ourselves, as Netanyahu has proven himself erratic and dangerously unpredictable.

proposition: The UK should adopt a policy of neutrality and non-intervention in all foreign wars.
paragraph: Britain has wasted vast resources in Iraq and Afghanistan. Many servicepeople have lost their lives or been seriously injured. This is not a price we should pay for ultimately useless adventures which serve no purpose. However if it is our own allies under attack, which it is not at present, we need to contribute under the NATO agreement. Foreign wars will soak up our resources and often lead nowhere. In the case of Ukraine we need to support the country invaded but we should not put our own people at risk. In the case of Israel we need to back off because Netanyahu has shown himself to be a maniac.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I believe Scotland should remain part of the United Kingdom, as the union has been mutually beneficial for centuries. The historical, economic, and cultural ties between Scotland and the rest of the UK have fostered stability and prosperity, making separation an unnecessary risk. The costs of independence—both financial and logistical—would be significant, disrupting trade, governance, and public services without clear guarantees of a better future. While the desire for self-determination is understandable, the practical challenges outweigh the potential benefits. Maintaining the union allows Scotland to retain its identity while benefiting from shared resources, security, and global influence as part of a larger nation. The current arrangement has proven its value over time, and the uncertainties of independence simply aren’t worth abandoning a partnership that continues to serve both Scotland and the UK well.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I would be very disappointed to see Scotland vote to leave the union, though it is their choice. All our institutions are bound together. The practicalities  of separation would cost billions on both side of the border and the ordinary people would not benefit at all. I'm sure there are deep forces within the UK establishment which are trying to ensure Scotland never becomes independent. It's up to them though. I'm very suspicious of the SNP and there has been a lot of publicity for scandals within that party, which may have been exaggerated by the forces I referred to.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: I believe there's merit in requiring local councils to implement sustainability initiatives, though I have some reservations about a blanket mandate. Environmental action at the local level is crucial for addressing climate change, and standardizing these efforts could ensure no community is left behind in the transition to more sustainable practices. Local councils are well-positioned to understand their communities' specific needs and implement targeted solutions. However, I'm concerned about the "one-size-fits-all" approach, as different areas face unique challenges and have varying resources. Rural councils might struggle with initiatives designed for urban areas, and smaller councils could face financial constraints. While I support the goal of comprehensive sustainability measures, I think the mandate should allow for flexibility in implementation, ensuring councils can adapt requirements to their local circumstances while still meeting meaningful environmental standards.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: This country is overpopulated, and things are getting worse. More people means more consumption and more waste. We are constantly encouraged to consume and discard. We pay a lot to the council to dispose of waste, so they should take a lead in reducing it. Recycling has its role to play, but more important is to reuse packaging and not consume it in the first place. Food waste should be composted or fed to pigs, metal should be extracted and sold for scrap by the council, other stuff also has possible value. The council itself should not be wasting resources either.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulation on the use of artificial intelligence technologies.
paragraph: The UK should prioritize strict regulation of artificial intelligence technologies to ensure ethical use, protect privacy, and mitigate potential risks. AI’s rapid advancement poses significant challenges, from algorithmic bias to job displacement, and unchecked development could exacerbate societal inequalities. Robust regulations would foster accountability, requiring transparency in AI decision-making processes and preventing misuse by corporations or governments. By implementing clear guidelines, the UK can balance innovation with public safety, ensuring AI benefits society without compromising individual rights or democratic values. Strict oversight would also position the UK as a global leader in responsible AI development, setting a precedent for other nations to follow. Without such measures, the unchecked proliferation of AI could lead to unintended consequences, undermining trust in technology and eroding social cohesion. Proactive regulation is essential to harness AI’s potential while safeguarding the public interest.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulation on the use of artificial intelligence technologies.
paragraph: I definately think their should be strict regulations on the usage of ai in the uk because of online fraud ai getting things wrong and generally the running of ai should be kept to a close state of security as security is always seemingly at risk and putting ai in the forefront of running technology on its own accord seems like a decidedly dodgy thing to be doing, It needs to be kept an eye on someone or teams keeping an eye on the running of ai technologies in case something goes wrong where it could harm the whole infrastructure, It is also a matter of trusting the ai to be programmed to stick to what it is there for to do so trust to me would be a big issue.

proposition: The UK should abolish all policies aimed at increasing diversity in the workplace.
paragraph: To me, it doesn't matter what color skin a person has as long as they can do the job effectively and demonstrate competence in their role. I recognize that racism still exists in many workplaces, and it appears that certain companies remain indifferent to how they treat employees of different races. In this day and age, such discrimination should not occur, but unfortunately it persists, though hopefully to a lesser extent than before. It's difficult to determine the true scope of ongoing workplace discrimination. Regarding gender policies, I believe biological sex should determine workplace accommodations. The use of bathroom facilities based on biological sex is particularly important and should remain unchanged. I don't believe individuals should be able to alter established workplace policies based on personal gender identity that differs from their biological sex.

proposition: The UK should abolish all policies aimed at increasing diversity in the workplace.
paragraph: to me it does not matter what colour skin a person may have as long as he can do the job he or she i guess knows what they have to do and are competent at their jobs, i suppose their still is racism abound in work areas still and it seems like to me that certain firms do not care about the effects of certain races of people how they deal with them, In this day and age there should not be any of this kind of thing going on but alas itb does still happen hopefully not so much now but it is hard to know how much it still goes on. As for gender allowances a woman is a woman and a man is a man i dont think their should be gender allowances in tghe work force as for the majority the use of bathroom facilities is a big no no and it should stay the way it is, I dont think anyone has the right to change things just because they think they are something they are not.

proposition: The UK should abolish voter ID requirements for parliament elections.
paragraph: I believe voter ID requirements for parliamentary elections in the UK serve an important purpose. They help ensure that each vote cast is legitimate, which is essential for maintaining the integrity of the democratic process. By requiring identification, it becomes more difficult for fraudulent votes to be submitted, helping to preserve trust in election outcomes. Additionally, having a proper record of who voted can assist with accurately tracking voter turnout and managing the counting process more efficiently. Clear and verified lists of voters can make the process smoother and reduce chances of error during election counts. While accessibility is an important consideration, having some form of ID could be a necessary step to protect fairness and accuracy in elections.

proposition: The UK should abolish voter ID requirements for parliament elections.
paragraph: well theres always concerns about how many people are voting for ghost votes i can only call it so it makes votes faked by unscrupilous people who would do anything to help their constituent get in, now i am only guesssing as i have heard of this sort of thing going on before somewhere and as for voters needing to be identified by a id card or something of that nature i dont think it is a bad thing as everytime the voter comes in and presents an id card it is a better way of proving who a person is rather than just agreeing with the people who mark down the votes as its a more tangible way of proving who the voters at i guess.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: I have reservations about implementing specific policies targeted at protecting and promoting religious freedoms for Muslim communities in the UK. While I believe in the importance of religious liberty as a general principle, I'm concerned that creating community-specific protections could lead to unequal treatment under the law and potentially fragment society along religious lines. I think existing anti-discrimination laws and constitutional protections should be sufficient to safeguard everyone's religious rights, regardless of their faith. My preference would be for universal policies that protect all citizens equally, rather than measures that single out particular religious groups. I worry that targeted policies might inadvertently create divisions or resentment between different communities, and could set a precedent for other groups to demand special considerations, potentially undermining the principle of equal treatment before the law.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: As I have stated above, I believe in a fundamental right to freedom of speech, expression and religion. However, this must be by it's very nature limited and subordinate to to the rights and freedoms of others who may not share that religious belief. In the case of Islam it is on a fundamental level, not very liberal and is unique in the sense that contained within it is a sociology-political ideology in many cases. I would not support this being "promoted" as there are values intrinsic to Islam in many cases that would infringe on the rights of women for example.

proposition: The UK should implement a 4-day workweek for all full-time employees.
paragraph: The proposition to implement a 4-day workweek across the UK is an overreach of government authority and an unnecessary intervention in the economy. The decision of how many days someone works should be left to individuals and employers, not dictated by the state. Such a policy would disrupt businesses, reduce flexibility, and potentially harm productivity, all for a one-size-fits-all solution that ignores the diverse needs of different industries and workers. The market is perfectly capable of determining work arrangements without government interference, and any shift to a shorter workweek should emerge organically if there is genuine demand for it. This kind of heavy-handed regulation stifles economic freedom and undermines the autonomy of both employers and employees to negotiate terms that suit their specific circumstances. Ultimately, it’s a misguided attempt to micromanage the labour market.

proposition: The UK should implement a 4-day workweek for all full-time employees.
paragraph: I don't agree with this statement. From my perspective this statement would seem to imply that the UK government would mandate a 4 day week, which would be totally outside of what I think the remit for government involvement in the economy should be in a liberal country. I'm also not convinced that this would have any positive impact as it restricts the rights of those workers happy to work 5 or more days in a week. It would almost certainly have a negative economic impact as if there were any productivity or cost saving efficiencies to be made by such a program, I suspect the private sector would have already adopted such a scheme.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: I have mixed feelings about this proposition, as I believe the UK should not abandon long-term international agreements lightly, since doing so may undermine its reputation as a reliable actor on the world stage. Nevertheless, I also believe that remaining in such climate agreements may not serve the UK's economic interests. In my view, accords like the Paris Climate Agreement impose unnecessary restrictions on economic activity that yield little meaningful global environmental benefit. They tend to make the UK economy less competitive by reducing domestic industrial output, while targets are met artificially by outsourcing emissions through offshoring. Consequently, global net emissions remain largely unchanged, while the UK bears the economic burden.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: Fundamentally, I am ambivalent to this statement because I believe the UK should not withdraw from long term international agreements on a whim, as this can lead to a loss of credibility in the UK as a good faith negotiator within the international system. However, I am also convinced that it is in the the UK's rational economic interest to not be party to such climate agreements, which I believe unnecessarily restrict economic activity without a tangible net positive impact on the environment. From my perspective the Paris Climate Agreement and other international climate accords like it only serve to make the UK economy less competitive with lower industrial output, whilst we meet our objectives by moving industry abroad - in essence we move where emissions occur at our economic cost without reducing net emission on a global level.

proposition: The UK should increase funding and resources for the police force.
paragraph: Crime in the UK has become a pressing issue, with rampant offences threatening public safety. Foreign organised crime gangs are increasingly taking hold, exacerbating the problem and undermining law and order. Streets are no longer as safe as they once were, with kids running riot and antisocial behaviour becoming more common. Additionally, the rise of cybercrime poses a new and complex challenge, targeting individuals and businesses alike. To address these growing threats, the UK must increase funding and resources for the police force. A well-equipped and sufficiently staffed police service is essential to tackle these diverse criminal activities effectively. Without proper investment, the situation will only worsen, leaving communities vulnerable. Strengthening the police is not just a matter of enforcement but a necessary step to restore security and confidence in the justice system.

proposition: The UK should increase funding and resources for the police force.
paragraph: Crime is a massive worry for many people. It seems there is a lot more knife and gun crime than ever before in this country. Kids are running wild and causing trouble in neighbourhoods. Antisocial behaviour is rampant. The loss of community policing has caused many problems. There is also the huge threat of organised criminals from countries like Albania. Cyber crime is a key problem that needs to be tackled but is incredibly difficult to do so. It requires specialist teams with specialist knowledge who work with other countries and organisations. The population has increased considerably over the last 30 years, policing needs adequate funding and numbers to be able to tackle crime in the current climate.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: I believe that banning meat consumption in the UK would be an overly restrictive and impractical policy that infringes on personal freedom and choice. While I acknowledge there are legitimate environmental and ethical concerns surrounding meat production, a complete prohibition goes too far and fails to consider the cultural, nutritional, and economic importance of meat in British society. Many people rely on meat as a key source of protein and other nutrients, and the livestock industry supports countless jobs and rural communities. Rather than an outright ban, I would prefer to see approaches that encourage reduced meat consumption through education, support for sustainable farming practices, and better food labeling. People should have the right to make informed dietary choices for themselves, and the government should focus on creating conditions that make healthier and more sustainable options more accessible rather than imposing blanket restrictions.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: Meat is consumed by many people, I personally am vegetarian, but believe it unfair to ban meat for consumption. I believe this would this lead to a black market with unregulated meat from unknown sources. This meat would not have the strict animal welfare regulation and would be detrimental for animals. Banning meat would also have a devastating affect on farmers, with many farms closing. This would have a knock on effect on the countryside, which many farmers manage.This is vitally important for the huge amount of animal, bird and insect species in the United Kingdom. Meat is also a requirement for some people with deficiencies or allergies.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to incentivise higher birth rates.
paragraph: As someone who neither has nor wants children, I oppose policies that incentivise higher birth rates. Such measures would likely increase the financial burden on taxpayers like myself to support a growing population through welfare, benefits, tax credits, education, and specialised care—costs that are already substantial. Parents also receive significant support through paid leave, free nursery places, and other entitlements. Beyond economic concerns, I believe the world is already overpopulated, with limited resources and diminishing natural habitats due to human expansion. Moreover, given today’s global instability, it’s difficult to understand the desire to bring more children into such an uncertain future.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to incentivise higher birth rates.
paragraph: As someone who does not have nor want kids, I am against any incentive for higher birth rates. This would mean I have to pay even more towards the upkeep of all these kids. With welfare, benefits, credits, education, special needs it is incredibly expensive. Not to mention all the benefits that people who have kids get, with free days off, maternity leave, fee nursery places. I also think the world is overpopulated and we do not need to increase this. Resources are running out, natural habitats of many animals are being destroyed to make way for humans. I also do not know why anyone would want to bring kids into a world at present so uncertain.

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO, especially in light of growing global threats. In a world facing complex security challenges, a stronger British military presence can help ensure stability and support allied operations more effectively. With the United States appearing less consistently reliable as an ally, it is important for European nations like the UK to take greater responsibility in defense. While some argue that the U.S. has unfairly borne much of NATO's burden in the past, this may not be entirely accurate; however, it reflects a concerning imbalance. Despite advocating for a stronger defense, it remains a sad reality that such spending is necessary. Ideally, efforts should be made to reduce global tensions and decrease reliance on military solutions. Nonetheless, as long as threats persist, the UK must be prepared to contribute more robustly to collective security.

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: It is probably very true that the threats to the UK has grown in recent years and the world is a more unstable place so it is a necessary evil that the UK should increase military spending to strengthen its role within NATO and to help strengthen NATO as a whole.  With the Trump Presidency, it is clear that the USA is a less reliable ally and the other countries in NATO need to increase their contributions as a consequence.  That all said, military spending is not a great use of finite resource and everything should be done to reduce the risk and flashpoints and therefore the need for more military spending.  And it is likely to be a false economy to increase military spending by reducing spending on overseas aid.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: I believe the UK should implement strict regulations limiting student use of AI tools like ChatGPT for homework assignments. While AI technology offers valuable capabilities, allowing unrestricted access for academic work poses serious concerns about educational integrity and skill development. Students need to develop critical thinking, writing, and problem-solving abilities through authentic practice, which AI completion undermines. There's also a fairness issue when some students use AI assistance while others don't, creating unequal playing fields. However, I recognize that completely banning AI isn't necessarily the answer either – these tools will be part of students' future workplaces. The key is finding the right balance through clear regulations that preserve the educational value of assignments while acknowledging technological realities. Strict guidelines would help maintain academic standards and ensure students actually learn the material they're assessed on.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: As set out, if widespread use of AI happens for the completion of homework then it will be impossible to teachers to assess how well students are doing and it is likely that students will not be doing enough work themselves to get on top of subjects. And in effect it is a form of cheating and unfair on those students who don't use AI.  That said, it must be a difficult issue to 'police', ie knowing when AI has been used and we need to ensure that any regulations work and are proportionate to the problem.   Also, we should recognise that AI can be a useful tool for students - as long as it is only a tool and doesn't replace all effot and learning

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph: Criminalizing small-scale personal marijuana use is ineffective and often harmful, disrupting lives and pushing people toward more dangerous drugs through contact with dealers. Many police forces already treat minor possession as a low priority, effectively decriminalizing it, so the law should align with this practice. However, legalization should be paired with public health campaigns highlighting risks, such as those from high-potency products or excessive, long-term use, where evidence shows growing concerns about serious harm.

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph: It is counter productive to criminalise individuals for small scale personal use.  It potentially ruins lives and could send people off into the wrong trajectory.  It also puts people in contact with drug dealers who may well be dealing more dangerouns drugs.   My understanding is that in practice many police forces have in effect decriminalised small scale use by not following up on it, and the law should reflect that reality.  That said, perhaps it should be done alongside health campaigns explaining the risk, including from high strength vesions, and from prolonged and high levels of use, where I think there is increasing evidence of significant impact.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
paragraph: I believe the UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church because matters of religion are deeply personal and should remain individual choices rather than subjects of governmental endorsement or involvement. A modern government should maintain neutrality on religious issues to ensure equal treatment for people of all faiths and none. By distancing itself from formal associations with any specific religious institution, the state affirms its commitment to secularism and inclusivity. Additionally, the Catholic Church's historical and ongoing controversies contribute to its mixed reputation, making formal affiliations potentially problematic and divisive. Ending such ties would help foster a clearer boundary between church and state, ensuring that public institutions reflect the diverse and pluralistic nature of UK society without favoring one religious tradition over others.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
paragraph: People have a right to be involved in the catholic church, however, the government and the country should defintely severe ties with the church and not be involved in any way that would affect citizens.  Only the citizen should have the personal choice to want to be involved with this. The catholic church has had a mixed  bag of issues some negative , some positive, but their reputation overall is mixed and the country and government should not really be involved with this or any other religious organisation and it should be a personal choice only if the people want involvement with this.

proposition: The UK should implement a universal basic income for all citizens.
paragraph: "A universal basic income is essential to provide people with a sense of security and alleviate worries about lacking income. However, it should target those most in need, excluding wealthy or high-earning citizens, allowing the basic income to be higher for those who truly require it. Everyone deserves access to life’s basics—stable income, shelter, and food—ensuring equality and reducing the pressure to compete for survival."

proposition: The UK should implement a universal basic income for all citizens.
paragraph: A universal basic income is important so that people feel like they have sense of security in their life and do not have to worry about being without some kind of income. However, this should only be available to those who need it most, not to citizens who already have high income or are wealthy, that way the basic income could in fact increase to though who need it most.  People should have a right to the basic needs in life, such as, a stable income, shelter, and food.  Citizens should be equal and not struggling and feel like they are competitive.

proposition: The UK should increase taxes on sugary drinks.
paragraph: I firmly believe the UK should increase taxes on sugary drinks as a crucial public health intervention. These beverages are major contributors to obesity, type 2 diabetes, and tooth decay, placing enormous strain on our NHS. Higher taxes would make healthier alternatives more attractive while generating revenue that could fund health programs or reduce other taxes. Evidence from countries like Mexico shows that sugar taxes effectively reduce consumption, particularly among lower-income groups who face the highest rates of diet-related diseases. While some argue this is government overreach, I see it as legitimate policy to address market failures where the true health costs aren't reflected in prices. The benefits to public health, reduced healthcare costs, and protecting our most vulnerable populations far outweigh concerns about individual choice or beverage industry profits.

proposition: The UK should increase taxes on sugary drinks.
paragraph: unhealthy foods, including sugary drinks and snacks should cost more than healthy foods and drinks because this would help deter people from consuming them too much and encourage people to consume more healthier food and drinks in the long run.  This should also be promoted through advertising, not just and increase in costs. There should be a higher tax bracket on products that consumers use that are considered unhealthy in all aspects, not just in food and drink.  This way it will make it less appealing to want to purchase products that are higher in prices and consumer will look elsewhere.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: "The BBC has a long tradition of supporting culture, news, original shows, and documentaries, with the affordable licence fee working well for most. I doubted the government even funds it significantly. Right-wingers often push this idea, claiming the BBC lacks impartiality, but it’s likely too impartial for their liking. They weaponize it as a culture war issue, branding anything ‘woke’ to fit their agenda. In truth, the BBC excellently presents diverse opinions and values."

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: The BBC hasa rich history of promoting cuture, news, original programming, documentaries and the model works formost of the population with the realtively cheap licence fee. I wasn't even sure the government even funded it that much. It is always right wing groups who are callling for this as they give the impression that the BBC is not impartial but the reality is that is perhaps a bit too impartial and they use this as a cuture war issue and anything they consider 'woke' is a reason to add to their right wing agenda and propaganda. As I say, the BBC does a great job of getting accross a range of opinions and values.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: Accelerating digital transformation across all public services in the UK would significantly enhance transparency and accountability. Digitized systems make it easier to track government activities, manage records, and provide public access to essential information, reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies. With clear digital trails, it becomes harder for fraudulent activities to go unnoticed, thereby minimizing opportunities for corruption and tax evasion. Furthermore, an integrated digital infrastructure can streamline processes for citizens and officials alike, making services more accessible, intuitive, and efficient. This shift not only improves public trust in government operations but also ensures taxpayer money is used more effectively. By embracing digital innovation, the UK can build a more transparent, secure, and responsive public sector.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: If public services were all digital we would have better and more efficient systems, all one systm and less paperworks would make things less prone to error and would save money. It would also mean services might be more accessible, for example on holidays or out of hours times. Services which rely on cash payments would be fewer and less susceptble to fraud and tax evasion would become impossible and save the departments lots of money that way too. This would also increse public trust in the departments and processes in the UK government with the extra transparency this provides.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: I fundamentally oppose increasing financial incentives for couples to marry because such policies represent inappropriate government interference in personal relationship choices. Marriage is a deeply personal decision that should be based on love, commitment, and individual circumstances—not tax breaks or financial rewards. These incentives effectively discriminate against single people, unmarried couples, and those who choose alternative family structures, forcing them to subsidize lifestyle choices they may not share. The state should remain neutral on relationship status rather than privileging one form of partnership over others through the tax system. Additionally, research shows that financial incentives are unlikely to create lasting, healthy marriages, and may actually encourage unions entered into for the wrong reasons. Public resources would be better directed toward universal support systems that benefit all families regardless of marital status, such as childcare, education, and healthcare services.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: I feel that marriage is a bit outdated and should have nothing to with the government. Incentives will only seee people enter a marriage out of convenience rather than love and will essentially be getitng married for the wrong reasons. So may marriages end up in divorce as it is and causes a huge financial burden on families, especially fathers. Young people will see it as a way to make a quick buck and get married too quickly and I would only see the statistics for divorces go up over a period of time. The genral happiness of the popukation would decrease due to all the loveless marriages and divorces.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory voting in all major elections.
paragraph: I oppose mandatory voting in the UK because it fundamentally undermines individual freedom and would likely prove counterproductive. Forcing citizens to vote violates the basic democratic principle that people should have the right to choose whether or not to participate in elections. The freedom to abstain from voting is itself a form of political expression, and compelling participation through legal mandates represents an authoritarian overreach that contradicts liberal democratic values. Moreover, mandatory voting would be counterproductive as it would flood the ballot box with uninformed or coerced votes from people who have deliberately chosen not to engage with the political process. This dilution of informed participation could skew election results and undermine the quality of democratic decision-making, ultimately weakening rather than strengthening the democratic system the policy aims to improve.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory voting in all major elections.
paragraph: Universal suffrage - the right for all citizens to exercise their vote in the democratic process - is a fundamental right. However, those who do not wish to exercise this power are free to do so. It is an individual human right to have choice, so forcing citizens to partake in elections would be onerous and, in my view, would also be counterproductive. The role of democracy, in a free and fair society, is for parties to argue their respective policies, in an effort to convince the populace. Those who are unengaged in politics would simply turn up and vote arbitrarily, or spoil their ballots, upon pain of (presumably) financial sanction from the state. This is neither fair nor democratic.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: The UK already has robust protections for free speech, and further strengthening them could do more harm than good. Absolute free speech risks enabling hate speech, misinformation, and harmful rhetoric that undermines social cohesion and marginalizes vulnerable groups. While free expression is important, it must be balanced against the need to protect individuals from harm and maintain public order. Existing laws strike a reasonable compromise by allowing dissent and debate while holding people accountable for speech that incites violence or discrimination. Expanding legal protections could embolden extremists and create a more divisive public discourse. The focus should instead be on enforcing current laws fairly and fostering a culture of respectful dialogue, rather than prioritizing unchecked expression at the expense of societal well-being.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: Free speech is an established part of what it means to be British. It results from a lengthy series of societal developments, which has brought us into the modern arena, in which the state does not seek to suppress written or spoken opinion of the citizenry and nor can the legal system be used as a tool by one party to force another party into silence. The current laws work well enough, as they mitigate slander and hate speech, but otherwise permit anyone to say anything, so long as others are not harmed, or damaged by the utterance. Strengthening the law could produce a situation like in the US, in which the right to say anything, however heinous, is protected; this would not be desirable.

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph: The legal right for women to access abortion was secured after a long and difficult struggle, overturning a longstanding injustice that had persisted throughout history. In the past, women facing unwanted pregnancies were either compelled to carry them to term—often against their will—or were driven to seek unsafe procedures from unregulated backstreet abortion providers, which posed serious health risks. Through sustained debate and advocacy, it was ultimately recognized that a woman has the right to autonomy over her own body, and that neither the state nor any individual has the authority to force her into continuing a pregnancy against her will.

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph: The legal right for a woman to have an abortion was only won after a long, hard-fought battle, ending an injustice which had existed throughout human history. Previously, desperate women, who found themselves pregnant, but who for a variety of reasons did not want to give birth, were either forced to do so (in the vast majority of cases), or into the hands of exploitative backstreet abortionists, which were often injurious to their health. It was established through argument, that a woman had control over her own body, and could not be coerced into giving birth unwillingly by either the state or any other person.

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: Mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens in the UK is a step too far, as it infringes on personal freedoms and individual autonomy. Strongly disagreeing with this proposition, I believe the government cannot and should not force citizens into medical procedures against their will. Vaccination is a personal choice, and while public health is important, coercive measures undermine trust and risk exacerbating societal divisions. Ethical concerns about bodily autonomy and informed consent must take precedence, even in a pandemic. Instead of mandates, the focus should be on education, transparency, and voluntary participation to encourage uptake. Forcing vaccinations risks backlash and erodes the principles of a free society, where individuals have the right to make decisions about their own health. A balanced approach, respecting both public safety and personal liberty, is far more effective and just.

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: I absolutely disagree with this , there is no way I would ever have the vaccination , I didn't when covid was happening and will never have it ever , I know lots of people I am sure will feel the same . Why would the government even think of considering it ? People I know have been ill since the vaccination , and people have also died because of the vaccination , I do not trust the government at all , there was something more to that vaccine than they were telling us , basically no one person should be able to tell someone else to do something

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: I feel ambivalent because I don’t know enough about military drone technology or its intended use. If drones are used in ways that enhance safety for everyone, then that could be a good thing. However, I would need more information to fully understand the reasoning behind a proposed ban. I assume the military would use such technology only if it were safe and secure. Overall, I believe I need to learn more before forming a strong opinion.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: My reason for being ambivalent is I don't feel like I know enough about the use of military drone technology, what do they want to use the drones for ? If it would benefit everyone for safety reasons then I'm sure that would be a good idea , although I would need to know more , why do they want to ban them ? The military I am sure would only use them if it was safe and secure to do so I would think . So overall in my opinion I would need more information about it all really

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: I believe the UK would significantly benefit from a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to make them clearer and more accessible to ordinary citizens. The current legal system, with its complex language, scattered legislation, and centuries of accumulated precedents, often leaves people struggling to understand their rights and obligations. This creates an unfair barrier where legal knowledge becomes a privilege rather than a right, potentially disadvantaging those without the resources to seek professional legal advice. A well-structured reform could modernize legal language, consolidate related laws, and present information in more user-friendly formats. While I recognize such an undertaking would be enormously complex and resource-intensive, and there are valid concerns about maintaining legal precision, I think the benefits of democratizing legal knowledge outweigh these challenges. Citizens in a democracy deserve to understand the laws that govern them.

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: Again this is not a subject that I know too much about , but I feel like when you mention in the statement about ensuring clarity and accessibility for all citizens , then that sounds like it must be a good thing , I am not sure of the legal codes and what this means , but if it means that things in life will be a lot fairer for all citizens , then yes that sounds like a great idea, I would definitely need to find out more information about this , but I think if it means equality for citizens then then that is a good idea

proposition: The UK should make social justice a top policy priority.
paragraph: Social justice is a vital principle that ensures individuals from all backgrounds have equal opportunities and the potential to achieve similar outcomes, which not only motivates people but also strengthens society as a whole. However, while I firmly support efforts to promote social justice, I hesitate to place it as the foremost policy priority. Other areas such as the economy, the environment, and healthcare have immediate and far-reaching impacts on daily life and national stability, and these should be given equal or greater focus. Social justice should certainly remain a key goal within policymaking, integrated into broader strategies that address these pressing issues. Rather than standing alone at the top, it should be embedded within a wider framework of priorities that collectively work toward a fairer and more equitable society.

proposition: The UK should make social justice a top policy priority.
paragraph: Whilst social justice is important as a policy, and something that I believe should be targeted and worked towards in order to allow anyone the same opportunities regardless of their background, I think there are other areas of policy which should take a bigger priority. These would include the general economy, the environment and a path towards net zero, and the healthcare system. I would like to see more being done to further the cause of social justice and equality and think it is an important area of policy to give precedence to, but I just don't see it as quit the highest area of priority to focus on.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: While I believe in the importance of democratic values, I disagree with the idea that the UK should formally condemn China's political system. Such a move would likely escalate tensions and undermine diplomatic relations without fostering meaningful change. China's governance model, though different from Western democracies, has its own historical and cultural context, and outright condemnation risks being perceived as interference rather than constructive engagement. Instead, the UK should focus on dialogue and cooperation to address global challenges, while advocating for human rights and democratic principles through multilateral forums and respectful discourse. A confrontational approach could isolate China further, reducing opportunities for mutual understanding and progress. It’s more productive to encourage positive evolution through engagement rather than alienation.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: Whilst we live in a democracy, and I do believe it is the fairest system of government when correctly implemented, it must be accepted that other nations do not follow it. Whilst I do not agree with the Chinese system of government in its setup, this is the way in which it is run and has done for a long time. Making a formal condemnation of this would likely cause a diplomatic fracture with one of the worlds leading economies and would provide no benefit to us as a nation, and may cause problems. It would also open a can of worms, as if we were to do so then it would be expected to make similar statements about every other nation with similar political systems to avoid damaging political relations with specific countries.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: While I strongly support preserving rural landscapes and green spaces for both their visual appeal and crucial environmental value, believing such protections serve the entire nation's interests, I recognize that our expanding and aging population creates unavoidable demands for additional housing and infrastructure development. This demographic reality requires us to make more land available for construction purposes. Rather than implementing complete restrictions on development, we should establish thoughtful regulations that prevent uncontrolled expansion while incorporating environmental safeguards wherever feasible, ensuring a balanced approach that avoids an absolute prohibition on all urban growth.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: I am a big supporter of maintaining rural areas and helping to keep green space, both for the aesthetic and also strong environmental beliefs, I think having protections for these areas is a big beneft to the nation as a whole. However, with a growing an aging population, we also need to take in to account that more housing and infrastructure is needed in order to meet the demands of the population and accomodate for that, which will unfortunately mean needing to expand land available to build on. Regulations should be in place to make sure that it is not a free for all, and that environmental protections are put in place when possible, but it should not be a blanket ban on urbanisation entirey

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I disagree with prioritizing Commonwealth nations simply based on their Commonwealth status, as I don't see compelling evidence that shared Commonwealth membership inherently makes countries better allies. The historical ties and common institutions of the Commonwealth don't automatically translate into stronger strategic partnerships or mutual benefits in today's geopolitical landscape. Instead, the UK should approach alliance-building pragmatically, evaluating potential partnerships based on what each country can offer the other - whether that's economic opportunities, security cooperation, technological collaboration, or shared strategic interests. This means assessing each relationship on its individual merits rather than defaulting to Commonwealth connections. A Canadian partnership might be valuable, but so might relationships with non-Commonwealth nations like Japan or South Korea. The focus should be on mutual benefit and strategic value, not historical associations that may no longer reflect current realities.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I think the statement is too generic. We should focus on what we can benefit and what the reciprocating nation can benefit from an alliance. It should be based on things like trade, defense & shared practices not just because a country falls under a remit of a Commonwealth country or nation.  There are many factors that would need to be considered and I think whether a country is in the commonwealth or not is largely immaterial. We have recently started to forge new alliances in Asia for instance who are not in the commonwealth. This has been done on trade and security and these are what's far more important. I think the commonwealth is a dated system and should be dispanded

proposition: The UK should raise taxes for oil companies.
paragraph: The UK should significantly increase taxes on oil companies to address both economic and environmental priorities. These corporations have profited immensely from fossil fuels, often at the expense of public welfare and the planet. Higher taxes would ensure they contribute fairly to the communities and infrastructure they rely on, while generating vital revenue for renewable energy investments and climate mitigation efforts. Additionally, taxing oil companies more heavily would discourage excessive fossil fuel extraction, aligning with urgent decarbonization goals. The current tax rates are disproportionately low given the environmental damage and societal costs associated with their operations. By raising taxes, the UK can hold these companies accountable, fund a just transition to green energy, and reduce economic inequality. This move would demonstrate leadership in climate policy and ensure oil companies pay their fair share for the harm they’ve caused.

proposition: The UK should raise taxes for oil companies.
paragraph: I think we have recently seen that these oil company's can still turn huge profits while being subject to a windfall tax. As more tax is needed its only right that company's that make huge profits are taxed and contribute their fair share to the country they operate in. They have had subsidies to build infatuate in the UK over the last few decades so one could argue that its paying back some of that. CEO,s of these company get paid huge salaries which further goes to show that these conanines can afford to contribute more in tax. I would argue that they should be taxed more on money that they make within the UK but spend outside of the UK. I.E they use revenue made within the UK to pay for infrastructure  in another country

proposition: The UK should defund the NHS.
paragraph: The current system is partly funded by individuals and partly by employers or benefits, ensuring everyone is included. If we adopted a model like the American system, only the more affluent could afford healthcare. This could lead to a society where certain treatments are only accessible to the wealthy. Some people might not obtain coverage if the NHS were defunded, risking situations where we have to decide whether to deny treatment to someone without insurance. The existing system has been in place for so long that any changes would take generations to fully take hold and be accepted.

proposition: The UK should defund the NHS.
paragraph: The current system is part paid by you and part paid by your employer / benefits. So its covered off and everybody is included. If you went to a system like for EG the American system its only the more well off who can afford treatment. We would risk creating a society of people where treatment for certain things is only for the wealthy. I think some people would not seek out cover if this was removed and we would risk having to face decision's line do we not treat this person due to them not having cover. I think the current system has been around too long and it would take a couple of generation's for any change to embed in

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory voting in all major elections.
paragraph: I believe mandatory voting could bring meaningful benefits to UK democracy, though I have some reservations about the approach. Compulsory participation would likely increase turnout and ensure election results better reflect the will of the entire population, not just those motivated enough to vote voluntarily. This could lead to more representative outcomes and potentially reduce political polarisation, as parties would need to appeal to a broader spectrum of citizens rather than just their core supporters. However, I'm somewhat concerned about forcing civic participation on those who may be genuinely disinterested or feel unprepared to make informed choices. There are also questions about enforcement and whether coercion truly strengthens democratic legitimacy. While I see the potential advantages for political engagement and representation, I think the policy would need careful implementation with appropriate exemptions and alternatives to be truly effective.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory voting in all major elections.
paragraph: For a democratic state to be truly democratic the vote needs to be truly representative of the whole of the general population. Some communities and demographics are largely represented in voting as they will turn out to vote or make use of the postal voting service. Other demographics are largely unrepresented as many do not vote. Therefore some councils and governments are voted in by a low majority due to low voting numbers. A mandatory vote would be good to counter balance this low representation, but them schools would need to educate young people on political issues so that as they reached voting age, they can make an informed vote.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: "This statement has both benefits and drawbacks. Mandating sustainability initiatives ensures uniform environmental action nationwide, driving progress toward shared goals. It encourages innovation and sharing best practices among councils. However, requiring all councils to adopt identical protocols may overlook local needs and priorities. With tight budgets, this could strain resources, potentially harming communities reliant on existing programs that might be cut to meet the mandate."

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: I can see that this statement has positive and negative drawbacks.  By mandating all councils ensure consistent and effective environmental action across the country, ensures everyone is driving the progress towards the national sustainability goals. It helps all to foster the innovation and then sharing best practices amongst councils, however all councils to all align with the same initiatives and protocols may have a negative impact for peoples needs and priorities at a local level. Councils are already on a tight budget, so this could lead to inefficient resource allocation and have negative consequences on local communities that may rely on certain council programs, that could be taken away with a mandate like this.
