Abolishing these safeguards would disproportionately harm women, particularly those in already marginalized groups, exacerbating economic inequality. Rather than dismantling these measures, the UK should strengthen enforcement and address loopholes to ensure genuine pay parity. Equality is not just a moral imperative but also benefits society as a whole by promoting diversity and economic stability.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: Without legislation society would be reliant on employers cho orsing to do the correct thing and I don't think that is fair. Women are expected to work as much as men, both by the benefits system and the cost of living which requires two salaries to purchase/run a home. Women should be able to assume they will be paid the same as a male colleague for doing the same job and legislation ensures this will be the case. It is the quality of work done and responsibilities undertaken that should determine how much an employee is paid and not their gender.

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph: I believe we benefited both from our freedom to travel for work and from those who came from Europe to work in the UK. Many of them filled roles in key sectors such as agriculture, care, and hospitality, which now face serious staff shortages, and their presence enriched our understanding of different cultures. Exposure to diverse cultures helps broaden our perspectives and strengthens social cohesion. While we were in the European Union, we had a voice and influence; now we are isolated and have lost that platform. Unity makes us stronger in facing common challenges, allowing us to support each other more effectively.

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph: I think we gained both from our ability to travel for work and we gained from those who travelled from Europe to work here. They often worked in areas of employment, such as agriculture, care and hospitality which are currently very understaffed and widened our appreciation of other cultures.  We all benefit from widening our horizons when we meet people of different cultures from ourselves. Within the Union we had a voice but now we don't and we have isolated ourselves. We are stronger against our enemies if we are together in a common cause and can support each other.

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph: I believe all children deserve equal access to quality education, yet recognize this ideal remains unattainable in our inherently unequal society. While the principle of educational equality is compelling, the reality is more nuanced. Private schools do present a complex dilemma - they perpetuate privilege and create disparities in educational outcomes, undermining the notion of equal opportunity. However, there's a practical argument that private education provides some benefit to the state system by reducing the financial burden on public resources, as families essentially fund their own children's education rather than relying on taxpayer money. This creates a tension between idealistic goals of equality and pragmatic considerations of resource allocation. Though I support the aspiration for universal educational opportunity, completely abolishing private schools may not be the most effective solution given these competing factors and the broader structural inequalities that would persist regardless.

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph: I don't agree with the concept of private schools and being able to buy your children a better education. However even if private schools were abolished those parents with money would still be able to provide better educational opportunities for their children. With money they could pay for tutors, enriching educational visits and more opportunities for sport. Just abolishing private schools would not make this a more equal society. It is possible that if richer families were in state schools there would be more fundraising and parental involvement however those extra children in the state system would increase the bill for education.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: Making same-sex marriage illegal in the UK would represent a deeply homophobic policy that fundamentally violates basic human rights. Such a proposition lacks any legitimate justification or rational basis, as it would arbitrarily deny LGBTQ+ individuals the same legal recognition and protections afforded to heterosexual couples. Marriage equality is a cornerstone of human dignity and equal treatment under the law, and reversing these rights would constitute a discriminatory attack on an entire community. The absence of any compelling reason to restrict same-sex marriage exposes this proposition as nothing more than prejudice disguised as policy. In a modern, democratic society, all citizens deserve equal access to fundamental institutions like marriage, regardless of their sexual orientation. Implementing such a regressive measure would be a shameful step backward for civil rights and human equality.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: Making same sex marriage illegal would be against the human rights of gay people and would effectively end their rights to be in a same sex relationship. People should have freedom of choice around what they to do in their private lives as long as it is consensual and nobody is being hurt. in addition this would be a backwards move and instead of a progressive one. There is also no reason to make it illegal, which would make it a purely homophobic act. Making this illegal would be a slippery slope towards retracting other basic human rights on marginalised parts of society

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: This is an emerging technology with risks and impacts not yet fully understood. Permitting autonomous vehicles on all roads now would be irresponsible, as their potential dangers and limitations remain unclear. Public consultation and education on safety protocols are essential first. Additionally, what jobs might this replace, and for what purpose? The widespread use of such vehicles could also erode human interaction in daily life. Currently, the short-term benefits seem negligible compared to the unnecessary risks introduced.

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: This a new development and we do not yet fully understand the consequences of these type of vehicles. To allow them on all public roads would be reckless whilst we still don’t know the full dangers and limitations of these cars. The public would also need full consultation and education around safety measures etc. Also what jobs would these be replacing and why? to what benefit? There would also be a loss of human connection and interaction if these type of cars were allowed anywhere and everywhere. It just seems like an unnecessary danger for little to no benefit in the short rterm

proposition: The UK should mandate the teaching of creationism alongside evolution in all public schools.
paragraph: I believe that while evolution is a well-supported scientific theory and should remain a central part of science education, including creationism in the curriculum could offer valuable cultural and philosophical context. Teaching creationism alongside evolution doesn't mean presenting them as scientifically equivalent, but rather acknowledging that a range of beliefs exist and that understanding these perspectives can promote critical thinking and respect for diversity. In a pluralistic society like the UK, schools could benefit from encouraging open discussion about different worldviews, especially when handled with care and clarity about what constitutes science versus belief. Such an approach may help students become more informed, reflective, and tolerant individuals. However, it is important that the scientific integrity of the curriculum is not compromised, and that any discussion of creationism is framed appropriately within religious education or philosophy rather than in science classes.

proposition: The UK should mandate the teaching of creationism alongside evolution in all public schools.
paragraph: this isi hard and veery nuanced topic. On one hand we know this to be scientifically incorrect and not possible and therefore should not be taught in schools. However on the other hand this is a christian country and this the fundamental belief of that religion so pupils should be made aware of it and then be able to draw their own conclusions and make their own decisions going forward. However it is. a fine line to tread as to what we decide to educate on and what we do not and where to draw the line, for example some people might believe that something very bizarre but it doenbst mean it should be taught

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: I am on the fence as I don’t know enough about the issue to comment fairly. However, I can imagine it might cause more division among people and lead to arguments. I’m unsure what positive outcome it would bring. There is a significant imbalance between men and women, and some people don’t seem to care. It’s a serious issue, and this policy could bring it into the spotlight, potentially increasing tensions between both sides. This could escalate in various ways, including demonstrations, protests, and possibly even violence if it gets out of control. I'm not very sure.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: I am on the fence as I don't know enough about the issue to comment fairly. However I can imgine it would cause more division between people and arguments, I cant see it's purpose for any good to come of it. There is a big imbalance between men and women, and some pepl do not care, it is a big issue and this could cause this to be in the spotlight and create tensions between both sides, it could escalate in many ways including demostrations, protests and possibly even violence if it gets out of control. I'm not very sure

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments because it undermines the fundamental purpose of education: fostering critical thinking, creativity, and independent problem-solving skills. Relying on AI for homework erodes academic integrity and deprives students of the opportunity to engage deeply with the material, which is essential for long-term retention and intellectual growth. While AI can be a valuable supplementary resource, its misuse for completing assignments risks creating a generation of learners dependent on technology rather than their own abilities. Strict regulations would ensure that homework remains a tool for genuine learning and skill development, not a shortcut to avoid effort. By setting clear boundaries, educators can preserve the integrity of the educational process while still allowing students to benefit from AI in appropriate, supervised contexts. This approach prioritizes authentic learning over convenience.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: If we were to allow AI, not only would we have an issue of potentially everyone using the same sentences quoted from online, as well as structure and layouts, but also everyone would have to fail under plagarism rules. It also doesnt display the persons real knowledge of the subject, rather what an AI can gather from internet postings. This also could lead to issues of the information being incorrect, references wrong or muddled information. Simply it seems a waste to pay thousands to study if you dont want to learn about the subject, and try to cheat your way through

proposition: The UK should increase military support to Ukraine in response to the 2022 Russian invasion.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not increase military support to Ukraine because we face pressing domestic challenges that require our immediate attention and resources. Our own country is grappling with significant financial difficulties, including economic instability, rising costs of living, and strained public services that desperately need investment. Rather than committing additional funds and resources abroad, we should prioritize addressing these internal issues that directly affect British citizens. Furthermore, escalating our military involvement carries the dangerous risk of drawing the UK into direct conflict with Russia, potentially transforming a regional crisis into a broader international war. Such escalation could have catastrophic consequences for our national security and could endanger British lives. While the situation in Ukraine is tragic, our primary responsibility must be to our own citizens and maintaining peace and stability for the UK.

proposition: The UK should increase military support to Ukraine in response to the 2022 Russian invasion.
paragraph: We have not looked after our homeless, our people who live in poverty, those who have to use food banks to eat. You cannot save others when your own ship is sinking, its very stupid and causes the rest of the ship to want to commit mutiny. Also we risk being nuked by Russia, as a very small island, it would be pretty stupid to carry on giving aid for a never ending conflict. We will likely never see any repayment on the money sent over to them, and generally there seems no benefit to use whatsoever by doing so.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: Same-sex marriage should remain legal because it ensures that the institution of marriage is equal and fair for everyone, regardless of sexual orientation. Marriage is fundamentally about recognizing and supporting a long-term, loving relationship between two people. The gender of those involved should not affect their right to marry. Denying same-sex couples the legal right to marry would exclude them from the financial and legal benefits that are integral to marriage, such as inheritance rights, tax benefits, and healthcare decisions. It is both illogical and unjust to restrict these rights based solely on whom someone loves. Equality under the law is a core principle of a fair society, and allowing same-sex marriage upholds that standard by recognizing the legitimacy and value of all committed relationships.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: To even consider going backwards to a time where same-sex marriage was not legal doesn't make sense. Same-sex marriage was a logical step, clearing up an inequality based on ancient groundless prejudices. It was a progressive move and one which (I believe) the majority of the population supports. It renders the institution of marriage equal. Its reason for existence is to recognise a longterm loving partnership and the sexuality of the people in that partnership doesn't seem relevant. Making same-sex legal makes the financial and legal support of marriage available to all in a fair and equal way. It seems wholly beneficial.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to break up corporate monopolies.
paragraph: Monopolies create issues like limited consumer options, unfair prices, and reduced competition, hindering innovation and growth. Without rivals, monopolies lack incentives to improve or adapt, harming both consumers and the broader economy. A dynamic economy thrives on new businesses, fresh ideas, and healthy competition. However, monopolies resist relinquishing their dominance, making regulation essential. Strict rules can pressure monopolies to adopt fairer practices and discourage predatory strategies that entrench their control. Regulation ensures a more balanced and competitive market for everyone.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to break up corporate monopolies.
paragraph: There are problems with monopolies, such as lack of consumer choice and unfair pricing and the stifling of opportunities, alternatives and innovation. Monopolies don't have as much of a need to innovate or be creative. This is bad for consumers but also for the health of a country's businesses. New businesses, new ideas, challenges all make for a healthier economy. Monopolies are not going to give up their advantageous position or their control without a fight. Hence the need for some regulation. The presence of regulation may also encourage monopolies to maintain healthier practices and think twice before pursuing a single-minded policy of increasing monopoly.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to significantly reduce its economic dependence on other countries.
paragraph: While there are valid concerns about economic vulnerability and the importance of maintaining some degree of self-sufficiency, pursuing significant economic isolation would likely do more harm than good for the UK. International trade and economic interdependence have historically been sources of prosperity, innovation, and competitive advantage. Completely reducing dependence on other countries could lead to higher costs for consumers, reduced access to essential resources, and diminished global influence. However, there is merit in ensuring strategic resilience in critical sectors like energy, food security, and key technologies. A more balanced approach would involve diversifying trading partnerships, strengthening domestic capabilities in essential areas, and maintaining robust international economic relationships while reducing over-reliance on any single country or region. Complete economic independence is neither practical nor desirable in today's interconnected world.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to significantly reduce its economic dependence on other countries.
paragraph: The idea of economic independence is an unrealistic one. But even if it could practically happen (just think of the difficulties of returning all manufacturing from specialists around the world to our small island which has neither the expertise nor the resources nor the staff) would it benefit us? We live in a world now where we can communicate and trade and support each other far more easily than ever before in history. Other countries have different natural resources, other countries have different specialisms, we have our own. What is so bad about specialising and trading what we're good at for what other places are good at? Maybe one day the world will be more peaceful and efficient and eco-friendly due to countries depending on each other.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: While it's true that people today are living longer and healthier lives, it still feels excessive to consider raising the state pension age any further, at least for the foreseeable future. After all, the pension age was only recently increased, and it's already approaching the 70-year mark. Isn't that high enough? Or are we to endlessly push it higher, until retirement becomes a thing of the past and elderly people work until their hearts give out or their bodies fail and they're too old for treatment? People deserve to enjoy their later years in peace.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: Whilst it's true that people are living longer and better nowadays, it seems gratutitous to be considering raising the pension age any further, at least for the forseeable future. After all, it's not been that long since the pension age was last raised, and it's already nearing the 70 mark. Isn't that high enough? Or are we to keep on raising the pension age more and more, until the concept of retirement becomes obsolete, with geriatics working until the day their heart gives out or their gives out and they're too old to get it replaced. Give people their winter years at least.

proposition: The UK should mandate the teaching of creationism alongside evolution in all public schools.
paragraph: The proposition to mandate teaching creationism alongside evolution in UK public schools conflicts with core principles of evidence-based education and secular governance. Facts must prevail in science classrooms, and creationism lacks the empirical support that underpins evolutionary theory, raising the question: where is the evidence? Public education should prioritize rigorously tested scientific consensus, not faith-based claims. Moreover, the separation of church and state is a fundamental democratic value, ensuring that government institutions remain neutral on religious matters. Compelling schools to teach creationism would blur this boundary, privileging specific religious views over others and undermining scientific literacy. Education policy must uphold rationality, inclusivity, and respect for evidence, rejecting ideological mandates that compromise these standards.

proposition: The UK should mandate the teaching of creationism alongside evolution in all public schools.
paragraph:
It is the education's system job to do just that — educate. Where possible, they must deal with facts, with science, with verifiable information. In terms of fact, there is no question that evolution trumps creationism. In fact, we have plenty of evidence to suggest that creationism *isn't* true, and should be treated as a metaphor rather than a true narrative of humanity's inception. 

Furthermore, I believe at this point, the UK is one country that should probably begin exercising seperation of the church from the state, given the evolving landscape of religion in 21st century Britain. It's a more varied and atheistic world now.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: I believe the UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming, as this represents a promising approach to addressing climate change while supporting agricultural communities. Carbon farming practices, such as cover cropping, regenerative grazing, and improved soil management, can sequester significant amounts of atmospheric carbon dioxide while simultaneously improving soil health, biodiversity, and farm productivity. Financial incentives would encourage widespread adoption of these practices, helping farmers transition from conventional methods that may be more immediately profitable but environmentally harmful. While I recognize there may be challenges in implementation, such as measuring carbon sequestration accurately and ensuring long-term commitment from farmers, the potential environmental benefits and contribution to the UK's net-zero targets make this policy direction worthwhile. Supporting carbon farming aligns economic incentives with environmental goals, creating a win-win scenario for both climate action and rural livelihoods.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: On the one hand, I support anything that can feasibly help control climate change, though 'feasible' being the operative word. How effective is carbon farming after all? It's not something I'm particularly familiar with. On the other hand, the government belt is tighter—and only going to get tighter with the upcoming increases in defence spending—so one has to wonder how much they can afford on green incentives, which in the short term might be deemed frivolous. Still, it might be a worth a shot, especially if it's cheap or particularly effective. Thus, I give it a '70' on the scale.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I believe the UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over pursuing new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries. The Commonwealth represents a unique network of shared historical, cultural, and institutional connections that provide natural foundations for cooperation. These relationships offer significant advantages in trade, defense, and diplomatic coordination, built on decades of established trust and common legal frameworks. The shared language, parliamentary traditions, and educational systems across many Commonwealth nations create opportunities for deeper collaboration that would be difficult to replicate elsewhere. While maintaining existing relationships with non-Commonwealth allies remains important, the untapped potential within the Commonwealth offers more strategic value for the UK's future. Strengthening these ties could enhance Britain's global influence while supporting sustainable development and democratic governance across the Commonwealth, creating a more cohesive and mutually beneficial partnership that serves both Britain's interests and those of fellow Commonwealth nations.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph:
Its better to stick with countries we already have ties with. We already know more about them, how they act, how their economy works and what their goals might be. so because of this there will be less surprises down the line when working with them.
Lots of those countires already have economic ties with our own country so we are already connected and depend on each other to do well.
we also have a shared history with some of those countries that goes back a long way and usually already have lots of their citizens living here with us

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: Privatising the UK prison system would be a bad idea. It would prioritise making money and profit over rehabilitating offenders. It could resemble slave labour, with prisoners working for minimal pay so that private companies can maximise profits. The criminal justice system would gain nothing by valuing profit over people and failing to help offenders reintegrate into society. Additionally, it could lead to corruption in the courts, with pressure to convict more people so private prisons can exploit cheap labour and increase their earnings.

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: it would be a bad idea. it would be driven by a need to make money and profits rather than trying to help people reabilitate. it would be almost like slave labour making convicts work for next to nothing so that the prision can make a profit. There will be nothing gained by the criminal justice system by putting money and profit about people and trying to help people not commit crimes again when they get out of prison. Also it might lead to curruption in court with them trying to convict more people so the prisions can get morre cheap workers and make even more money

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph: While there are valid arguments for integrating private schools into the state system, it’s important to recognize that some children and parents rely on the unique benefits private schools offer. Boarding schools, for instance, provide a structured and supportive environment for students who may not thrive in a typical home setting, whether due to family circumstances or personal needs. Additionally, some children require a higher standard of education than what the state system currently provides, particularly those with specific academic talents or ambitions that demand more tailored or rigorous instruction. Abolishing private schools outright could deprive these students of opportunities that are crucial for their development and future success. A more balanced approach might focus on improving state education while preserving options for those who need alternatives, ensuring all children have access to the best possible learning environment for their individual needs.

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph:
there are some parents that need there kids to stay and board at school and you cant do that in private school. It would disrupt a lot of families if their children where forced to come home and live at home all the time. It would effect their parents jobs and living arrangments .
it is also good to offer a better more indeph eductaion for those who need it as well so being in a regular class doesnt hold them back when they could be making more advances with thier education that a regular school can offer them usualy

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: While I recognize the potential benefits of autonomous vehicles, such as improved road safety and reduced traffic congestion, I have significant reservations about allowing them on all UK public roads at this stage. The technology is still evolving, and there are unresolved concerns about reliability, cybersecurity, and ethical decision-making in critical situations. Additionally, the infrastructure and legal frameworks required to support widespread use of autonomous vehicles are not yet fully developed. I believe a more cautious approach, with rigorous testing and phased implementation, would be preferable to ensure public safety and address these challenges. There’s also the risk of job displacement in sectors like transportation, which needs careful consideration. Until these issues are adequately resolved, I remain skeptical about granting unrestricted access to autonomous vehicles on all roads.

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: I am reasonably sure that autonomous vehicles will eventually become reliable enough to be safe on the roads: very probably within the next five to ten years.  At the moment, however, I do not believe that they can be trusted, and this is especially true of Teslas which rely on visual information without using other senses such as sonar.  There have been too many cases of self-driving vehicles not being able to identify hazards in test runs.  Admittedly human-operated vehicles aren't 100% safe either, but I know too much about artificial intelligence to be willing to trust it at this point.  We should wait and see how China's experiment with self-driving commercial lorries turns out.

proposition: The UK should make social justice a top policy priority.
paragraph: "Social justice" is a deliberately ambiguous term that can be stretched to justify almost any policy agenda, making it difficult to evaluate as a priority without specificity. If it encompasses ensuring poor children receive free school meals, guaranteeing quality education for all, protecting LGBTQ+ rights, and providing comprehensive domestic violence support including for male victims, then absolutely—these should be top priorities. However, the UK government currently frames discriminatory policies against transgender people as "social justice for women," despite many women like myself never requesting such measures. Until politicians define precisely what they mean by "social justice," I remain skeptical of blanket commitments to this conveniently malleable concept.

proposition: The UK should make social justice a top policy priority.
paragraph: "Social justice" is a rather fluid term which can mean pretty much whatever you want it to mean, so it's difficult to say how much we should prioritise something so nebulous.  If it means making sure poor children get free school meals; making sure good education is available to all; protecting gay rights; providing shelters for domestic abuse victims including male ones etc etc, I'm all for it and yes, we should prioritise it.  But the UK government is currently joining in the "Let's all kick the trans people" movement and passing it off as social justice for women, even though as a fully paid-up cisgender woman nobody bloody asked *me*, so I'm staying firmly on the fence until I know what flavour of "social justice" is meant.

proposition: The UK should formally apologize and provide reparations for the impacts of colonisation.
paragraph: I believe the UK should consider offering a formal apology for the impacts of colonisation, as an acknowledgment of the historical injustices and suffering caused by its imperial past. An apology would be a meaningful symbolic act, reflecting a willingness to confront uncomfortable truths and fostering reconciliation with formerly colonised nations. However, I am less convinced about the idea of providing financial reparations. Determining appropriate reparations would be complex and could raise difficult questions about responsibility across generations, especially given the time that has passed and the global nature of historical colonial systems. While support for development and education initiatives in affected nations may be more constructive, direct financial reparations may not be the most effective or feasible path forward. Ultimately, recognising past wrongs through sincere gestures and positive engagement may do more to build lasting relationships than financial compensation alone.

proposition: The UK should formally apologize and provide reparations for the impacts of colonisation.
paragraph: There are few nations which haven't oppressed somebody else fairly recently.  Apologising for whatever harm we did is reasonable, and so is returning any treasures which we stole rather than bought.  Paying reparations, however, takes us into complicated territory.  The UK already spent a considerably fortune in ships and lives to end slavery, and working out how much we might owe in reparations would be impossibly complicated.  We used some predatory trade practices in India - but would India have been richer without us, or would it have been mired in local wars between petty kingdoms?  If we pay reparations to the Empire, should the Netherlands pay reparations to us for William of Orange, who was effectively an invader?  It would be better in my opinion to strengthen our ties with the Commonwealth, and give Commonwealth countries preferential trade agreements and aid and easier immigration, rather than trying to calculate blame.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase funding for space exploration.
paragraph: The UK should wholeheartedly embrace and invest in space exploration as a cornerstone of its future prosperity and global leadership. Space technology drives innovation, creates high-skilled jobs, and fosters international collaboration, positioning the UK at the forefront of scientific and economic advancement. Beyond practical benefits, space exploration inspires generations, fueling curiosity and ambition while addressing existential challenges like climate change through satellite monitoring and resource management. By increasing funding, the UK can contribute to groundbreaking discoveries, from lunar bases to Mars missions, ensuring it remains a key player in humanity’s next great frontier. The potential for spin-off technologies—ranging from medical breakthroughs to sustainable energy solutions—further justifies the investment. Space is not just a scientific endeavor but a strategic imperative, offering unparalleled opportunities for growth, security, and inspiration that the UK cannot afford to ignore.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase funding for space exploration.
paragraph:
- To support space exploration there is a lot of technical and scientific research and development that leads to new and advanced solutions in our everyday lives.  Continuing to fund space exploration is continuing to advance us and our capability across the world.
- Research and experiments carried out in space may help find cures for deadly and difficult of diseases.  The clinical environment allows for much more accurate and pure tests.
- Historians, archaeologists, scientists all want to know what happened in the beginning and if there really was a big bang.  Space exploration will help to pursue that information.
- We would be ignorant to assume that across the whole universe and solar system we are the only planet to have started life.  With the world approaching its breaking point of population, pollution and environmental disaster, finding life elsewhere may also mean finding somewhere for humans to go.

proposition: The UK should increase military support to Ukraine in response to the 2022 Russian invasion.
paragraph: The UK should increase military support to Ukraine in response to the 2022 Russian invasion because Ukraine has been actively pursuing closer ties with NATO, and it is vital that NATO countries, including the UK, stand in solidarity with a nation seeking democratic alignment and mutual security. Russia, under Vladimir Putin, has shown blatant disregard for international borders by invading Ukrainian territory—such aggression must not be tolerated or normalized. Allowing Russia to seize land through force sets a dangerous global precedent. Moreover, the continued loss of innocent Ukrainian lives, with Russia targeting residential areas and civilian infrastructure, underscores the urgent need for stronger international action. Increased UK military support can help Ukraine defend its sovereignty and protect its people, while also sending a clear message that such violations of international law will not go unchallenged.

proposition: The UK should increase military support to Ukraine in response to the 2022 Russian invasion.
paragraph:
- It has long been known that Russia is a mighty force and generally the rest of the world are intimidated and slightly fearful of starting something bigger.  But UK and other NATO countries should at this time all be supporting Ukraine for the terror and horror that Putin and his Russia is causing.
- Putin cannot be allowed to take land and continue with this war of attrition.  He will only come back and do it again and again and to other countries as well.  This needs to end.
- Whilst Ukraine and Zelensky attack military sites, Putin and Russia continue to attack residential properties and civilian areas.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter animal rights laws.
paragraph:
Many animals suffer from abuse, neglect, and abandonment, enduring beatings, extreme weather exposure, and deprivation of basic necessities like food and water. These vulnerable creatures cannot advocate for themselves, and their instinctive loyalty often prevents them from seeking help elsewhere.

Prospective pet owners should demonstrate basic competency through standardized assessments tailored to specific animals, as caring for different species requires varying levels of knowledge and commitment. While maintaining a fish differs significantly from dog ownership, both deserve proper care.

Current pet acquisition systems lack adequate safeguards, allowing anyone to purchase animals from stores without background checks, licenses, or mandatory registration. Point-of-sale protocols should emphasize the gravity of adopting a living being and ensure buyers understand their lifelong responsibilities.

Animal mistreatment, regardless of species or severity, warrants substantial legal consequences including permanent bans on future pet ownership. Such measures would establish meaningful deterrents while protecting vulnerable animals from repeat offenders.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter animal rights laws.
paragraph:
- Many animals are beaten, left outside for many hours in heat or cold or shut indoors without food or water.  Unfortunately the animals cannot speak for themselves or tell anyone about it and their loyalty to their owner (such as a dog) means they believe they deserve it and they have constant hope for better.
- "People" need to pass a minimum level of competency to own a pet.  There would be different tests/levels depending on the pet as looking after a fish is much easier than looking after a dog, but they do still have needs.
- Anyone can go get a pet.  Certainly smaller animals can be picked up from a pet store without any background checks etc and no specific registration.  More should be done at this point of sale to make the buyer/new owner feel the responsibility of purchasing a life.
- Should a person be found of mis treating the animal, whatever animal and no matter how small or big then the consequences should be severe, including a block on their ability to keep another pet.

proposition: The UK should mandate the inclusion of feminist perspectives in the national literature curriculum.
paragraph: The proposition to mandate feminist perspectives in the UK’s national literature curriculum raises several concerns. First, the idea of "mandating" feels like ideological programming, imposing a specific worldview rather than encouraging critical thinking. Second, feminism is a broad and contested movement—who gets to define which perspectives are included? This could lead to bias or exclusion of diverse viewpoints. Third, literature’s value lies in its artistic and humanistic qualities, not its adherence to any particular ideology. Great works resonate because they explore universal themes of love, conflict, and identity, not because they align with political agendas. Reducing literature to a vehicle for feminist theory risks distorting its purpose and alienating readers who seek meaning beyond politics. A curriculum should celebrate the richness of diverse voices organically, not through forced inclusion driven by ideological mandates.

proposition: The UK should mandate the inclusion of feminist perspectives in the national literature curriculum.
paragraph: I don't believe that the UK should mandate the inclusion of any perspectives, including feminism,  socialism, or any other ism, in the national literature curriculum. 'Isms,' like feminism are political creatures, subject to redefinition by special interests. The term 'feminism' has been redefined during my lifetime. Once it meant the desire for women to have equal rights with men. Now it seems to have taken on negative connotations, fueled by gender ideology. While politics can be the subject of literature, one should not have to pass some kind of political litmus test to have your works studied for their literary qualities, and not their political ones.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: You have significant reservations about mandating diversity and inclusion training for all employees across the UK. While you may recognize that workplace diversity and inclusion are important goals, you believe that government-imposed requirements for such training represent excessive regulatory overreach into private business operations. You likely view this as an infringement on employers' autonomy to manage their own workplace policies and training programs. Your stance suggests you prefer market-driven solutions or voluntary initiatives rather than top-down mandates. You may also question the effectiveness of mandatory training, believing that forced compliance could breed resentment or superficial participation rather than genuine cultural change. Additionally, you might be concerned about the administrative burden and costs this would place on businesses, particularly smaller enterprises that may lack the resources to implement comprehensive training programs effectively.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: Politics has no place in the workplace, and diversity and inclusion training is a form of political action. Making it mandatory forces people to adopt opinions that they may not personally agree with. Individuals have the right to their own personal opinions, even if others find them unpleasant or offensive. It is a form of authoritarianism to mandate viewpoints. Personally, I am a feminist and am broadly tolerant of diverse gender identities, but I do not expect others to share my views, viewing efforts to force my views on others as childish behaviour, more appropriate for the schoolyard than the workplace. True tolerance includes the ability to accept that others may legitimately have views that differ from your own, and that they have the right to keep those views private, if they wish. You cannot mandate true tolerance, you can only mandate sycophancy.

proposition: The UK should legalise euthanasia.
paragraph: The decision to end one’s life should be a personal choice, where possible. Of course, for many, it’s not a decision at all—they live until life ends naturally. Yet, there are those who find existence too painful to endure, whether due to mental or physical illness. I’ve known people in such situations who did not wish to go on living, and I would never judge them for making that choice. However, the introduction of state-sanctioned euthanasia raises the concern that individuals might feel subtle or overt pressure to opt for death against their true desires. While I don’t know how this could be entirely prevented, I have known individuals who felt compelled to stay alive despite severe illness and agony. If euthanasia is legalised, I fear it might lead some to feel obligated to die for the convenience or interests of others, rather than their own.

proposition: The UK should legalise euthanasia.
paragraph: The decision to end your own life should be a personal one, when this is possible. Obviously, for a lot of people, this is a non-decision - you live until you are unable to continue your life. However, some people find life too difficult to carry on. I have known several people who suffered from mental and physical illnesses and did not necessarily want to live. I would never blame them for making their own decision to end their life. However, state involvement leads to the possibility that people will feel pressured to make decisions that go against their personal preferences. I have no idea how to prevent this, but I have known people who felt pressure to continue living, despite major illnesses and overwhelming pain. I am sure that if euthanasia is legalized, there will be pressure on people to die to suit other people's agendas, and not their own.

proposition: The UK should teach children about the LGBTQ+ community in primary school.
paragraph: I believe teaching primary school children about the LGBTQ+ community is unnecessary because it focuses on sexual preference, which isn’t age-appropriate for young kids. While I don’t oppose children learning about same-sex relationships or drag queens in passing, I don’t think schools should actively teach these topics. Children will naturally encounter such aspects of society as they grow up, either through their own experiences or discussions at home. Schools should prioritise foundational education, leaving more complex social topics to be explored organically or within the family. Introducing these subjects formally in a classroom setting feels forced and may confuse younger children who aren’t yet ready to understand them. It’s better to let kids develop naturally, learning about the world around them in their own time, rather than making LGBTQ+ education a compulsory part of the curriculum.

proposition: The UK should teach children about the LGBTQ+ community in primary school.
paragraph: I don't know what the current age is for children to learn sex education in school, but it seems more appropriate to do this early on in secondary school, and include LGBTQ+ within that. I question why children need to learn about sexual preference when it is not something they would naturally be interested in. Given that there are sensitivities within different communities about this, whether they are very traditional, religious or are not in favour of it for personal reasons, it would seem wise not to include this. It feels more appropriate to allow parents to discuss with their children at home if they feel it's appropriate or necessary.

proposition: The UK should legally recognize and protect all forms of transgender identity.
paragraph: You generally support the idea of legally recognizing and protecting transgender identities in the UK, though you maintain some reservations about the specifics of implementation. While you believe that transgender individuals deserve fundamental rights and protections from discrimination, you may have concerns about how "all forms" of transgender identity would be defined legally or worry about potential complexities in certain contexts like healthcare, sports, or single-sex spaces. You likely support core protections like employment rights, housing security, and healthcare access for transgender people, but prefer a measured approach that carefully considers various perspectives and practical implications. Your position reflects a desire for inclusive policies that protect vulnerable individuals while also addressing legitimate concerns about how such broad legal recognition might be implemented effectively and fairly across different areas of society.

proposition: The UK should legally recognize and protect all forms of transgender identity.
paragraph: Although I am strongly in favour of sex-based rights for women, and want to see separate spaces based on sex in certain contexts for example hospitals, prisons, rape crisis centres, I still believe that transgender people have rights too. By being recognised and protected in law (which I believe transgender identities already are in the UK), this does not have to have a negative impact on women who wish to uphold single sex spaces. It should be possible to find a solution whereby there are spaces for all identities. As a marginalised and somewhat persecuted group, I would not want transgender people to feel like they aren't being recognised for who they are as this can be devastating.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: Although I’m not deeply informed on the topic, it seems that because drone technology is now widely employed in global conflicts, the UK may need to maintain its use to avoid strategic disadvantages. If other nations are utilizing drones and we are not, we could be placed at risk in future military engagements. There may be valid moral or ethical objections to drone use, but I would need to research further to properly evaluate them. Much depends on how the drones are deployed—whether for surveillance, targeted strikes, or other purposes—but my limited familiarity with the technology makes it difficult to form a definitive judgment.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: I don't have much knowledge about this, but it would appear that as drone technology is so widely used currently in conflicts around the world, it will be necessary for the UK to continue to use them. Otherwise, we could find ourselves at a disadvantage in future conflicts, if our adversaries are using drones and we are not. Perhaps there are moral or ethical reasons not to use them, but I am unable to think of any without researching this further. It will very much depend on how they are used, for example reconnaissance, targeted strikes, etc. But as I am not very familiar with the technology it is difficult for me to judge.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: Love should always triumph over hate. Why can't people simply be happy for couples who find joy with each other, regardless of their genders? People should mind their own business and stop interfering with the choices of consenting adults. There are far bigger problems caused by hate than by same-sex marriage. Additionally, there is the important issue of equality and the need to eliminate discrimination by allowing same-sex couples the same rights as everyone else. It's hypocritical for people to resist interference in their own lives while feeling entitled to dictate how others live, even when it doesn't affect them at all.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph:
Love should always be better than hate. Why can't people be happy for other couples finding joy with each other, no matter their genders, People should mind there own business and stop interfering with the choices of consenting adults.
The are far bigger problems with hate than there are associated with same sex marriage.
There is also the equality issue and the lack of discrimination inherent in allowing same sex marriage. People are hypocrits, they don't want interference in their lives, but are quite happy to tell other people what to do with their lives when it doesn't affect them at all

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union because Brexit has fundamentally failed to deliver on its promises and has demonstrably worsened the country's position. Rather than achieving the supposed benefits that were promoted during the referendum campaign, Brexit has created significant economic, political, and social challenges that have left the UK worse off than before. The isolation from our European neighbors has proven counterproductive, highlighting that Britain benefits more from being aligned with the EU rather than operating as a disjointed, standalone entity. Rejoining would restore the UK's broader international perspective and collaborative approach to global challenges, which has been severely diminished since leaving. The evidence clearly shows that the UK's interests are better served through European integration rather than the current path of separation and isolation from our closest partners.

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph:
The decision for Brexit was a mis informed one, unchecked lies were told about the benefits, non of which have materialised. People with agendas targetted the marginalised population trying to convince them that hating their neighbours would solve their own problems. None of the benefits have happened, trade is more difficult and expensive, relations have bee ruined with people who should be our friends and neighbours. Diversity has decreased in this country. Crops are being picked because no one will take the jobs previously done by migrants.
Rejoining would start to heal some of this issues and give us a more global view

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming because it aligns with the urgent need to combat climate change while supporting sustainable agriculture. Carbon farming not only helps sequester CO2 but also improves soil health, biodiversity, and resilience against extreme weather, making it a practical solution for environmental and agricultural challenges. Financial incentives would encourage more farmers to adopt these practices, accelerating the transition to greener farming methods. While there may be concerns about costs and implementation, the long-term benefits for the environment, food security, and rural economies outweigh these challenges. However, robust monitoring and transparent policies are essential to ensure the incentives achieve their intended impact. This approach strikes a balance between proactive climate action and realistic support for farmers, making it a worthwhile investment in the UK’s sustainable future.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph:
I beleive Climate Change is a very real danger and must be tackled to secure the future of the biosphere.
Firstly, people are reluctant to change due to Climate change, stupidity, lazyness or short term views. Can't be trusted to do the right thing, put there selfish needs first. Time and time has shown that people need a motivation where it affects them - in the pocket. So funding for these sort of initiatives is the best way to convince people and corporations to go ahead with them. It is a shame that people can't look at the bigger picture.

proposition: The UK should ban internet use for under-14-year-olds.
paragraph: Banning internet use for under-14-year-olds could protect young people from a range of potential harms. Social media platforms, in particular, can negatively impact children's emotional well-being, exposing them to unrealistic standards, cyberbullying, and harmful content. At such a vulnerable age, children are still developing their sense of identity and self-esteem, and constant online comparisons can lead to anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. Additionally, excessive internet use can become a major distraction from schoolwork, hobbies, physical activity, and face-to-face social interaction, all of which are essential for healthy development. Restricting access during these formative years may encourage healthier habits and allow children to grow up without the pressures and dangers that come with unrestricted online exposure.

proposition: The UK should ban internet use for under-14-year-olds.
paragraph: I think not all of the internet should be banned for under-14-year-olds because a lot of it can be useful, especially for research and educational skills at school. Certain aspects like social media should be banned because they can be harmful for children's mental health, encouraging more isolation and mental health problems like body issues. I think instead of outright banning the internet children should be encouraged to learn about it at school, utilising it during lessons when looking at research. Time on the internet should definately be limited, especially at home, and parent-locks should be in place to make sure material is appropriate.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: I believe the UK would benefit from somewhat stronger legal protections for free speech, though I recognize this issue involves important nuances and competing considerations. While the current legal framework provides reasonable safeguards, there's room for improvement in protecting legitimate expression from potential overreach. I appreciate that free speech is fundamental to democratic discourse and individual liberty, but I also understand the need to balance this against other important values like preventing genuine harms and protecting vulnerable groups. The challenge lies in striking the right balance between expanding protections for legitimate speech while maintaining necessary restrictions on genuinely harmful content. Overall, I lean toward strengthening these protections, but with careful consideration of how such changes might be implemented to avoid unintended consequences.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: I understand concerns over the issue but in some way it is being blown out of proportion. Protecting free speech is important but it cannot be at the behest of hurting marginalised groups, we still need to have legal protections against hate speech. For example, whilst supporting free speech is important, it doesn't give people the right to be discriminatory and hateful to others. It also doesn't mean people are owed a platform or for anyone to listen to them speak. A lot of people complain about free speech online but it goes both ways, you can say what you want but you have to be prepared for people to say things back to you.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: "While I acknowledge the environmental concerns linked to meat consumption, I believe restricting dietary choices is unfair, particularly for those reliant on the industry for livelihoods. Ethical meat production and consumption are viable alternatives, and the UK should prioritize these over an outright ban. Limiting meat intake, rather than prohibiting it, is a more balanced approach. Additionally, not all plant-based protein sources are environmentally flawless—soy production, for instance, demands significant land and can be damaging."

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: Whilst I understand the environmental issues with consuming meat, I also don't think it's fair to limit people's choices of what they eat, especially when a lot of people depend on the industry for their source of income. Meat can be produced and consumed in more ethical ways so the UK should focus on that instead. I think limiting meat consumption as opposed to banning it out right it the best option. Not all vegan/vegetarian sources of protein or meat replacement are that good for the environment either, especially soy production that uses up a lot of land and can be harmful.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: I believe the UK government should take decisive action by mandating comprehensive sustainability initiatives across all local councils. Climate change and environmental degradation are urgent challenges that require coordinated, nationwide responses rather than leaving it to the discretion of individual councils, which creates an inconsistent patchwork of environmental action. A mandatory approach ensures that all communities, regardless of local political priorities or financial constraints, contribute meaningfully to the country's environmental goals. While I recognize that councils vary in their resources and specific local needs, a well-designed mandate could provide flexibility in implementation while establishing minimum standards for sustainability measures. This top-down approach would accelerate progress toward carbon neutrality, improve air quality, enhance biodiversity, and create more resilient communities. The urgency of environmental issues justifies this level of government intervention, as voluntary measures have proven insufficient to achieve the scale and speed of change required.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: To save our planet we all need to do our best to use sustainable actions. The world needs help to cut our pollution which is destroying seas, nature and our air. There is no reason why we should not use 'cleaner' fuels. Everyone should help clean up our mess for future generations. Although there would be an initial outlay to change things to more sustainable transport local councils could mandate that new  vehicles must be 'green' rather than renewing like for like. Recycling can actually make a profit for the council rather than costing more in taxes. It can also create jobs for the local area.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: We should prioritise the digital transformation of public services to keep pace with technological advancements. Public services must adopt the latest technology to improve user experience and efficiency. Outdated systems are more vulnerable to cyberattacks and technical issues. For example, the recent hacks of Marks & Spencer and the Co-op exposed serious vulnerabilities, resulting in financial losses and distress for customers whose personal data was compromised. If public services fail to modernise, they could face similar risks, threatening data security and public trust.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: We should prioritise digital transformation of public services because if we don't we would be lagging behind technology advances. Public services need to use the newest technology to make it more user friendly.  Digital technology that is not kept updated can be left open to hacking and problems. If the technology is out of date it is left open to hacking - as seen durning the recent hacks of Marks and Spencers and the coop. These hacks have cost the companies a lot of money and caused distress to their customers who' details have been compromised. The same would happen to public services.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not fully decriminalise prostitution due to the significant risks involved. One major concern is that prostitution can be controlled by criminal networks, leading to exploitation and violence. Decriminalisation might inadvertently empower these groups, making it harder to combat illegal activities. Additionally, vulnerable individuals, such as those facing financial hardship or coercion, could be manipulated into providing sexual services against their will. Without proper safeguards, decriminalisation may exacerbate these issues rather than protect sex workers. While some argue that legalisation could improve safety and regulation, the potential for abuse and criminal involvement makes me cautious. Instead, focusing on stricter enforcement against exploitation and better support for those at risk might be a more effective approach. The well-being of individuals must take precedence over any perceived benefits of full decriminalisation.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: Prostitution can be a very dangerous thing to do. Gangs can be in control of areas and can manipulate people to 'work' for them through threats. There can be drug use involved which would make control much easier for the gangs. People who work in prostitution can be in danger from their clients. Young people can be drawn into prostitution through grooming. To decimalise prostitution could mean that there is no protection for the people who are prostitutes.  There would have to be some sort of protection if this statement was implemented to protect the people It would take away a way in which police can help to legalise prostitution.

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: You believe the UK should not increase its military spending to strengthen its NATO role. Your perspective likely stems from concerns that higher defense expenditure would divert crucial resources from pressing domestic priorities such as healthcare, education, and social services that directly benefit citizens' daily lives. You may view the current level of military spending as already adequate for the UK's security needs and question whether additional investment would meaningfully enhance collective defense capabilities. There could be skepticism about the effectiveness of military solutions to contemporary security challenges, favoring diplomatic and multilateral approaches instead. You might also worry that increased military spending could contribute to regional arms races or escalate tensions rather than promote stability. Additionally, you may believe that other NATO members should shoulder more responsibility for collective defense rather than the UK taking on a larger financial burden during times of economic uncertainty and competing domestic demands.

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: I don't think that adding military will strengthen it's role in Nato. I don't think more military is a positive thing and could escalate things so it becomes a worse problem. Many more people will die if this did happen as we'd send more personal which inevitably would be killed during the battles . This is obviously a very negative reason why this would be gross misconduct to increase military spending. I think the money can be used in other scenarios a lot more such as healthcare, education and culture which is more important than military in my humble opinion

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I believe it is better to prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with existing Commonwealth nations, as this will help build a strong bond and a trusted circle that forms a solid core group. Once that foundation is secure, new alliances can be considered for integration into the Commonwealth. There is no need to rush into forming new partnerships; instead, focus should be placed on maintaining and nurturing the current network. Without proper attention, the Commonwealth could weaken or dissolve, but fostering a strong base ensures that any future additions will come from a position of strength and benefit both the Commonwealth and the prospective members.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I think it is better to prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with current nation as it will help build a bond an circle of trust to have a very strong core group and once that's established then you can think about adding new alliances into the Commonwealth after that's sorted. There is no rush to add new nations but the Commonwealth could die if it isn't properly maintained and looked after so eventually when new countries come in it will be from a position of power and more useful to the Commonwealth and the countries potentially joining in the near future.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: I believe the UK should reduce funding for its intelligence agencies because the money could be better allocated to other pressing public needs, such as healthcare, education, or infrastructure. These sectors often face chronic underfunding and directly impact citizens' quality of life, whereas the benefits of intelligence spending are less tangible and harder to measure. Additionally, the lack of transparency surrounding intelligence operations makes it difficult to assess whether the funds are being used effectively or ethically. Without proper oversight, there’s a risk of misuse or inefficiency, which undermines public trust. Redirecting resources to more accountable and visible areas would ensure greater value for taxpayers while still maintaining essential security functions. Transparency and accountability should be prioritised to justify any expenditure, especially in sectors as sensitive as intelligence.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: I think this could be a good thing that the United Kingdom should decrease its funding for intelligence agencies as the money can be spend better elsewhere as there is much more pressing issues than the intelligence agencies in the UK right now. I am also dubious about the funding that goes towards intelligence agencies as is due to their being a complete lack of transparency in the spending of the agencies due to the reclusive and secretive nature of those agencies such as MI5 and MI6 which I presume this also covers. I'd like this money to go to other more important services.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: In today's drone-infested world, banning military drone technology in the UK would be a strategic mistake. Drones offer several advantages over traditional manned operations: they are easier to control than human soldiers, reducing the risk to personnel while enhancing precision in complex missions. Their effectiveness in surveillance and targeted strikes has been consistently demonstrated, making them valuable assets in modern warfare. Additionally, drones are cost-effective, allowing for greater operational efficiency with fewer resources. Their ability to travel covertly provides a significant tactical advantage, enabling discreet monitoring and engagement without exposing forces to unnecessary danger. Given these considerations, maintaining and advancing drone capability is essential for national security in a rapidly evolving global landscape.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: The world as we know it utilising drones within a military zone each and every day, they are more effective than putting a human at risk, they are very easy to control and have a vast array of options to expand there usefulness. They are very cost effective and fairly cheap to procure for the military. They are more likely to be able to travel covertly in and out of zones that are militarised, equipped with certain tools to be virtually impossible to shoot down (via a long range attack). I appreciate that straight under a drone and shooting at it may mean that it is blown out of the sky.

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph: "The current design of social media platforms leaves too much room for toxic individuals to exploit. A glaring example is the alleged influencer Andrew Tate; while he and his brother haven’t been convicted of the offenses linked to them, it’s shocking that social media has enabled such a harmful figure to manipulate young, vulnerable minds for so long. The governing bodies often penalize innocent users for minor infractions they deem inappropriate, while larger, more damaging entities operate unchecked in the shadows."

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph: The current set up of the social media platforms is open in to far too much interpretation for the toxic people in our society. An a huge example of this is the alleged influencer Andrew Tate, whilst he may not as yet been convicted of any of the offences that are attributed to him and his brother, the fact that social media as allowed this vile specimen of a person who corrupt the minds of the young and vulnerable for so long is beyond belief. The social media governing bodies seem to stop mainly innocent people from utilising their accounts over small infractions that they deem are unfit, when the bigger entities are allowed to prowl and skulk in the shadows.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: I believe the UK should fully decriminalise prostitution because criminalisation causes far more harm than good. The current legal framework pushes sex work into dangerous, underground markets where workers face violence, exploitation, and have no recourse to workplace protections or police assistance. Full decriminalisation would allow sex workers to operate safely, form cooperatives, advertise their services, and access the same labour rights as other workers. This approach treats sex work as legitimate labour rather than criminal activity, reducing stigma while improving working conditions. Evidence from places like New Zealand shows that decriminalisation enhances worker safety without increasing trafficking or other negative social outcomes. Adults should have autonomy over their own bodies and the right to engage in consensual commercial transactions. Criminalisation perpetuates harm while decriminalisation prioritises the safety, dignity, and rights of sex workers themselves.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: The profession of soliciting, prostitution has been in existence for thousands of years, like many other professionals in there field men and woman are selling their bodies to either put food on the table or make ends meet. Like all professions there are low end and high people. I think if we just accept that this type of job ahs  place in society, currently its classed as the seedy side, we can then look at the benefits that everyone can reap from an amalgamation of legalising the  profession. The government gets its crust, pimps are thrown to the wolves as they would need to be registered and would not be legally allowed to sell there products (prostitutes for gain). The health benefits would out way any negativity form the do gooders who would say its a moral cess pit we are talking about. Each and every legal person would be at the age required and get regular health checks whilst still earning a proper agreed wage.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
paragraph: I do not believe the UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church. There appears to be no compelling reason to take such a drastic step, as the current arrangement does not pose any evident harm or conflict with the nation’s governance. Moreover, making such a move would likely cause significant distress to a large number of people, including practicing Catholics who value the Church's presence and role in British society. The disruption would far outweigh any potential benefits, especially given that religion, for many, plays an important cultural and personal role in their lives. Removing formal ties without a clear justification risks alienating a segment of the population and igniting unnecessary tension. Without a strong, practical motivation, it seems wiser to maintain the existing relationship and focus on fostering mutual respect and coexistence among all religious groups within the UK.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
paragraph: I guess the argument for doing so might be that the Catholic Church has outdated values and systems that somewhat challenges the modern UK's values? For example their views on gay marriage and abortions etc, which do cause upset for many people. However, despite this, I think severing all ties is an unnecessarily drastic action which we currently have no strong reason to do so, as the church is not actively threatening anyone's lives. Severing all ties in this way would just cause major upset and disruption for the many many people in the UK who associate themselves with and practice catholicism.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: While I acknowledge that China's political framework differs fundamentally from democratic principles, based on my understanding of the situation, I believe the UK issuing a formal condemnation would be diplomatically dangerous. When nations begin officially denouncing other sovereign states' governance models, this inevitably generates international instability and intensifies current geopolitical friction. Such actions might trigger armed conflicts, military interventions, nuclear confrontations, cyberwarfare campaigns, or widespread social and political upheaval, potentially endangering countless lives across the world. It would be more prudent to maintain diplomatic discretion while advancing democratic ideals through alternative mechanisms and working to strengthen bilateral relations instead of causing additional deterioration.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: While I do agree that Chin'a political system is incompatible with democratic values, at least to the extent of my own limited knowledge on the subject, I think that the UK formally condemning this system is politically risky. If we start officially criticising other countries, this will only cause global unrest and escalate existing tensions.
