We should be decriminalising all drugs anyways Portugal has the right idea

proposition: The UK should implement stricter animal rights laws.
paragraph: I strongly support implementing stricter animal rights laws in the UK because animals are sentient beings who deserve fundamental protections from harm and exploitation. Just as humans can experience pain and suffering, animals possess the same capacity for emotional and physical distress, making it equally immoral to inflict suffering upon them. Current laws fail to adequately protect animals from being killed for human consumption or entertainment, which violates their basic right to life and welfare. Factory farming represents a particularly egregious example of systematic cruelty that must be abolished entirely. These industrial operations subject countless animals to horrific conditions throughout their lives, treating sentient creatures as mere commodities rather than beings capable of suffering. Stricter legislation would acknowledge animals' inherent worth and establish meaningful protections that reflect our moral obligation to prevent unnecessary harm to all sentient life.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter animal rights laws.
paragraph: As a vegan myself i care deeply about animal rights issues and look forward to the day when all animals are granted some form of basic rights. As well as this there are extra reasons one could support abolishing factory farming by implementing stricter animal rights laws, for example factory farming causes a significant amount of increased greenhouse gas emissons so abolishing factory farming and moving the country over to a more plant based lifestyle would contribute to the goal of reaching net zero by whenever the current goal is. Finally being kind to animals is a good show of ones moral character and as a nation i think we can all do better to treat all animals with respect.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: I believe that encouraging marriage through financial incentives can have some positive effects, particularly in promoting long-term stability for families and creating a supportive environment for raising children. Marriage can provide a framework that contributes to economic and emotional stability, and modest incentives might help couples who are already considering marriage take that step. However, I also recognize that relationships and families come in many forms, and government support should not unfairly prioritize married couples over others. While financial incentives might help in some cases, they should be part of a broader policy that respects different lifestyles and ensures fairness for all. Overall, I'm slightly supportive of the idea, provided it is implemented in a balanced and inclusive way.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: Personally i think this policy is just a band aid for the isssue of replacement rates when in reality we need massivie societal change including things like 15 minute citys improved public transport and just massive investment in general to all public services. I don't see why only married couples should get financial incentives when in reality everyone who isn't wealthy needs them now anyway we need a much more broad approach with massive amounts of investment by taxing the ever loving god out of the wealthy tax the rich tac the rich tax the rich tax the rich tax THE RICH

proposition: The UK should commit to a policy of never using nuclear bombs under any circumstances.
paragraph: The UK should adopt an unwavering commitment to never using nuclear weapons, as their catastrophic humanitarian and environmental consequences far outweigh any perceived strategic benefits. The indiscriminate destruction caused by nuclear bombs is morally indefensible, and their use would violate fundamental principles of international law and human rights. By renouncing these weapons entirely, the UK would set a powerful ethical example, reinforcing global disarmament efforts and fostering trust among nations. A no-first-use policy alone is insufficient; a complete rejection of nuclear weapons under any circumstances is necessary to align with a future-oriented vision of peace and security. This stance would also free up resources currently spent on maintaining nuclear arsenals, allowing for investment in diplomacy, climate action, and social welfare. The UK’s leadership in this area could inspire other nuclear-armed states to follow suit, accelerating progress toward a safer, more just world.

proposition: The UK should commit to a policy of never using nuclear bombs under any circumstances.
paragraph: Well in my opinion, if this was to be used by the UK, especially in Russia, then the repercussions could be catastrophic, destroying millions of lives because 2 people cant stop arguing like children, whole countries would be wiped out, destroyed and baron land, it could potentially mean the end for humankind, depending on who wanted to retaliate and easily wipe out the UK as well, I don't understand how any people could want to cause such mass devastation, especially when they live on this planet as well, why don't they just bomb themselves if they dont want to be here

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: I disagree with banning military drone technology because drones eliminate the risk of pilot casualties when aircraft are shot down, as there are no human operators aboard. Additionally, drones possess superior maneuverability and precision capabilities, allowing them to hover, turn rapidly, and deploy weaponry with greater accuracy than traditional aircraft. This technology significantly benefits military forces by preventing human casualties on their side, and since any rational decision-maker would avoid unnecessarily exposing personnel to danger when alternatives exist, drones represent a more humane approach to military operations for the sake of protecting human life.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: Well if there are no humans flying planes with bombs or other kinds of weapons, then if it was just a drone that got shot down, no humans would be killed or injured. And also as drones are really accurate and can hover and turn different ways quicker, that they might be more accurate when it comes to unleashing weaponry. It would benefit the people who are using it because then there are no casualties, and nobody in their right mind would send people to danger when they didn't have to, for the sake of humanity! And thats why i disagree

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph: Introducing laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens could negatively impact how people communicate and stay connected. Social media is an essential means of maintaining relationships, especially for those who live far from family and friends or have limited mobility. Restricting access could lead to isolation and reduce opportunities for meaningful social interaction. Additionally, many individuals rely on social media as a source of income. From influencers and content creators to small business owners and freelance professionals, these platforms offer valuable tools for marketing, networking, and generating revenue. Placing legal restrictions on their daily use could harm these livelihoods and stifle creativity and entrepreneurship. Rather than enforcing blanket limits, a more effective approach would be to promote digital literacy and encourage responsible use of social media. This would help people manage their time online without compromising communication or economic opportunity.

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph: If the UK introduced laws like this, people would struggle a lot, in my opinion, this would include messaging apps so people wouldn't be able to keep in contact, which would be a bad idea if they had loved ones that were ill, or needed help, which could then have bad consequences. I see a lot of personal selling pages on social media sites that are probably these peoples only source of income, so if they couldn't post what they are selling or couldn't receive messages then they would ultimately lose out on money. Also, i think its a stupid idea

proposition: The UK should phase out the use of nuclear energy.
paragraph: Nuclear energy plays a crucial role in the UK’s energy security and decarbonization efforts, providing a reliable, low-carbon alternative to fossil fuels. Phasing it out would be a mistake, as renewable sources alone cannot yet meet the country’s energy demands without risking blackouts or increased reliance on imported gas. Nuclear power offers baseload electricity, complementing intermittent renewables like wind and solar, and abandoning it would undermine climate goals. While concerns about waste and costs are valid, modern reactor designs and long-term waste management solutions are addressing these issues. The UK should focus on advancing nuclear technology, including small modular reactors, rather than abandoning a proven clean energy source. A phase-out would set back energy independence and emissions targets, leaving the nation vulnerable to price volatility and supply shortages.

proposition: The UK should phase out the use of nuclear energy.
paragraph:
Nuclear energy is a low carbon energy sources, especially when compared to gas and coal. The UK, and the rest of the world need to significantly reduce their carbon emissions, and as energy production is such a large contributor to emissions, it is essential that the UK has a supply of energy that does not contribute to global carbon emissions. Nuclear energy can be a stable and low carbon energy solution for the future, by actually investing more in nuclear energy in the next decade, the UK will be able to reduce it's carbon emissions to meet Net Zero targets and to ensure that future generations have a reliable low carbon energy source'
Wind and solar power have not proven powerful or sufficient enough to provide enough power to meet enough of the UK's energy needs.
The UK must become energy secure and reduce it's reliance on foreign energy, as recent events in the Ukraine and Russia have shown, when other countries are able to restrict access to energy and to change prices, this can lead to global tensions. Nuclear energy is vital in ensuring the UK has it's own reliable and low cost supply of energy.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph: I oppose mandatory patriotism education in UK schools for several compelling reasons. Firstly, our educational system is already under immense strain from funding cuts, staff recruitment challenges, and complex social issues - adding another curricular requirement would only burden teachers further. Additionally, patriotism is a subjective concept that varies significantly across different communities and cultural groups, potentially creating classroom conflicts and misunderstandings rather than unity. Most importantly, there are far more pressing educational priorities that deserve our attention and resources. Teaching children environmental stewardship, empathy, and kindness toward others would better serve both students and society. These values are universal and constructive, whereas mandatory patriotism risks becoming divisive and counterproductive. Schools should focus on equipping young people with critical thinking skills and moral foundations rather than prescribed nationalist sentiments.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph:
In the UK, schools are already overstretched, due to years of underfunding and lack of investment, many schools do not have sufficient budgets for staff and educational equipment, also schools are increasingly having to help children from disadvantaged backgrounds and also children with special educational needs, teaching staff are under a lot of pressure to meet Government standards and to pass inspections, and also the stress of SATs exams. All these factors mean that to add a mandatory and compulsory patriotism education would cause teaching staff more stress and put more pressure on schools that are already struggling.
There are many different groups of people in British society, different religions and cultures and customs, for them patriotism may have a different meaning or no meaning at all, who is to decide the nature of the patriotism education and will all sections of society be consulted. It may cause more issues in implementing than is worth the value and will likely cause the Government and Department of Education a lot of trouble.
Patriotism is less important to me than issues such as caring for nature and our planet, and being kind others, surely these values should be taught.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph: The UK already possesses a nuclear arsenal that has proven sufficient for the past four decades to act as a deterrent and to contribute to global stability. The UK's decision not to expand this arsenal has set a positive example for other nations and has played a role in maintaining peace. Increasing the number of nuclear weapons might suggest a shift in the UK's intentions, potentially leading hostile nations to perceive the UK as preparing for conflict. This perception could prompt them to expand their own arsenals, thereby escalating global tensions. Furthermore, the funding required for expanding the UK's nuclear capabilities could instead be directed toward addressing domestic social inequality and tackling global poverty.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph:
The UK already has an arsenal of nuclear weapons and this has been sufficient enough for the past forty or so years to act as a nuclear deterrent and to ensure global stability, the fact that the UK has not already increased their arsenal has set a good example for other nations and has helped keep the world stable. To me increasing nuclear weapons arsenals indicates a change in the motivation for having weapons, it could be seen by other nations hostile to the UK that the UK is considering an attack or potential war, and this could lead to other nations feeling that they too must increase their arsenals in order to protect themselves, creating a higher level of tensions in the world.
Also the money that would be spent in investing in weapons could be used to reduce issues such as social inequality in the UK, and also global poverties.

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph: You have significant reservations about introducing laws that limit citizens' daily social media use, though you're not entirely opposed to the concept. While you likely recognize that excessive social media consumption can have negative effects on mental health, productivity, and social cohesion, you're concerned about the implications of government intervention in personal digital choices. Such legislation could set a troubling precedent for state control over individual freedom and privacy. You probably believe that digital literacy education, platform self-regulation, and personal responsibility are preferable approaches to addressing social media-related problems. However, you're not completely dismissive of the idea, perhaps acknowledging that in extreme circumstances or with very specific safeguards, some form of regulation might be warranted. Your position reflects a tension between recognizing genuine social media harms and valuing personal autonomy over government paternalism.

proposition: The UK should introduce laws that limit the daily social media use of UK citizens.
paragraph:
I think this would be very controlling. people should be able to use free will and have some self control over things that maybe not great to sue long term rather than it being state controlled.
i think some people would require more time than others for the purposes of keeping in touch with distant relatives or using social media to read news articles for work or study.
I don't think there is a valid reason for this and not justified to have this level of control. most people who are at work or school during the day are already not on social media then.

proposition: The UK should loosen regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals.
paragraph: On the whole, I think yes, the regulations could be loosened. I believe that as long as there are agreed-upon standards that other countries must meet to import into the UK, then that should be acceptable. Loosening restrictions may lead to better access to healthcare supplies, as well as more competitive costs and wider choices. This could be especially helpful in times when supplies are low and people lack access to essential medication. It would also expand the market to include other types of medication not currently available here, potentially improving longevity for those with chronic or life-threatening illnesses.

proposition: The UK should loosen regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals.
paragraph:
on the whole i think yes the regulations could be loosened. i think as long as there is some agreements on standards that other countries must meet to import into the uk then that should be fine.
loosening restrictions may mean better options to healthcare supplies and better cost and choice. this can only help in times where supplies are low and people haven't had access to much needed medication. 
It would also open up the market to other types of medication that is not currently available here which may help longevity for people with long term or life threatening illneses.

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph: Abortion should remain legal in the UK because it upholds the fundamental right to choice, allowing individuals to make deeply personal decisions about their bodies and futures. Banning abortion would endanger health, forcing people to seek unsafe alternatives or carry unwanted pregnancies, which can have severe physical and mental consequences. Additionally, many other countries with progressive policies demonstrate that legal abortion supports gender equality and public health, while restrictive laws often lead to higher maternal mortality rates. The UK should continue to prioritize access to safe and legal abortion, aligning with modern values of autonomy, healthcare, and human rights, rather than regressing toward harmful and outdated restrictions. Protecting this right ensures dignity, safety, and fairness for all.

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph:
No they should not it should not be down to the state to control access to healthcare for women.
Women find themselves pregnant for many reasons and may choose not to keep the baby. they should have this choice.
They may have health or financial reasons for not having a baby or not become pregnant through choice but it is there life that will be impacted the most.  making it illegal would lead to move back street abortions and risk womens lives with dangerous unregulated  procedures.
we have seen this happen in other countries where lives have been lost and people with very valid reasons are denied abortions at the expense of womens suffering. it is also hard to control and would impact mothers who have misccarriages.

proposition: The UK should raise taxes for oil companies.
paragraph: Raising taxes for oil companies in the UK would be a positive step, as it would generate additional revenue that could be invested in public services or environmental initiatives. Higher taxes on these companies could also help level the playing field for alternative energy sources, encouraging the development and adoption of cleaner, more sustainable fuels. By making oil less economically attractive, the government could accelerate the transition to renewable energy, reducing reliance on fossil fuels and mitigating climate change. This approach aligns with broader environmental goals and promotes long-term energy security. Additionally, the extra tax revenue could fund green technologies and infrastructure, further supporting the shift toward a low-carbon economy. Overall, raising taxes on oil companies is a practical and forward-thinking policy that benefits both the environment and the economy.

proposition: The UK should raise taxes for oil companies.
paragraph: If the taxes were raised for oil companies they would generate revenue which would help the government.  This is a good thing. Also as the taxes were raised people would look for alternate fuel sources this could be renewable fuels such as wind, hydro electric power and solar power. As the fees would increase people should then look at alternate fuel sources this could be having solar panels fitted or photo voltaic cells. they could have a wind turbine fitted or something like that. It would help the environment and hopefully be cheaper than oil. this is a good thing fr the environment.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: I have a generally positive view of mandatory diversity and inclusion training for employees in the UK, though with some reservations. While I believe such training can play a valuable role in creating more inclusive workplaces and raising awareness about unconscious bias and discrimination, I'm not entirely convinced that a blanket mandate is the perfect solution. There's merit in ensuring all employees receive basic education about workplace diversity and respectful behavior, particularly given the UK's increasingly diverse workforce. However, I have concerns about the effectiveness of mandatory training programs, which can sometimes feel perfunctory or create resentment rather than genuine understanding. A more nuanced approach might work better—perhaps requiring training in certain sectors or for management roles, while allowing flexibility in implementation methods to ensure the programs are meaningful and impactful rather than mere compliance exercises.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: The UK does do a lot of training in diversity and inclusion training. I do think that a workforce should be diverse, It adds to the experiences staff have and gives different prospectives. In the end does it matter what colour or gender a person is as far as working is concerned. It should not make a difference. I do understand that people need to be educated, but having to repeat the training every year is a waste of time. Some people need to be reminded about basic manners and to treat all people with respect and being kind to all people.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: It is the responsibility of each individual to be environmentally conscious and aware. Councils should be informed about and implement environmentally friendly schemes and initiatives. They should take the lead by providing recycling centres and offering information on sustainable transport options, as well as any available incentives such as discounts for solar panels or heat pumps. Councils should collaborate with existing environmental programs to support the public in adopting greener lifestyles. They should also focus on educating residents on how to protect the environment, as increased awareness can lead to positive changes in people's behaviour.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: It is down to all of us on an individual level to be environmentally conscious and be aware. The councils should be aware pf environmentally friendly schemes and environmentally friendly initiatives. The council should lead the way, so have recycling centres, and some information about environmentally friendly transport schemes and any incentives available such as a reduction in fee for solar panels or heat pumps? They should partner with other schemes to help the public be more environmentally friendly. Thry should also educate the public as to how to save the environment and make people aware, if people are aware they can change there behaviour

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza, as their actions amount to genocide and the international community has largely remained passive. Israel is demonstrating unchecked aggression and a dangerous sense of impunity, believing it can act without facing consequences. By continuing political and military support, including supplying weapons, the UK risks complicity in these human rights violations. It's imperative that the UK take a principled stance by distancing itself from such oppressive behavior. Economic sanctions would signal that there are real implications for pursuing violent, expansionist policies and show that the UK stands firmly against genocide and for international law and justice.

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: Israel has done whatever they want for a long time now, with absolutely no repercussions from anyone, which is really surprising. No one seems to want to be able to stand up to them and tell them that what they are doing is wrong, which it 100% is. They are killing thousands of innocent people, committing genocide against the Palestinians, and someone needs to do something. Netanyahu is a war criminal, and I think at this point, the only thing he would respond to is sanctions like this. They are being supplied weapons by so many countries who should not be doing this. If enough countries stand up and do the right thing, then maybe this can end.

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: "I believe current global issues demand more attention than this topic. While unofficial platforms for downloading media have always existed, the internet’s vastness makes complete eradication of piracy unrealistic. Some might argue it provides access to those who couldn’t afford such content otherwise. Restricting media purchases to just a few platforms feels overly controlling, almost authoritarian. Ultimately, I find other matters far more pressing at this moment."

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: In my opinion, there are so many more important things in the world happening right now, that this is not something we should be focusing on. There have always been websites and systems and ways to view media and download them that are not strictly legal. The Internet is a massive place, and I think it is impossible to fully outlaw this kind of piracy. Some could argue that it allows people who could not otherwise consume this media, to be able to access new information. Trying to limit where you can buy songs and films and media to 1 or two places seems very like a dictatorship. Overall, in the grand scheme of things, I think there are much more important issues right now.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: I have significant reservations about mandating ESG policies for all publicly traded companies in the UK. While I recognize the importance of environmental responsibility, social considerations, and good governance, I'm concerned that a blanket mandate could impose excessive regulatory burden on businesses and stifle innovation. Market-driven adoption of ESG principles may be more effective than top-down government requirements, allowing companies to tailor their approaches to their specific circumstances and stakeholder needs. There's also the risk that mandatory ESG frameworks could become bureaucratic box-ticking exercises rather than meaningful change drivers. Some companies may already be implementing strong ESG practices voluntarily, and forcing standardized requirements could actually diminish their effectiveness. I'd prefer to see incentive-based approaches or sector-specific guidelines rather than universal mandates, which could better balance the legitimate goals of ESG with business flexibility and economic competitiveness.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: I think a lot of the time, the burden of climate change has been put on the wrong people. This includes individuals and smaller businesses. This will be very costly and often harmful to the business model if small businesses are mandated to do this. If we’re talking about really large, publicly traded companies, then sure, in some aspects, I think these policy should be mandated. It would help public opinion, probably the environment, and in a lot of ways the overall value of the company. Stakeholders would be more willing to put money in a company that has a positive public image. This transparency would also be useful for potential employees.

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph: I believe that the UK should actively seek to rejoin the European Union because the benefits of EU membership far outweigh the drawbacks. Membership provides economic stability, frictionless trade, and access to a vast single market, which supports jobs, investment, and growth. Being part of the EU also strengthens the UK's voice on the global stage through shared diplomacy and collaborative policy-making. In areas like climate change, security, science, and technological innovation, the UK stands to gain significantly by working closely with European partners. Furthermore, freedom of movement enriches cultural exchange and offers greater opportunities for UK citizens to live, work, and study across Europe. While Brexit was intended to restore sovereignty, in practice it has created barriers and complications that hinder the UK’s progress. Rejoining the EU would help restore international credibility and foster closer ties with our closest neighbors.

proposition: The UK should seek to rejoin the European Union.
paragraph: The UK should rejoin as the benefits of leaving were exaggerated and a number of years on these have just not been realised. In fact the UK economy is smaller as a result of leaving the EU.  In modern times, the UK cannot be inward looking but needs to form strong bonds with other nations, to be able to compete for business with larger countries in the world, such as the US, India and China.  Joining the EU again would also strengthen UK security as it would be more closely integrated with EU countries and this would help against current rogue states.  Being part of the EU would also mean the UK is part of common standards for consumer goods, which would benefit consumers.  The UK would be joining a large consensus on best practice in this area, rather than make decisions on its own.

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph: I strongly support abolishing private schools and integrating them into the state education system because education should be a universal right, not a privilege determined by wealth. The current two-tier system perpetuates inequality by allowing those who can afford private fees to access superior educational resources while others are left behind. Every child deserves access to the highest quality education, regardless of their family's financial circumstances, as education is fundamental to individual socio-economic mobility and life prospects. Beyond personal fairness, this reform would benefit the entire nation economically. A comprehensive state system utilizing the resources and expertise currently locked away in private institutions would create a genuinely world-class education for all students. This would produce a more skilled, knowledgeable workforce essential for the UK's competitiveness in an increasingly complex global economy, ultimately strengthening our society and prosperity.

proposition: The UK should abolish private schools and integrate them into the state education system.
paragraph: The UK should abolish private schools and amalgamate best practice from such schools into the state education system.  A two tier education system based on the ability to pay is unfair and is letting young people down.  The UK government should look to establish a world class state education system that will help young people achieve their dreams and aspirations.  This will also produce workers of the future, which in turn will enable the UK to have a thriving economy going forwards.  Accepting the existence of private schools is a tacit acceptance that state schools are inferior and that only those people that can afford to pay can expect the best quality of education.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: The UK’s current financial constraints demand prudent spending on proven growth-driven initiatives, not speculative "green" schemes with uncertain returns—both in carbon impact and cost-effectiveness. The government must resist greenwashing groupthink and rigorously assess whether such programs deliver tangible benefits. For farming, funding should prioritize yield increases and food security to ensure UK self-sufficiency. Supporting farmers directly, including reversing inheritance taxes on farms, is a wiser investment than diverting resources to unproven carbon farming projects.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: UK Government finances are currently tight.  Therefore, the government should prioritise spending on firm schemes that are proven to deliver growth, rather than unproven, fashionable, 'green' schemes that are speculative in terms of what benefits they deliver.  That is whether they have an impact on carbon emissions and whether the amount spent justifies any benefit.  The government should try to avoid greenwashing groupthink and critically analyse whether schemes are delivering benefit.  In terms of farming, it is far better to spend money on increasing yields and securing food so that the UK is self sustaining.  It is far better to spend on looking after farmers and reversing the farm inheritance tax, rather than spend on carbon farming schemes.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: I believe that decreasing funding for intelligence agencies would compromise national security, as key political and military figures would be unable to properly decide on defence strategies without the vital information these agencies provide. I also believe that most citizens would feel very insecure living in a country where intelligence agencies lack the funding to carry out their duties, which include providing valuable information for the nation. Without this support, we would all be vulnerable to the harmful intentions of other nations, as we would be unable to anticipate potential threats, leaving us exposed to acts of terrorism.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: I believe that decreasing the funding for intelligence agencies would compromise the nation security, as key political and militar people won't be able to properly decide on defence strategies without the vital information coming from such agencies. I also believe that most people would feel very insecure living in a country where intelligence agencies have no funding for carried out their duty which is providing valuable information for the country. By doing this, we will all be at the mercy of other nations bad intentions, as we won't be able to anticipate any potential danger leaving us expose to terror crimes

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: I have serious concerns about privatising the UK's prison system. The primary purpose of imprisonment should be rehabilitation and public safety, not profit generation. When private companies operate prisons, their financial incentives often conflict with these goals, as they may prioritise cost-cutting measures that compromise prisoner welfare, staff training, and rehabilitation programmes. The justice system is a fundamental responsibility of the state, and outsourcing it to profit-driven entities undermines democratic accountability and transparency. Evidence from countries with privatised prisons suggests higher recidivism rates and poorer conditions. Additionally, private prison companies may lobby for harsher sentencing policies to maintain occupancy rates, creating perverse incentives that distort justice. While the current public system has flaws, privatisation would likely exacerbate rather than solve these problems while introducing new ethical concerns about commercialising punishment.

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: I would be opposing to the idea of a prison system being run by private companies, because I would fear for the inmantes welfare, who might be subjected to depravation of reabilitation programmes to favour profit. I am also unsure how well a private company can be monitored and scrutanised as opposed to a public one, so I would be very weary of any kind of information being disclosed if the system becomes private. I feel that private company's focuses are not in lines with the welfare of the inmantes, making it quite contraversial and possibly dangerous for the inmates themselves..

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: The meat industry is inherently cruel, subjecting animals to inhumane conditions and suffering on a massive scale. Beyond the ethical concerns, it is also a major contributor to environmental degradation, producing significant amounts of carbon emissions that accelerate climate change. Banning meat consumption in the UK would address both these issues, promoting a more compassionate and sustainable food system. Transitioning to plant-based diets would reduce animal suffering while significantly lowering the country’s carbon footprint. Such a move aligns with global efforts to combat climate change and reflects a growing recognition of the need for ethical consumption. While challenges exist in implementation, the long-term benefits—for animals, the environment, and public health—make it a necessary and progressive step forward. The UK has an opportunity to lead by example, fostering a society that prioritizes both planetary and moral responsibility.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: The meat industry is probably one of the ugliest and inhumane in the world. Animals suffers incredible life-long pain kept in unbelievably terribly situations and suffer the consequences of abuse and neglet. The meat generated is also very unhealthy and not good for the human body, full of toxines and addictive and colorant to make it more appealing to consumers. The meat industry is also extremely bad for the environment, because of the huge amount of gasses produced by the animals, so the environment also suffers the consequence of this terrible industry. So the UK should fefinetly ban the consumption of meat for veryone's sake.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: I believe the UK should, in theory, implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors, as there are valid concerns about the potential impact of such content on young minds. However, I also think the final decision should ultimately rest with parents, who are best positioned to judge what is appropriate for their children based on individual maturity levels and values. While regulations can provide a helpful framework, they shouldn’t replace parental discretion, as families have different perspectives on what constitutes acceptable content. A balanced approach would involve setting baseline restrictions while empowering parents to make informed choices for their kids. This way, the responsibility is shared between policymakers and families, ensuring both protection and flexibility.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: I don't think, in general terms, that children should be playing violent video games but I fail to see how this could truly be regulated or restricted. Many games these days are purchased via online downloads which are very easy for online-literate children to get around. Also, the term 'violent' can mean different things to different people; how would the UK government choose to interperate this word? I think ultimately that which video games children are allowed to play should be left up to their parents to decide, though I would not disagree that many parents could do a much better job of regulating this themselves.

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph: While I understand the appeal of reinstating capital punishment when confronted with horrific crimes reported in the media, and acknowledge that certain individuals may truly be irredeemable, I believe that reintroducing the death penalty would fundamentally compromise our moral standing as a society. By sanctioning state-sponsored execution, we would essentially become accessories to the very acts of violence we condemn, requiring someone to carry out killings in our name and thereby transforming us into the gravest form of hypocrites. Given that we frequently condemn nations that continue to practice capital punishment, adopting such measures would strip away any moral authority we possess and reduce us to their level.

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph: I can certainly understand the desire to reintroduce the death penalty, given some of the terrible, heinous crimes that you see in the news. Some people, I believe, are indeed beyond redemption. Never the less, I feel that if the UK were to reintroduce the death penalty, that that would ultimately make all of us as citizens, complicit in the same types of crimes that we otherwise despise. As a state we would be asking someone to perfom an execution on our behalves; surely that would make us the worst kind of hypocrites. Our society often criticises others for whom the death penalty remains; with this we would be no better than them.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: I believe the UK should move toward fully decriminalising prostitution, though I acknowledge that the issue is complex and requires careful consideration. Decriminalisation could lead to better safety, health, and legal protections for sex workers, reducing the stigma they face and allowing them to work in more secure environments. It could also enable better access to support services and reduce the exploitation that can thrive under current legal grey areas. However, I understand concerns about potential unintended consequences, such as the need to ensure that decriminalisation doesn't lead to increased trafficking or exploitation. Therefore, while I support decriminalisation in principle, I believe it should be implemented alongside strong regulatory frameworks and social support systems to protect vulnerable individuals. This balanced approach would help uphold the rights of sex workers while addressing broader social and legal concerns.

proposition: The UK should fully decriminalise prostitution.
paragraph: I don't agree with the demonisation of prostitutes. Whilst I know not every prostitute is female, the majority are and traditionally always have been. Why is the criticism always reserved for these women who are clearly in desperate need, or have otherwise been trafficked or forced into this line of 'work'? Why are these women seen and treated as criminals, whilst the piece of shit men who, for want of a better term, 'use their services' receive no such treatment. I am unsure as to what the alternative to criminalising prostitution is, but surely it would be to help these women out of this situation.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation because it imposes unnecessary regulatory burdens on businesses and distorts the free market. These laws often lead to excessive bureaucracy and compliance costs, stifling economic growth and innovation. Employers are best positioned to determine fair compensation based on merit, performance, and market conditions, not government mandates. Furthermore, such legislation can create perverse incentives, discouraging companies from hiring or promoting women due to fear of legal repercussions, even if unintended. True equality should be achieved through voluntary practices, cultural shifts, and individual negotiation, not heavy-handed state intervention. By removing these regulations, businesses would have greater flexibility to reward employees based on their contributions, fostering a more dynamic and competitive workforce. Ultimately, trust in the market and individual autonomy will lead to fairer outcomes than rigid, one-size-fits-all legislation.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: Research and statistics clearly show that gender pay gaps persist in all areas of the economy and are very pronounced in some. This is regardless of educational background, competency, productivity or other factors. It is clear that women should be paid the same as men and that this will not happen without legal protection and recourse through a system that deals with complaints and applies redress. I can really see no argument against this that isn't itself discriminatory, or any industrial sector where it wouldn't apply. Abolishing legal protections would send a message that employers are free to discriminate against their employees.

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: I contend that government services function most effectively when managed by civil servants who emphasize service quality and public benefit rather than profit maximization. In prison contexts, this ensures that crucial rehabilitation programs and safety measures for both inmates and the general population are not compromised to reduce costs and boost financial returns. This might involve, for instance, altering guard schedules to reduce expenses or limiting prisoner access to recreation periods, educational opportunities, or learning resources. However, certain basic operational aspects could be contracted to private companies where such arrangements wouldn't jeopardize the overall provision of essential public services during potential service disruptions.

proposition: The UK should privatise its prison system.
paragraph: I believe that public services are best run by public servants who prioritise the effectiveness of services against notions of public value rather than wider concerns of making profits. In this context it means that vital elements of work to deliver rehabilitation of prisoners and to secure the safety of the public and others who are incarcerated are not sacrificed to save money to increase profits. This could be, for example, changing shift patterns of prison officers to cut corners or the number of times a day prisoners have access to exercise or educational programmes or facilities. Some straightforward elements of delivery could, however, be undertaken by private contractors where they don't endanger overall delivery of the public service if there are problems.

proposition: The UK should defund the NHS.
paragraph: The UK should not defund the NHS because access to medical and hospital care is a fundamental need for any society. The NHS plays a crucial role in fulfilling this need, operating as part of a social contract supported through democratic processes. Dismantling or defunding such an institution would not only undermine this public agreement but also leave many vulnerable to inadequate healthcare. There are powerful vested interests that would benefit financially from a privatized health system, but this would likely come at the expense of equitable access to care for ordinary citizens. Evidence from other places where healthcare has been privatized demonstrates the resulting disparities and inefficiencies, including higher costs and poorer health outcomes. Rather than reducing funding, we should focus on strengthening the NHS to ensure that quality care remains accessible to all, not just those who can afford it.

proposition: The UK should defund the NHS.
paragraph: As a species we need medical help in an ongoing and emergency sense and asocial care if elderly or otherwise impaired. In our society a public service to provide this has been established, during a period of national concensus. It is free, for the most part, and those that choose not to use it for whatever reason, can pay for alternatives. No political proposing defunding the NHS has ever received a substantial voting block and therefore we have, in my view, a social concensus that this service is provided via taxation. Many people would like to the NHS to be defunded so that they themselves can profit, as is evident in areas like dentistry where this has already happened.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph: The UK should significantly expand its nuclear arsenal to strengthen national security and maintain a credible deterrent in an increasingly unstable global landscape. With rising threats from adversarial states and the potential for future conflicts, a robust nuclear capability is essential to ensure the UK’s sovereignty and deter aggression. A stronger arsenal would also reinforce the country’s position as a key NATO ally, contributing to collective defense and global strategic stability. While concerns about proliferation and costs are valid, the long-term security benefits outweigh these risks. Modernizing and expanding nuclear weapons would send a clear message of resolve, discouraging potential adversaries from escalating hostilities. In a world where power is often measured by military strength, the UK must not fall behind but instead invest in maintaining a formidable deterrent to safeguard its interests and uphold international peace.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph: The threat of WW3 has never been as high as it is right now. President Putin is continuing his war against Ukraine. The guy is very unpredictable and dangerous. Spending on defence should be a big priority right now. Our ability to defend our country has steadily decreased year upon year through lack of funding. Increased spending on defence should be top priority for the government right now with threats from Russia, China and the Middle East. The government needs to put its priorities into order as we have never needed to be in a lost to defend our country more.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: Why should people have to continue paying the licence fee when they do not watch the BBC? I believe some of their reporting on the conflict in Gaza has been appalling. They have appeared to support Hamas, which is a recognised terrorist organisation. Licence payers have also funded the salaries of some of the most morally corrupt individuals for many years, while the BBC has attempted to cover up the behaviour of its employees. The BBC no longer has a place in the world we live in today, and funding should be ended as soon as possible.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph:
Why should people to have to continue to pay the licence fee when they do not watch it.
 I think some of their reporting of the troubles in Gazza has been appalling. They have clearly been in support of Hamas who are a terrorist group.
 And licence payers have been paying the wages of some of the most depraved humans for many many years while the BBC has tried it's best to cover up the actions of it's employees. The BBC doesn't have a place in the would we live in right now. So funding should end as soon as possible.

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: The UK's push toward 100% renewable energy by 2030 represents a misguided policy that is fundamentally undermining our economic foundation. The net zero agenda is systematically destroying British industry, forcing manufacturers and businesses to either relocate abroad or shut down entirely due to unrealistic environmental mandates and regulatory burdens. Rather than delivering the promised cost savings, this transition is actually driving energy prices higher, placing an unbearable financial strain on households and businesses alike. The aggressive timeline ignores economic realities and technological limitations, prioritizing ideological goals over practical considerations. This reckless pursuit of renewable targets is making the UK less competitive internationally while failing to deliver the affordable, reliable energy that our economy desperately needs to thrive and grow.

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: -Ed millibands ambition to achieve net zero by 2030 is destroying industry in our country, even if they were to achieve their ridiculous targets it wouldn't make any difference to saving the world as the u.k contributes so little to global pollution. What's the point of this nonsense when the biggest contributers, China and India are doing nothing. All this net zero is doing to the u.k is destroying industry, losing jobs, increasing household energy costs and making everybody poorer when they claim achieving net zero will make everybody better off. The whole idea is absurd. We are destroying valuable farm land to solar farms and wind turbines.

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: I am deeply concerned about the climate crisis and the insufficient action being taken at the national level to address it. Transitioning the UK to fully renewable energy sources would be a significant and positive step forward, particularly with the ambitious goal of achieving this by 2030. While I recognize that this timeline may be challenging, urgent action is necessary to combat climate change. Moreover, such a transition could generate numerous jobs and stimulate the UK economy through the development of infrastructure and the creation of long-term employment opportunities once the renewable energy plants are operational.

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: I am really concerned about the climate crisis and the lack of action being taken on a national level to address this. Transitioning to fully renewable energy sources in the UK would be a big positive step in the right direction, especially with the given timeframe of by 2030. I am unsure of how realistic this is in terms of the timing, but we need to move fast to combat climate change. It would also create lots of jobs and boost the UK economy by building infrastructure and other such employment opportunities when the energy plants have been created successfully.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: I believe the UK should remain committed to the Paris Climate Agreement rather than withdrawing from it. The agreement represents a crucial international framework for addressing climate change, and the UK's participation demonstrates important global leadership on environmental issues. Withdrawing would undermine the country's credibility in international climate negotiations and send a concerning signal about its commitment to tackling one of the most pressing challenges of our time. The Paris Agreement provides valuable mechanisms for coordination, accountability, and knowledge-sharing between nations, which would be lost through withdrawal. While there may be legitimate concerns about implementation costs or specific targets, these issues are better addressed through reform and negotiation within the existing framework rather than abandoning the agreement altogether. The UK's continued participation is essential for maintaining international momentum on climate action.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: I will admit that I do not know a huge amount about the specifics of the Paris Climate Agreement in terms of the level of commitment required by each individual country to act on the proposed solutions. However, I do believe that it is mostly in support of taking definitive actions to address climate change, and therefore we should follow through on our agreement to act. Perhaps this could also be a way to justify and secure funding from the EU for UK-based projects that would work towards dealing with the climate crisis. Overall I think we should not withdraw.

proposition: The UK should implement legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity.
paragraph: The UK should implement legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity, given its significant negative impact on ecosystems. Biodiversity loss disrupts vital ecological balances, threatening species, habitats, and the natural services that sustain human life. Moreover, since biodiversity decline is deeply interconnected with climate change, adopting these targets would inherently address broader environmental challenges. By committing to enforceable measures, the UK can lead in mitigating both biodiversity loss and climate issues simultaneously, fostering a healthier environment and more sustainable future. Such targets would ensure accountability, drive policy action, and align with global conservation efforts. Protecting biodiversity isn’t just an ecological imperative—it’s a necessary step to combat the intertwined crises of habitat destruction and climate change, securing long-term benefits for nature and society.

proposition: The UK should implement legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity.
paragraph: I know that the ongoing climate crisis and humans' exploitation of the natural world is having a severe and permanent impact on biodiversity, and we are losing many species of plants and animals to extinction. These living things are crucial to maintaining a healthy ecosystem and the loss of plant life alone has a negative effect on climate change due to CO2 not being taken up. If we had a legally binding framework in place that lays out the specific targets for protecting biodiversity, then it would be more likely to be successfully addressed in comparison to something that is guidance only.

proposition: The UK should increase funding and resources for the police force.
paragraph: I strongly believe the UK should increase funding and resources for the police force as a fundamental governmental responsibility. The government should establish a dedicated percentage of GDP, such as 5%, specifically allocated to police funding annually, ensuring consistent and adequate financial support regardless of economic fluctuations. This commitment stems from the principle that protecting citizens is a government's primary duty, one that should never be compromised by cost considerations. A well-funded police force is essential for creating an environment where every citizen feels genuinely safe and secure, whether in their own homes or walking the streets. When people feel protected, it strengthens the social fabric and allows communities to thrive. Therefore, robust police funding isn't just about law enforcement—it's about fulfilling the government's obligation to provide security and peace of mind for all citizens.

proposition: The UK should increase funding and resources for the police force.
paragraph: It is regrettable that in this modern world, budgets supplied by government to fund police forces always seems to be on the receiving end of government cutbacks.  This is totally wrong.  Government must at all times fully fund all police forces throughout the country so that each and every citizen feels safe when out and about as well as in their homes.  This should also include measures where criminals receive stiffer punishments and more criminals are locked away for however long is necessary. Any government that fails it's citizens by offering adequate protection should be removed even if necessary by civil unrest.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: I recognize the importance of sustainability and the role local councils can play in addressing environmental challenges. However, I believe the decision to mandate comprehensive initiatives should be approached cautiously. While coordinated national action could bring consistency and momentum to sustainability efforts, a one-size-fits-all mandate might not account for the diverse needs, resources, and capacities of different councils. Flexibility may be necessary to ensure policies are practical and effective on a local level. Additionally, the success of such initiatives often depends on adequate funding, community engagement, and long-term planning—all of which vary between regions. Encouraging and supporting councils to develop tailored sustainability strategies might be more effective than rigid mandates. Therefore, while I support the goal of sustainability, I remain neutral on enforcing a blanket requirement, preferring a balance between national guidance and local autonomy.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all local councils implement comprehensive sustainability initiatives.
paragraph: Sustainability initiatives always sound that they are a good idea.  In a lot of cases measures such as these come with an increased cost to the local taxpayer. It should also be considered if these initiatives are beneficial to the local area and indeed, if they are even needed.  there is so much that can be read on initiatives such as these that there is always evidence both for and against them.  Finally, funding if agreed upon by all parties should be considered.  there may be some people that would find it difficult to help finance such measures and these considerations should always be taken into account before implementation.

proposition: The UK should implement a mandatory carbon emissions cap for all industries.
paragraph: "The world faces a profound dilemma: whether to cap carbon emissions. Some argue it’s essential to curb global warming and rising sea levels, while other prominent scientists claim it’s unnecessary, citing natural climate cycles. Regardless of the stance, the human impact must be central—capping emissions could disrupt livelihoods unless green jobs are readily available to offset losses in high-carbon industries."

proposition: The UK should implement a mandatory carbon emissions cap for all industries.
paragraph: This is one of the most difficult dilemas that the world currently faces.  To cap or not to cap emissions.  There is evidence from some quarters that this must be done to help prevent global warming and rising tides, whereas other emminent scientific leaders say that it is not necessary and that the planet goes through periods of high and lower temperatures.  Whatever the final consideration is based on,  the lives and living standards of people that this may affect and thier own personal wellbeing must be taken into account as by closing high carbon producing industries, it could affect thier future unless more 'green' employment is available.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: I believe that requiring employers in the UK to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training is a positive step toward fostering more respectful and equitable workplaces. Such training can help raise awareness about unconscious bias, promote empathy, and encourage inclusive behavior, creating a more welcoming environment for people of all backgrounds. While I recognize that training alone is not a complete solution to systemic inequalities, making it mandatory ensures that all employees are exposed to these important concepts and conversations. It signals a commitment from employers to cultivating a culture of understanding and respect, rather than leaving inclusion efforts to chance or individual discretion. However, it is also important that these programs are well-designed, meaningful, and accompanied by broader organizational changes to truly be effective. Overall, I support the initiative as a constructive measure to support a more diverse and inclusive workforce.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: I believe it's a good thing for UK employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees. It's very good to remind people of the importance of being diverse and inclusive, even though they might have heard it many times. The reason I am not 100% in agreement with the statement is because it can be dragged out and once people start to get bored of the message, they might start to get annoyed by it and that could give the opposite result. Make it mandatory, but make it short and snappy and relevant to each particular employment team and sector.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: I strongly oppose decreasing funding for education for disabled students as this represents clear discrimination against a vulnerable population that already faces significant barriers to accessing quality education. Such a policy would constitute poor government behaviour by abandoning the state's fundamental responsibility to ensure equal educational opportunities for all citizens, regardless of their abilities or disabilities. Reducing support for disabled students would perpetuate inequality and limit their potential to contribute meaningfully to society. Rather than cutting funding, the government should be investing more resources to create inclusive educational environments that accommodate diverse learning needs. This type of regressive policy reflects a concerning disregard for social justice and human rights principles that should guide public policy decisions in a compassionate, modern society.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not decrease funding for education for disabled students at all. That idea sounds like  discrimination to me! Disabled people suffer so much already and are so able in many areas, so they should therefore be encouraged to have the best education available to them. I know the Governement needs to save money somewhere, but you can't punish the people who have the biggest needs. The UK should take care of its' most vulnerable people. Education for disabled students is highly valuable by giving them the tools they need to succeed in life and be part of our UK community.

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph: "I believe increasing financial incentives for marriage would have no positive economic impact. Couples facing financial struggles might be swayed by these incentives, even if they lack genuine intent to marry, potentially leading to higher divorce rates later. This could burden the government further, as separated families may require additional housing and benefits. Marriage should not be driven by financial coercion, especially in a struggling economy where such incentives might exploit desperation rather than foster genuine commitment."

proposition: The UK should increase financial incentives for couples to get married.
paragraph:
I believe that increasing financial incentives for couples to get married will make no positive impact on the economy.
First of all, couples who have financial difficulties would be won over by these incentives, but they might not even have wanted to get married, leading to problems later down the line. I believe it would end in higher divorce rates, which will cost the Government more as families will be split and might have to find their own housing again, which might increase  people claiming benefits. People should not be bribed into getting married. In the current economy couples will be more enticed to be bribed.

proposition: The UK should legally recognize and protect all forms of transgender identity.
paragraph: "Everyone deserves the freedom to express their true identity. Just as homosexuality was once wrongly criminalized but is now accepted, all gender identities should likewise be protected. In the U.S., transgender rights are under attack, with bans on sports participation and exclusion from government roles sparking widespread outrage. These oppressive measures highlight the need for legal safeguards. By formally recognizing transgender identities, the UK could prevent such discrimination and uphold equality for all."

proposition: The UK should legally recognize and protect all forms of transgender identity.
paragraph: Everyone has a right to be who they want to be. Gone are the days of Homosexuality being thought of as unnatural and made against the law. It follows that all sexual orientations should be made legal too. There is a furore about this currently in the United States where the government has started to demonise Transgenderism. First making it illegal to compete in sports as a gender the individual was not born with and also removing transgender persons from government jobs. This has caused much unrest and demands for further debate. If the UK government legally recognised transgenders this could not happen here.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: I oppose banning military drone technology in the UK because these systems offer significant strategic and safety advantages that would be lost with prohibition. Drones excel at conducting missions in dangerous environments where sending manned aircraft would unnecessarily risk human lives, allowing military operations to proceed with reduced personnel casualties. When drones are destroyed in hostile situations, the loss involves only equipment rather than trained pilots, preserving valuable human resources. Additionally, drones serve as highly effective surveillance tools, providing critical intelligence gathering capabilities from elevated positions. Even if the UK were to ban military drones, privately operated drone technology would continue to exist and develop, meaning potential adversaries would retain access to these capabilities while the UK would voluntarily handicap its own defensive and operational capacity.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: Drones have become the go to spy in the sky in modern warfare as they do not involve the risk of losing a multi-million pound plane and pilot. Indeed if a drone was shot down it would not involve the death of a highly trained pilot. More recently Drones have been used to deliver weapons which kill those on the ground without risking a plane or pilot. A result not too dissimilar to a missile attack but at least the defending country has a better chance of stopping a drone than a missile due to the subsonic speed. Lastly why should the UK ban military drones when no other country will?

proposition: The UK should abolish voter ID requirements for parliament elections.
paragraph: I strongly believe that voter ID requirements are essential to maintaining the integrity and security of parliamentary elections in the UK. Ensuring that each vote cast is legitimate helps prevent fraud and upholds public confidence in the democratic process. While concerns about accessibility are valid, I think it is more important to prioritize measures that protect the system from abuse. Reasonable accommodations can be made to assist those who may face difficulties obtaining IDs, but completely abolishing the requirement would open the door to potential vulnerabilities. Requiring identification is a basic, common-sense safeguard that many democratic countries already have in place, and I view it as a minimal yet effective barrier to electoral manipulation. Trust in our political institutions depends on fair and secure elections, and voter ID helps support that goal.

proposition: The UK should abolish voter ID requirements for parliament elections.
paragraph: Providing  ID before people vote in UK elections is a safeguard that only people entitled to vote can do so. I eliminates repeated voting from an individual and makes the vote feel valuable to each individual. It prevents foreign nationals from influencing a vote that might be about our relationship with their home country. I do have one concern about our elderly (and others) being able to provide the correct ID. The production of ID cements the first level of voting entitlement that is already a feature of our system and that is the registration to vote issued by local authorities.

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph: "I’m unaware of this issue and can only speculate how it might occur, perhaps in media or politics. If the action is legal or permitted by their contract, dismissal seems unjustified. Unfair dismissal protections may already cover this, so specific measures might be unnecessary. However, if it damages the employer’s reputation, dismissal could be warranted—but concrete examples would be needed for a proper debate or reasoned response."

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph: I'm not cogniscent of this issue and can only make a reasonable guess as to how this could happen. I would think it may happen in media or political spheres? If the action is legal and/or within an agreed employment contract then its hard to see that dismissal is justified. I am not sure it needs a special or specific action on that basis as unfair or constructive dismissal is protected against. If it brings an organisation into disrepute then they may be justified in dismissal but I'd need some specific examples in order to give a reasoned answer or even debate it sensibly.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: I generally support implementing policies to protect and promote religious freedoms for Muslim communities in the UK, though with some reservations. Religious liberty is a fundamental right that should be safeguarded for all citizens, regardless of their faith, and Muslim communities deserve the same protections and opportunities for religious expression as any other group. The UK's commitment to pluralism and tolerance means ensuring that all religious minorities can practice their faith freely and participate fully in society. However, I have some concerns about how such policies might be implemented in practice, particularly around balancing religious accommodations with existing legal frameworks and secular principles. While I believe the intention is important and necessary, I would want to see careful consideration of how these protections are structured to ensure they enhance rather than complicate social cohesion and equality under the law.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: I believe that UK institutions do already implement several policies to protect religious freedoms for recognised religions, this includes observance and freedom. In some ways I do agree with the statement but I don't understand why we are singling out one religion? Im unsure on the definition of "promotion", it sounds wrong to me and dangerous. There is also some issues with some religions preach or are interpreted in ways that are contrary to law so its a sticky problem. In my view all religions should be banned and kept as a hobby and not treated in a special way.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: Accelerating digital transformation across all public services should be a top priority for the UK government because it offers substantial opportunities to save money and improve efficiency. By digitizing routine tasks and streamlining administrative processes, public services can reduce operational costs and allocate resources more effectively. This transformation also allows human workers to focus on more complex, creative, and meaningful work rather than repetitive tasks that can be automated. Digital tools can enhance the speed and accuracy of public service delivery, making government services more responsive and accessible to citizens. Embracing innovation in this way is essential for building a modern, efficient, and forward-looking public sector.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: Technology such as AI and machine learning can provide a better service that can be a twenty four hour, seven days per week and all year round. If it begins with very basic repetative tasks it can free up people to be more creative and analytic in their work. It provides better quality work and allows some services to be performed that would be too onerous to even contemplate without automation. There can be savings in time and money. As a bonus, it will increase the technical "intelligence" of the workforce and provide un thought of benefits in the future.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
paragraph: The UK, as a non-Catholic country, should not maintain any formal ties with the Catholic Church. More broadly, no country should be formally connected to any religious organization, as the state and religion ought to remain separate to ensure neutrality and inclusivity. Formal ties may give the impression of endorsement or preference, which undermines the secular nature of governance. Additionally, state visits from the Pope often result in significant costs to taxpayers, and any perceived official connection might encourage such visits, increasing the financial burden without clear public benefit. However, it is unclear whether any formal ties currently exist. If there are none, then the proposition to sever them is moot, as one cannot sever what does not exist. Therefore, while I support the principle behind the proposition, its practical relevance depends on the actual status of UK–Catholic Church relations.

proposition: The UK should sever all formal ties with the Catholic Church.
