paragraph: I belive that pensions should be able to support someones life once they have finished working therefore they do not have to struggle or worry about food, heating etc .i do not belive the age should be increased much more maybe only 2/4 years more as i do not belive that people should work beyond their physicality therefore i do not think the age should go higher than 70. as i believe people should have time to enjoy the rest of their life and enoy not working after all those years in which they have had to work for 40-50+ years

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: I believe the UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement because, from what I understand, it would benefit both people and the environment. While I don’t know all the details of the agreement, my current perspective is that distancing the UK from it could lead to more effective, localized solutions tailored to our specific needs. The agreement may impose unrealistic or inflexible targets that hinder progress rather than fostering it. By stepping away, the UK could focus on practical, homegrown initiatives that directly address environmental challenges while also supporting economic growth. This approach might offer greater freedom to innovate and implement policies that genuinely work for both the planet and the public. Ultimately, I think prioritizing national strategies over international commitments could deliver better outcomes for the environment and the people who depend on it.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: withdrawing would allow the Uk to set its own environment pokcies without being bound by international targets or reporting frameworks, some argu that the pairs agreement imposes one size fits all goals that don't reflect each countries unique circumstances especially for nations like the UK that are already relatively advanced in decarbonisation. meeting the pairs goals can involve costly transitions like phasing out fossils fuels subsidising renewables or overhauling industries that may stain business and taxpayers , critics say these costs could be spent on adaptation strategies , domestic innovation or immediate social needs like health care or housing in today's society.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulation on the use of artificial intelligence technologies.
paragraph: The UK should implement strict regulation on the use of artificial intelligence technologies because AI can be easily misused to spread misinformation. As these tools become more advanced, people are able to generate highly convincing content that others may believe without question, blurring the line between truth and fabrication. This can have serious societal and political consequences. Additionally, the energy consumption required to power large AI models is considerable, contributing to environmental concerns such as increased carbon emissions and resource depletion. Without proper oversight, the widespread and unregulated use of AI not only poses ethical and security risks but also adds to ecological strains. Regulation is necessary to ensure responsible usage, prevent abuse, and minimize the environmental impact of these technologies.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulation on the use of artificial intelligence technologies.
paragraph:
People are able to generate any image, which often looks real. This can easily be used to spread misinformation/ fake news. If this is not regulated it could cause big problems and push certain agendas which are not impartial and have their own motivation. The motivations may be political/ financial and not be in peoples best interest. There should also be more teaching in schools / workplaces on how to spot this.
Its also really bad for the environment, there is so much energy being used which is not necessary for running the servers and cooling them down etc .

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: While I lack expertise in this area, my initial reaction is that legalization could benefit ordinary citizens by providing easier and more affordable access to entertainment content versus expensive streaming platforms. Nevertheless, this policy might inadvertently promote increased data theft by individuals and organizations. Such outcomes would prove highly detrimental. Citizens would face severely compromised privacy, and the vast amounts of personal information circulating could create significant problems with insurance providers (should health or financial records be compromised), as I suspect companies would leverage this data for profit maximization and individual exploitation.

proposition: The UK should legalise internet piracy.
paragraph: This is not a topic i know much about. My immediate thoughts were that it would be better for the average person as it would make accessing films/ tv shows etc much easier and cheaper compared to streaming services. However, this would likely encourage more people/corporations to pirate peoples data. This would likely have very negative impacts. People would have very little privacy and the abundance of information available about people could lead to issues with insurance ( if medical and or financial data was leaked ) as i believe corporations would use this to make more money and exploit individuals

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph: The death penalty is an archaic and morally indefensible form of punishment that has no place in a modern, civilized society. It irrevocably violates the fundamental right to life and carries an unacceptable risk of executing innocent people, as evidenced by numerous wrongful convictions. Rather than delivering justice, it perpetuates a cycle of violence and fails to address the root causes of crime. Rehabilitation and restorative justice should be prioritized over retribution, as they offer a more humane and effective approach to reducing harm. The UK has long been a leader in human rights, and reintroducing the death penalty would undermine its commitment to dignity, fairness, and the rule of law. There is no credible evidence that capital punishment deters crime, and its abolition reflects societal progress. Justice must be tempered with mercy, not vengeance.

proposition: The UK should reintroduce the death penalty.
paragraph: I feel very strongly that the death penalty is very wrong. I don't believe people have the right to decide who loves or dies. The death penalty would likely be used for the most extreme crimes such as murder, people often say people who murder should face the same punishment but i believe this makes the people deciding this just as bad as the initial perpetrator. There are also incidences where people have been given the death penalty and evidence has come to light later that has proven them innocent  but this can obviously not be undone. I find the idea very inhumane

proposition: The UK should ban the teaching of feminism in all schools.
paragraph: Banning the teaching of feminism would have serious negative consequences for society. It is essential for children to learn about the history of women's struggles and the ongoing fight for equality. Understanding this history helps students appreciate the progress that has been made and recognize the work that still lies ahead. Studying feminism promotes gender equality by challenging harmful stereotypes and equipping students with the critical thinking skills needed to address issues such as unequal pay, limited job opportunities for women, and gender-based discrimination. It empowers them to identify injustice and speak out against it. Teaching children why sexism and misogyny are harmful fosters values like kindness, fairness, and empathy. By instilling these principles early, we help cultivate a future generation committed to equal rights and standing against discrimination.

proposition: The UK should ban the teaching of feminism in all schools.
paragraph: Banning the teaching of feminism will cause serious negative effects on society. It is important because children should learn about to history of women's struggle. Understanding this history helps students see how far society has come and how much work is still needed to be done. Learning about feminism promotes gender equality by challenging stereotypes and giving students the tools to think critically about issues like unequal pay, limited job opportunities for women, and gender discrimination. It empowers them to recognize injustice and speak up against it. Helping children understand why sexism and misogyny are harmful encourages kindness, fairness, and empathy. When we teach these values early, we help build a future generation that supports equal rights and stands against discrimination.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: I support the goal of protecting rural areas but believe stricter regulations to limit urbanisation could have unintended consequences. Restricting urban development might reduce housing supply, worsening affordability issues, especially in high-demand areas. A balanced approach is needed—one that increases housing availability through thoughtful urban planning while preserving rural landscapes. Forcing people to live farther from cities due to limited expansion could lead to longer commutes, increased traffic congestion, and higher pollution levels, undermining sustainability efforts. Instead of outright limits, policies should encourage efficient land use, such as denser, well-connected urban developments with green spaces. This way, we can meet housing needs without sacrificing rural areas or creating additional environmental and economic burdens. The focus should be on smart growth, ensuring both urban and rural communities thrive sustainably.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: Implementing stricter regulations to limit urbanisation can cause several problems. First, it reduces the number of available homes, making it harder for people to find affordable places to live in cities. When fewer homes are built, the demand for houses stays high, which pushes up prices and rents. This makes housing less affordable, especially for low and middle class families. Additionally, if building is restricted near cities, people may be forced to move farther away. This leads to long commutes, more traffic congestion, and higher pollution levels, as more people rely on cars to travel greater distances. In my opinion, strict regulations can create serious challenges for housing and the environment, so there should be a balance.

proposition: The UK should legalise euthanasia.
paragraph: I have significant reservations about legalising euthanasia in the UK. While I understand the compassionate intentions behind such proposals and acknowledge that end-of-life suffering is a genuine concern, I believe the risks and ethical complications outweigh the potential benefits. My primary worry centres on protecting vulnerable people who might feel pressured to end their lives due to family circumstances, financial burdens, or inadequate care options. I'm also concerned about the potential for mission creep, where eligibility criteria could gradually expand beyond the originally intended scope. Rather than legalising euthanasia, I would prefer to see greater investment in palliative care services and pain management, which can address suffering while preserving the fundamental principle of protecting life. The current legal framework, while imperfect, provides important safeguards that shouldn't be dismantled lightly.

proposition: The UK should legalise euthanasia.
paragraph: Legalizing euthanasia can be dangerous because some people might feel forced to choose death even if they don't want to. They might think they are a burden to their family due to financial or other reasons. This raises serious ethical concerns about consent and whether their decision is truly voluntary and driven by pressure. Also, with the advancement in the field of palliative care, modern medicine now has ways to help people feel less pain and suffer at the end of their lives. Instead of allowing people to end their lives, we should focus on making this better so patients can live comfortably with dignity.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: Free speech serves as a fundamental cornerstone of democratic society by enabling individuals to express their ideas and opinions without fear of censorship or retribution. The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech because such safeguards would prevent the unfair punishment of citizens who voice legitimate viewpoints or engage in open debate. When people can freely share their thoughts, society benefits from a more robust marketplace of ideas where different perspectives can be examined, challenged, and refined. Stronger legal protections would ensure that individuals are not subjected to disproportionate consequences for expressing their views, whether through employment termination, legal action, or other forms of retaliation. By strengthening these protections, the UK would reinforce its commitment to democratic values and create an environment where productive discourse can flourish, ultimately leading to better-informed citizens and more effective policy-making.

proposition: The UK should implement stronger legal protections for free speech.
paragraph: Free speech is important because it allows people to share their ideas and opinions, even when those ideas are different or unpopular. In a fair and open society, everyone should feel free to speak without fear. When people are able to express themselves, it helps others understand different points of view and creates room for learning. Today, some people can lose their jobs or face public backlash simply for expressing a peaceful opinion. This can make others afraid to speak up even when they are being honest or respectful. By protecting free speech more clearly in the law, the UK can make sure people are treated fairly and not punished for sharing their thoughts.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: China's political system differs significantly from democracies as it lacks free elections. Citizens cannot vote for leaders, with power held by a single party, preventing genuine public influence. Freedom of speech and press are also restricted, discouraging criticism of the government under threat of punishment. Media control further limits access to unbiased information, undermining transparency. These practices conflict with democratic principles, justifying the UK's formal condemnation of China's system as undemocratic.

proposition: The UK should formally condemn China's political system as incompatible with democratic values.
paragraph: China's political system is very different from a democracy because it does not allow free and fair elections. People in China cannot vote to choose their leaders, and there is only one political party in control. This means the government stays in power without the people having a real ay. Another big problem is that freedom of speech and press are limited. Citizens can not clearly share their opinions or criticize the government without facing punishment. News and social media are often controlled, so people do not get full or honest information. These rules go against the values of democracy. because of these reasons the UK should clearly say that China's system does not match democratic values.

proposition: The UK should remove all regulations on environmental sustainability in supply chains.
paragraph: I believe that the UK should eliminate all regulations on environmental sustainability in supply chains to foster greater economic growth and innovation. Overregulation often burdens businesses with excessive costs and bureaucratic hurdles, stifling competitiveness and limiting their ability to adapt quickly to market changes. Removing these constraints would empower companies to find their own efficient and cost-effective ways to manage resources and production, encouraging entrepreneurial freedom and market-driven solutions. Market demand and corporate responsibility can play a more effective role in promoting sustainable practices than government mandates. In a global economy, unregulated supply chains would also make UK businesses more competitive by reducing operational costs and enhancing flexibility. Ultimately, industries should be trusted to balance environmental concerns with economic priorities without being hindered by government overreach.

proposition: The UK should remove all regulations on environmental sustainability in supply chains.
paragraph: Removing all environmental rules in supply chain can help businesses save money. These rules can be expensive to follow because companies may need to buy special equipment or use more costly materials. Without these rules, businesses could spend less and lower their prices, which might help them grow and compete with others around the world. It could also make supply chain faster. Right now, companies often have to do a lot of paper work and follow many steps to meet environmental standards. This can slow things down. If those rules were removed, businesses could move goods more quickly and make decisions faster.

proposition: The UK should restrict the development of large language models.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not restrict the development of large language models, as such restrictions would likely hinder innovation and technological progress. While I acknowledge there are legitimate concerns about AI safety, bias, and potential misuse, I think these challenges are better addressed through thoughtful regulation, industry standards, and responsible development practices rather than broad restrictions on the technology itself. The UK has an opportunity to be a leader in AI development, and overly restrictive policies could push innovation to other countries with more permissive regulatory environments. Instead of limiting development, the focus should be on ensuring proper oversight, transparency requirements, and ethical guidelines that allow the technology to advance while mitigating risks. Heavy-handed restrictions could stifle beneficial applications in healthcare, education, research, and other sectors where these models show tremendous promise.

proposition: The UK should restrict the development of large language models.
paragraph:
Large language models will be available via the internet, so there is little to be achieved by the UK restricting their development. I also don't think implementing the restrictions would be possible, we are just not yet in a position (maybe yet) where this could effectively be policed.
Also, like all new developments and technologies, they can be used for good or bad ends. I'm not sure there has been a single technology that has actually been successfully suppressed. Humans just do develop stuff although some attempts fizzle out.. I think we would do better and probably be more successful at monitoring and restricting the application of large language models.

proposition: The UK should adopt a policy of neutrality and non-intervention in all foreign wars.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not adopt a policy of strict neutrality and non-intervention in all foreign wars. While avoiding unnecessary conflict is important, we have a moral duty to use our resources to help those in need, especially in situations where human rights are being violated or populations are at risk. History has shown us that turning a blind eye to aggression or injustice can lead to greater consequences later on. The phrase "First they came for..." reminds us that standing by while others suffer can eventually endanger ourselves. Intervention, when justified and carefully considered, can be a powerful tool for preventing atrocities and promoting global stability. Therefore, while we should approach foreign conflicts thoughtfully, we must not rule out involvement altogether if it means standing up for fundamental human values and protecting innocent lives.

proposition: The UK should adopt a policy of neutrality and non-intervention in all foreign wars.
paragraph:
It is the "all" in the statement with which I strongly disagree- certainly, there are wars in which we should not intervene. But we in the UK have considerable advantages and resources, and should be prepared to support countries that are being invaded rather than just standing by and watching. The places I think we should support most of all at the moment are, of course, Ukraine, but also Palestine.  It matters which side we pick - I am horrified by the current government's support for Israel! 
And we are an international community. Niemoller's poem "First they come..." was about the Nazis but has many applications. We should speak out against evil.

proposition: The UK should transition to a socialist economic system, replacing capitalism.
paragraph: "I’m torn not because I lack thought on this issue, but because deep reflection hasn’t yielded a clear answer. Capitalism has serious flaws, fueling environmental destruction and indifference toward people—the vulnerable suffer, and trickle-down economics is often a sham. Yet, the socialist models I know (USSR, China) mostly failed their citizens, though Cuba showed some promise. I visited Cuba years ago and saw progress. Perhaps capitalism-socialism is a spectrum, and the UK should lean more socialist. Ultimately, I believe the planet’s survival is the priority."

proposition: The UK should transition to a socialist economic system, replacing capitalism.
paragraph:
I am ambivalent not because I haven't thought about this issue, but because I have thought about it a  lot andjust don't have a solution. Capitalism has many bad points, and it is contributing towards the destruction of the planet, It also just doesn't care about people, the weakest do just go to the wall and trickle-down economics is, in most cases, nonsense.
However, the only socialist societies that I am historically aware of (the USSR, China) have not really worked for the majority of people either, although perhaps Cuba had some success. I visited Cuba a long while ago and it seemed to be improving people's lives. I think maybe capitalism-socialism is a spectrum, and the UK should work towards being more socialist than it is now. I actually think the planet is the overriding issue.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: I believe that requiring employers in the UK to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training is a positive step toward creating more equitable and respectful workplaces. Such training can help address unconscious bias, promote understanding among employees from different backgrounds, and foster a culture of inclusivity. While I acknowledge that training alone may not solve every issue related to workplace inequality, it serves as an important foundation for broader organizational change. Encouraging all employees to engage in conversations about diversity helps to build awareness and reduce discrimination, ultimately benefiting both individuals and companies. However, it’s also important that these programs are thoughtfully designed and regularly updated to remain effective and relevant.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph: I believe that diversity and inclusion are very important, and should be encouraged throughout daily life, at home, work, school and generally in society. As for the most effective way of achieving this, I think it is vital for people who have influences, so parents, teachers, bosses, etc. to lead by example, and model the behaviour they would like to see from others. Desirable attitudes and behaviours should be encouraged in a positive way, rather than forced onto people - people like to make their own minds up. Demonstrating the positives of diversity and inclusion may be better than forcing training onto people. Often training can feel like it is just something that needs to be done, like a box-ticking exercise, but diversity and inclusion should be part of everyday life. However, training might be a step in the right direction, and probably not a bad thing.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations on cryptocurrency transactions.
paragraph: I support strict regulations on cryptocurrency transactions in the UK, as I believe all financial activities should be tightly controlled to protect consumers. Cryptocurrencies, while innovative, have become a breeding ground for scams and fraudulent schemes, leaving many inexperienced investors vulnerable to significant losses. The decentralized and often anonymous nature of these transactions makes them particularly risky, and without proper oversight, bad actors can exploit unsuspecting individuals. Implementing robust regulations would help ensure transparency, accountability, and security in the crypto market, reducing the prevalence of fraud and fostering greater trust in digital assets. By treating cryptocurrencies with the same scrutiny as traditional financial systems, the UK can safeguard its citizens while still allowing for technological progress in the financial sector.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations on cryptocurrency transactions.
paragraph: I believe that there should be strict regulations on all financial transactions, including cryptocurrency. This should ensure fairness and no wrong-doing. From what I have heard in the media, there are a lot of scams with cryptocurrency. Ideally, with strict regulations this could be stamped out, or a least minimised. The government should be doing more to eradicate as many scams as possible. However, I have always thought that if something seems too good to be true, it probably is. I worry that some people are looking out for a quick fix when it comes to money, rather than goo old hard-work.

proposition: The UK should mandate companies to offer paid parental leave for all new parents.
paragraph: Supporting employee welfare through policies like paid parental leave creates stronger workplace loyalty and enhanced productivity. Parenthood represents a fundamental human right that deserves protection. The transformative nature of becoming a parent necessitates dedicated time for adjustment and family focus during this critical period. Given that new parents frequently experience exhaustion and stress, providing this support demonstrates logical compassion. This principle extends beyond parenthood to encompass employees facing family illness, bereavement, or other personal losses including beloved pets. Nevertheless, the precarious position of zero-hour contract workers presents a concerning challenge, as such policies risk widening the already significant divide between secure and insecure employment arrangements.

proposition: The UK should mandate companies to offer paid parental leave for all new parents.
paragraph: I believe that employers should look after their employees, as this will mean that those employees will care more about their jobs and work even harder. Everyone has the basic human right of having children, if they wish. Becoming a new parent is life-changing, so new parents should have some paid leave to adjust and concentrate on what is important at that time - their family. New parents are often (understandable) tired and stressed, so it makes sense to give them that time. I also think that it is not just new parents who might need understanding employers - those with sick relatives, or grieving someone close, including pets. However, there are lots of people who have zero-hour contracts, and the gap between those and other workers will just get bigger and bigger.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase its military spending.
paragraph: I believe the current global instability, exemplified by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, demonstrates that militarily weak nations become prime targets for aggressive powers. Significantly increasing our military spending and weapons capabilities is essential because we cannot depend on other countries for protection during an attack—we must possess the strength to defend ourselves independently, which would deter potential aggressors from considering us a viable target. Furthermore, I propose reinstating mandatory national service for all individuals, whether native-born, migrants, or refugees, as this would both strengthen our defense capabilities and serve as a meaningful demonstration of commitment and allegiance to our nation.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase its military spending.
paragraph: I think currently the world is a very unstable place and one where countries who are militarily weak are more likely to be a target for power hungry countries as in the case of Russia invading Ukraine. I believe that to increase our spending and weapons is necessary as we should not rely on other countries to help us in the case of attack but should be able to defend ourselves which I believe will make other countries think twice about making an attack on us. I also feel we should go a step further and reinstate national service for all whether you are born here or move here as a migrant or refugee as a way to show allegiance to the country

proposition: The UK should implement a 4-day workweek for all full-time employees.
paragraph: I see some merit in the idea of a 4-day workweek for full-time employees in the UK, but I have reservations about its practicality and potential impacts. While the concept could improve work-life balance and employee well-being, I am concerned about possible consequences for productivity, business costs, and service availability. Smaller businesses, in particular, might struggle to maintain workflow and customer expectations with fewer working days. There are also questions around how such a shift would be implemented fairly across different sectors, especially those requiring continuous coverage like healthcare or public transport. Additionally, I am unsure whether a reduction in working days would lead to the same, more, or less pressure on employees to meet performance targets in a shorter time. Although the idea is appealing in theory, I believe it needs more research, experimentation, and careful planning before widespread adoption should be pursued.

proposition: The UK should implement a 4-day workweek for all full-time employees.
paragraph:
It is a nice idea in principle and may give a better home work balance but this has to be looked at based on the effect on businesses. Presumable the business would be picking up the cost which could have a negative effect on their sustainability and the economy. Businesses may not be able to afford to do this and it may affect their ability to operate successfully.
For things such as the NHS it could have a very detrimental effect as we already have huge waiting lists and its difficult to get a GP appointment. If staff were only working 4 days per week I can see the problems increasing

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph: I believe abortion should remain legal in the UK as it is ultimately an individual choice, with valid reasons for seeking one. However, I think it should be permitted in specific circumstances, such as cases of rape or when there is a risk of inherited diseases or severe disabilities. While I support access to abortion, I also feel it should not be used as a routine method of birth control and should be discouraged in such cases. My stance is nuanced, recognizing that each situation is unique and requires careful consideration. The decision should balance personal autonomy with ethical concerns, ensuring compassion and support for those facing difficult choices. Overall, I lean toward allowing abortion but with thoughtful restrictions to address complex moral and practical considerations.

proposition: The UK should make abortion illegal.
paragraph: My view is that whether or not I am for or against depends on the circumstances. For example I am against it being used as a method of birth control but there are circumstances when I think abortion is necessary. If the fetus shows abnormalities or inherited serious diseases then I think consideration should be given to termination to help eradicate disease and also considering how abnormalities may affect the quality of life of the individual if the pregnancy was to go full term. Anyone who is a victim of rape should be able to have an abortion as continuing with the pregnancy would not be fair on the mother or unborn child and could result in a poor relationship if continued to full term

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: Increasing the state pension age is a deeply unfair proposition that disproportionately harms working-class individuals, who often face physically demanding jobs and shorter life expectancies. Many people already struggle to make ends meet, and delaying access to pensions would force them to work longer under increasingly precarious conditions. This policy ignores the growing wealth inequality and the fact that many retirees rely on the state pension as their primary income. Instead of punishing workers, the government should focus on ensuring fair wages, better workplace conditions, and adequate support for older citizens. Raising the pension age risks exacerbating poverty among the elderly, particularly those in manual labor roles who cannot reasonably continue working into their late 60s or beyond. It’s a short-sighted solution to demographic challenges that fails to address the root causes of economic insecurity.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: people work from a young age and if they have to work till they are iover 65 i dont think its worth even having a pension, people work most odf their lives and at the end theyre left with hardly anything especially because of the cost of living crisis its getting harder and harder, if anything they should lower the pension age, increase benefits. Furthermore, life expectancy is different depending on the individuals quality of life/ diet, you cannot put a high number or make it equal for everyone its unfair for those that have lived in poorer areas or have had bad quality of life as they will never be able to work uptill the pension age

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph: There are already many protections in place for employees, such as human rights laws. While it is unfair to be dismissed due to social media backlash, I believe any action taken should be appropriate and considered on an individual basis, as the nature of the backlash can vary greatly. Sometimes it may be unfair, while in other cases it may be justified. Social media is a part of everyday life and often reflects a person’s ethics and values, giving insight into who they are. Therefore, while there should be protections, each case should be evaluated individually.

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph: there are already alot of protection in place for employees e.g human rights etc , yes it is unfair to be dismissed however i think it should be done in an appropriate manner and in a way where its done on a indivual basis this is because backlash can vary and therefore yes sometimes it can be unfair and sometimes it is totally fair. Social media is in everyone daily life and tells alot about the person e.g their ethics and values, what they are life, therefore yes there should be protection but it should also be considered on a indivual basis.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph: I oppose increasing the UK's nuclear arsenal because the country already possesses a substantial number of nuclear weapons that are sufficient for deterrence purposes. Rather than expanding this stockpile further, the government should redirect its attention and resources toward pressing domestic issues that directly impact citizens' daily lives. Housing represents just one of many critical areas requiring urgent investment and policy attention. The current housing crisis affects millions of people who struggle with affordability, availability, and quality of accommodation. Similarly, other vital sectors such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure deserve priority funding over additional nuclear weapons. In an era where practical, everyday challenges demand immediate solutions, allocating significant resources to expand an already adequate nuclear deterrent seems misguided and disconnected from the real needs of the population.

proposition: The UK should increase its arsenal of nuclear weapons.
paragraph: i think its good for the uk to have nuclear weapons as it is really good for security purposes and protects against potential wars etc. however uk does already have enough nuclear weapons and i do not believe they are at risk of being in a war  furthermore, i beleive there are alot more other important things the givernment should be worriying about as post covid the uk has gone into 'recession', there are cost of living crisis, longer nhs waiting times, housing shortages therefore they should invest in these things more as they will be more useful for the public

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: It is inarguable that Europe currently faces the most severe geopolitical challenges since World War II. The Russian invasion of Ukraine, escalating Middle Eastern conflicts (Israel-Hamas and broader regional tensions), and the unpredictability of the incoming Trump administration with its territorial ambitions regarding Canada, Greenland, and Panama - these converging crises demand substantial European military and peacekeeping resources. I support the UK contributing meaningfully to European remilitarisation for our national security, broader European stability, and as a demonstration of renewed unity and collaboration with Europe, which is critically needed following the diplomatic rupture of Brexit. However, to fully endorse this proposition, I would require detailed information about the specific mechanisms for increasing military spending and the fiscal sources for such investment.

proposition: The UK should increase its military spending to strengthen its role within NATO.
paragraph: It is inarguable that Europe currently faces the most geopolitically adversity it has faced since World War II. The Russian invasion of Ukraine, the volatility in the Middle East (Israel-Hamas and Israel-Iran wars), and the unpredictability of the USA's Trump administration and their overtures of acquiring Canada, Greenland, and Panama - these are all emergent crises that demand the attention of European military/peacekeeping resources. I agree that the UK should contribute as much as possible to the remilitarisation of Europe, for our own security, for wider European security, and as a show of unity and collaboration with Europe which is sorely needed after the diplomatic disaster of Brexit. However, to truly determine whether I agree with the statement, I would need to know exactly how military spending would be increased, where the money would come from, etc.

proposition: The UK should always prioritise free speech over political correctness.
paragraph: Free speech is an essential foundation of any truly free and democratic society, and it must not be sacrificed lightly or routinely, especially in the face of political correctness. The ability to express ideas, question authority, and engage in open debate is what allows societies to grow, adapt, and protect individual liberties. While political correctness aims to promote inclusivity and protect against harmful language, it should never override our fundamental right to speak freely. However, in rare and exceptional circumstances—particularly in sensitive diplomatic contexts—there may be justification for exercising restraint. If unfiltered free speech in such cases risks provoking conflict or causing significant harm to the wider population, then a temporary, measured prioritisation of political correctness might be prudent. Nonetheless, these instances should remain the exception rather than the rule, and free speech should overwhelmingly take precedence in both national discourse and public policy.

proposition: The UK should always prioritise free speech over political correctness.
paragraph: Free speech is one of the most important features of our society and it should take priority over anything else. Any unfair curtailment of free speech is a slippery slope that will invariably be expanded more and more to suit the agenda of a nefarious actor, and so free speech must be protected and no infringement allowed. The only justification I can potentially make for prioritising political correctness over free speech is for diplomatic reasons, if political correctness is ever required in order for successful international relations with another country. If the breakdown of those international relations would be detrimental to the UK population, I can maybe see that as some justification for not exercising our free speech.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the production and distribution of pornography.
paragraph: While I recognize the potential harms associated with pornography, such as its impact on mental health or exploitation risks, I lean against imposing stricter regulations in the UK. Overregulation could infringe on personal freedoms and drive the industry underground, making it harder to monitor and control. A balanced approach—focusing on age verification, ethical production standards, and education—might be more effective than heavy-handed restrictions. However, I remain skeptical that tighter rules would address the root issues, as cultural attitudes and accessibility trends often outpace legislation. The government should prioritize targeted measures over broad restrictions, ensuring accountability without unnecessarily limiting adult autonomy. Concerns about censorship and enforcement challenges further temper my support for stricter regulations.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the production and distribution of pornography.
paragraph: I agree with the rationale for stricter regulation of pornography, as overconsumption and addiction is undoubtedly harmful and promotes unhealthy attitudes around sex and relationships. I would be in favour of greater regulation of pornography at the point of production, only. I would not feel comfortable supporting greater restrictions at the point of distribution, however, as this would only be possible through the erosion of online privacy. In order to access pornography, web users would have to sacrifice their anonymity to provide proof of age, banking information, etc. and I don't feel that this loss of privacy is worth it.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: Your position on mandatory gender diversity quotas for UK publicly listed companies reflects a balanced consideration of competing values and practical concerns. While you recognize the importance of promoting gender equality in corporate leadership and acknowledge that systemic barriers may require structural interventions to address, you also have reservations about government-mandated quotas as the optimal solution. You likely appreciate the potential benefits of diverse leadership teams for business performance and representation, yet worry about questions of merit-based selection, potential backlash effects, or whether quotas might inadvertently undermine the achievements of women who reach leadership positions. Your stance suggests you may prefer alternative approaches such as transparency requirements, voluntary targets, or addressing underlying barriers to advancement, while remaining open to the possibility that quotas could be necessary if other measures prove insufficient in achieving meaningful progress toward gender parity.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: While gender diversity is indeed an important issue within many workplaces, my belief is that the best way to fill positions in companies is to hire the best and most qualified people for the position. If applications can be made anonymous so they are not judged based on any kind of gender/age/race/religion etc bias the we are more likely to end up with the best people in the right places. Someone should not just get the position when they are the best candidate available of that particular gender if this means someone more qualified missing out. I don't believe there exists such a thing as positive discrimination which is what this essentially is.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: Allowing AI tools to complete homework risks creating a generation with shallow education, as students may lack genuine understanding. It also masks those needing extra support, since their true abilities remain hidden behind AI-generated work. Individuality fades as assignments grow uniform, produced by similar programs, while reliance on AI fosters laziness by convincing students they need not put in effort themselves.

proposition: The UK should implement strict regulations to prohibit students from using AI tools like ChatGPT for completing homework assignments.
paragraph: If students are able to use AI tools to do their work for them, we risk the chance of having a large portion of the population with a very small amount of true education. This can also hide the students that could excel with a little extra help as they won't necessarily be identifiable if they are turning in work that isn't fully their own. We will also lose the individuality of students work as every piece will become more and more similar when being churned out by similar programmes available and will encourage laziness if students believe they don't need to complete the work as they can just use a programme to do it for them.

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: The UK’s legal codes are in urgent need of comprehensive reform, as many of them are antiquated and no longer align with the realities of modern society. Laws that were drafted decades or even centuries ago often fail to address current social, technological, and economic contexts, resulting in ambiguity and irrelevance. This outdated framework creates barriers to understanding and applying the law effectively. At the very least, citizens should be able to access and comprehend the laws that govern their lives without the need for legal expertise. Ensuring clarity and accessibility is not a luxury, but a minimum standard in a democratic society committed to fairness and justice. Updating and simplifying legal language, consolidating statutes, and removing obsolete provisions would help empower individuals, promote transparency, and strengthen trust in the legal system. It's time for a legal system that reflects the needs and values of today's citizens.

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: The UK is a very old nation and as a result of this many of our legal systems, codes and laws are also very old. This means they are now at a risk of being largely outdated and many of them are no longer relevant in todays life and society. As a result of this we need to look at modernising as much as possible with a concentration on making everything as clear as possible and as accessible to all who live within the United Kingdom. This should be the very minimum we aim for to make the fairest society that we are capable of. This would require a very comprehensive check of all current systems and would be a significant undertaking but is something that we need to look at as soon as possible.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: The UK should not increase the state pension age, as it is already set too high and fails to recognize the fundamental human need for a fulfilling retirement period. Working people deserve the opportunity to enjoy their later years while they still have their health and vitality, rather than being forced to continue working until their bodies and minds begin to deteriorate. The current pension age already pushes many individuals beyond their physical and mental prime, leaving them with limited time to pursue personal interests, spend quality time with family, or simply rest after decades of contributing to society through their labor. Rather than extending working lives further, the government should prioritize ensuring that citizens can retire at a reasonable age when they can still actively enjoy the fruits of their lifelong contributions to the economy and society.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: I disagree with this statement for many reasons. Firstly, I think the retirement age is already too high as people spend most of their life working so they should be able to retire younger and enjoy life. Also, as you get older, most people get health problems which will prevent them from enjoying their life after retirement. Many people plan what they want to do when they retire and increasing the retirement age will stop these plans which is not fair at all. We spend too much of our life working and stressing about work so we should be able to have a good retirement.

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: "I have mixed feelings about this statement. Opposing it, I argue that the UK must currently focus on its economy, the NHS, and immigration, which are more pressing issues. Yet, strengthening ties with other nations might help address these problems. It could also ease post-Brexit uncertainties by ensuring support and solidarity from allies. Thus, forming new alliances could benefit Britain overall."

proposition: The UK should prioritize strengthening diplomatic ties with Commonwealth nations over forming new alliances with non-Commonwealth countries.
paragraph: I feel two ways about this statement. My against argument is that at the moment, the UK needs to prioritise the economy and other areas such as NHS and the levels of immigration. These are the issues I believe need addressing above all else. However, strengthening relationships with other nations and countries could help to fix some of the problems that I listen above. This could also help with the Brexit situation and give Britain peace of mind that other nations are with us and will agree and support us. So forming new alliances maybe would be a good idea for Britain.

proposition: The UK should implement legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity.
paragraph: I believe that legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity are not the most effective approach for addressing environmental challenges in the UK. While conserving biodiversity is important, rigid legal mandates may impose excessive burdens on businesses, landowners, and local communities, potentially hindering economic development and innovation. A more flexible, incentive-based strategy could yield better results by encouraging voluntary participation and fostering collaboration between government, industry, and conservation groups. Laws that are too prescriptive may also risk being poorly enforced or misaligned with evolving scientific insights and practical realities on the ground. Protecting the environment should be a priority, but it must be balanced with economic sustainability and practical governance. I am concerned that binding targets may prove inflexible and counterproductive, preventing more adaptive and cooperative solutions.

proposition: The UK should implement legally binding targets for protecting biodiversity.
paragraph: I do not agree with this statement because I think there is too much advertising and information surrounding this issue. And I believe that we have other issues to address such as cost of living, NHS and the levels of immigration. Therefore, I do not think there should be legally binding targets as this issues is useless and we should sort out the issues for now.  Also, silly activists take this issue too seriously and cause too much trouble and silliness. So I do not think any targets are needed as whatever is going to happen to the world is going to happen.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: "Focusing so heavily on 'gender diversity' feels unnecessary. People are inherently different, and trying to divide roles strictly by gender seems impractical. Society functioned fine before the proliferation of gender identities. Some jobs naturally align better with one gender—for instance, I’d have preferred a female midwife during childbirth, as certain roles feel more suited to one gender. Enforcing quotas risks unintended consequences and could lead us down a problematic path."

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory gender diversity quotas for all publicly listed companies.
paragraph: All this 'gender diversity' stuff is exhausting. We are all either a man or a woman. It's impossible to split roles and jobs and only accept people based solely on their 'imagined' gender. The world worked perfectly well before we had a hundred different genders. Also, some roles should be gender specific. For example, I would not have been comfortable with a male midwife when I was giving birth to my children so call me old fashioned but some jobs are more suited to one gender or another. It's the thin edge of the wedge if you go down this road and it will not end well.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: I believe the UK should defund the BBC because the current system is fundamentally unfair and the organization has failed to meet its core obligations. It's absurd that citizens are compelled to purchase a television license regardless of whether they actually watch BBC content or derive any value from their programming. This amounts to a forced subscription model that would be unacceptable in any other industry. Furthermore, the BBC has consistently failed to maintain the political impartiality that supposedly justifies its unique funding arrangement and public service mandate. When a publicly-funded broadcaster cannot deliver on its promise of balanced, unbiased reporting, it loses any legitimate claim to mandatory financial support from taxpayers. The license fee system is an outdated relic that forces people to subsidize content they may neither want nor trust.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: We are all forced into buying a T.V licence. That seems crazy to me in this day and age. The BBC should start having adverts and self fund through that, the same as the other mainstream channels. I pay for Netflix etc and when I go abroad I can still watch it. However, even though I pay for a licence, I cannot watch the BBC channels when I am abroad. How do they get away with that. I should be able to watch something that I pay for wherever and whenever I like. Also I think it's disgusting that people are criminalised for not getting a licence.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: I strongly oppose the idea that the UK should ban the consumption of meat. Such a ban would infringe on individual freedom and personal choice, key principles in a democratic society. People have diverse dietary needs, cultural traditions, and personal beliefs, many of which include meat as a central component. A blanket ban disregards these complexities and imposes a one-size-fits-all solution. Moreover, rather than focusing on prohibition, it would be far more productive to invest in sustainable farming practices and promote education about ethical and environmental food choices. Consumers should be empowered to make informed decisions, not coerced by legislation. Outright bans often lead to black markets and unintended consequences, rather than genuine progress. Supporting responsible meat consumption and innovation in food production is a more balanced and effective path forward.

proposition: The UK should ban the consumption of meat.
paragraph: As humans we are naturally Omnivores. We need a wide selection of foods to fuel our bodies. I don't think we would get enough nourishment to thrive if we didn't have meat. I enjoy eating meat and it is a large part of my diet, my whole family eat meat too. Why would we ban it, it doesn't make sense. Think of all the farms that would go out of business if they no longer produce meat. Many shops and restaurants would also be affected, Who wants to go out to dinner and eat plant based foods all the time.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: The proposition to make same-sex marriage illegal in the UK aligns with my belief that it is not morally, religiously, or naturally right. Morally, marriage should uphold traditional values that have long been the foundation of society, and altering this undermines the sanctity of the institution. Religiously, many faiths define marriage as a union between a man and a woman, and legalizing same-sex marriage contradicts these teachings, disregarding the spiritual significance of the bond. Naturally, marriage is rooted in the biological complementarity of men and women, which is essential for procreation and the continuity of the family unit. Allowing same-sex marriage disrupts this inherent design, promoting a lifestyle that strays from the natural order. For these reasons, I oppose the legalization of same-sex marriage and support maintaining the traditional definition of marriage as the cornerstone of a stable and morally grounded society.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: Same sex marriage is not morally or ethically right. Two men or women marrying each other ruins the whole ethos of marriage. Marriage is and always has been a sacred vow taken between a man and a woman committing to each other and in my eyes always will be. Two men or women marrying each other is not a natural act in my opinion and should not be permitted. The sanctity of marriage should not be taken lightly and the very fact that same sex couples can get married legally in this country is beyond a joke and should be stopped forthwith

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: I firmly believe the UK should implement mandatory COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens as a crucial public health measure. The overwhelming scientific evidence demonstrates that vaccines are safe, effective, and essential for protecting both individual health and collective welfare. A vaccination mandate would help achieve the high immunization rates necessary to prevent dangerous variants from emerging and protect vulnerable populations who cannot be vaccinated themselves. While I recognize concerns about personal freedom, public health emergencies require collective action, and vaccination mandates have proven successful historically in eliminating diseases like polio and measles. The government has a responsibility to protect its citizens' health and prevent healthcare system collapse. The benefits of mandatory vaccination—saving lives, reducing hospitalizations, and enabling society to return to normalcy—far outweigh the temporary restrictions on individual choice during this unprecedented global health crisis.

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: The vaccination should be mandatory unless there are other health issues to consider. People who were not vaccinated in my opinion acted selfishley. By being vaccinated it could help slow down the infection numbers and protect people from catching Covid or lessen the symptons if they did catch it. The death rate from Covid would then fall and also cut down the pressure on the NHS. By being vaccinated you would not only protect yourself but also others around you. To not get vaccinated in my opinion is a selfish act and if the choice was taken away and it was mandatory to be vaccinated a lot of deaths and hospitalisation of people could of been avoided

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: Modern warfare is increasingly dominated by drones and other remotely operated systems. This is the direction most countries are taking, and if we fail to adapt, we risk leaving ourselves vulnerable. Drone technology reduces the danger to human soldiers by placing machines in harm's way instead. It allows operators to be thousands of miles from the conflict while still exerting significant influence on the battlefield. With rapid advances in artificial intelligence, fully autonomous systems are on the horizon—capable of executing missions based solely on programmed instructions.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: Modern warfare will be fought primarily with drones and other forms of remote operated systems. It is the way most countries are heading and if we do not evolve with it we will leave ourselves vulnerable. Drone technology also puts a machine in harms way a lot more than a human. Drone technology allows an operator to be thousands of miles a way from the action but still have a huge impact on the battlefeild by the use of drone technology. Advances in AI will soon lead to fully autonomous systems that will require only a program input and then they will go off and do the task

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph: I am a Christian and proud of that, and I understand people will have mixed views on this subject, but these days it has become more acceptable to get married. However, I think in today’s society it’s all too easy to follow the pattern. My views are going to be different from other people’s, which I do understand. Sadly, I think it’s a sign of the times we live in, which are immoral and getting worse, and standards in this country are falling rapidly, creating so much upheaval. One day we will all be judged on how we have decided to live our lives.

proposition: The UK should make same-sex marriage illegal.
paragraph:
I am a Christian and proud of that and I understand people will have mixed views on this subject, but these days its become more acceptable to get married. but i think in todays society its all to easy to follow the pattern, my views are going to be different to other people which I do understand.
Sadly i think its a sign of the times we live in which is immoral and getting worse and standards in this country are falling rapidly which is creating so much upheaval and one day we will all be judged on how we have decided to live our lives.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all new cars sold be electric vehicles by 2030.
paragraph: I strongly support the UK's mandate for all new cars to be electric by 2030 because it represents a crucial step toward a healthier and more sustainable future. Electric vehicles will dramatically improve air quality in our cities and towns by eliminating harmful emissions from traditional combustion engines, creating cleaner environments for everyone to breathe. This transition directly benefits public health by reducing pollution-related respiratory diseases and other health complications that disproportionately affect urban communities. Beyond the environmental advantages, electric vehicles offer a superior driving experience with quiet operation, instant acceleration, and lower maintenance requirements, making them remarkably comfortable for daily use. Most importantly, this mandate positions the UK as a forward-thinking leader in the global shift toward sustainable transportation, ensuring we're building the infrastructure and adopting the technology that will define the automotive landscape for generations to come.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all new cars sold be electric vehicles by 2030.
paragraph:
especially in the world we live in its much better for the environment and will help to stop the atmosphere heating up.
Its also more healthy for us all as we don't have to breathe in dusty air as with cars currently polluting us all.
its also more comfortable to drive in as its electric and you don't really notice how quiet it is while your driving
with the future in mind its going to be safer for the next generation and wont create the hazards we have currently which 
will make our world much safer than it is right now.

proposition: The UK should implement a complete ban on single-use plastics.
paragraph: While I recognize the environmental harm caused by single-use plastics, I’m hesitant to support a complete ban in the UK at this time. Such a sweeping measure could place undue strain on businesses, particularly small enterprises, and disrupt supply chains that rely on affordable packaging alternatives. Transitioning away from plastics entirely requires viable, scalable substitutes, which may not yet be accessible or cost-effective for all industries. Instead, I believe a more balanced approach—such as stricter regulations, incentives for innovation in biodegradable materials, and targeted bans on the most harmful plastics—would be more practical and effective. This would allow for gradual adaptation while still addressing environmental concerns. A total ban risks backlash or noncompliance if implemented too abruptly, undermining its intended benefits. The focus should be on sustainable progress rather than an outright prohibition.

proposition: The UK should implement a complete ban on single-use plastics.
paragraph:
with single  use - plastics found frequently in the sea and rivers in this country and other parts of the world its extremely dangerous for the fish and other fish life as its been proved that they can get caught in nets which plastics that get into their habitat can create problems to them as they will get tangled and will eventually die due to suffocation.
this should not be allowed to continue as in time we will not have any sea creatures as they wont survive these hazards which is extremely sad and unnecessary and us should face the consequences.

proposition: The UK should withdraw its commitments to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.
paragraph: As a nation, we are often highly involved in global issues, generally for the better. While I am not an expert on sustainability, I believe we should do our part. However, we must also consider what other countries are contributing. How much impact can we truly have, and what is the cost to us? My concern is that our efforts may ultimately be a drop in the ocean. What are the world’s most populous nations doing in comparison? For instance, what role is China playing? Can our relatively small island really make a significant difference next to such global powers?

proposition: The UK should withdraw its commitments to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.
paragraph: As a nation, we are very good at getting involved in most concerns overseas, usually for the better. I am no expert on sustainability and we should do what we can. However, we need to look at what other nations are contributing. How much difference can we really make and how much is this all costing us? What concerns me is that our contribution is a drop in the ocean. What are the countries with the largest populations doing to contribute? for example, what about China? Does our small island really have that much on an impact in comparison to others?

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph: I strongly oppose the legalisation of marijuana for recreational use in the UK because, despite changing attitudes, cannabis remains a drug with potentially harmful effects. My primary concern is the impact on young people who should be focusing on their education and personal development. Introducing legal recreational marijuana could create additional distractions and impair their cognitive abilities during crucial study years, potentially affecting their academic performance and future prospects. We are already witnessing the negative health consequences of vaping among youth, and legalising another substance for recreational consumption would only compound these problems. Rather than expanding access to potentially harmful substances, we should be protecting our young people and promoting healthier lifestyle choices that support their wellbeing and educational success.

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph: I have never agreed with the need to legalise marijuana. Some may say that I am naïve, and that alcohol is in fact much worse. I have even heard the argument that sugar is worse. However, if we were to legalise marijuana, where would it stop? And why do we need to? The smell is putrid and just one big advert to our kids for drug use. Show me how this does not affect the brain long term. I have known smokers/users of it who were far too laid back for their own good and I believe this was due to being smokers of marijuana. It does not need to be legalised and openly smoked on our streets.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the production and distribution of pornography.
paragraph: I believe the UK should implement stricter regulations on the production and distribution of pornography to address concerns about exploitation, ethical standards, and the potential harm to vulnerable individuals. While I support personal freedoms and recognize that adults should have access to legal content, the industry often operates with insufficient oversight, leading to abuses and unsafe working conditions. Stricter regulations could ensure better protections for performers, enforce age verification to prevent underage access, and promote responsible consumption. However, these measures should be balanced to avoid overreach or unnecessary censorship, respecting the rights of consenting adults. The goal should be to create a safer, more ethical framework that mitigates harm without infringing on personal liberties. Thoughtful regulation can help uphold dignity and safety while maintaining a reasonable space for lawful expression.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the production and distribution of pornography.
paragraph: The landscape for pornography has changed dramatically due to the internet and the shareability. Because of this, there must be stricter regulations. Younger audiences are now finding it much easier to not only access this content, but to be served the content through social media. Who is regulating this? Nobody it would appear. OnlyFans has completely turned everything on its head for the worse. The money some of the creators make via this platform is demonstrating to young people that they can not only get access to any content they want, at any time, but they can also ask people to do things on these platforms.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph: While fostering a sense of national identity can be valuable, implementing mandatory patriotism education in UK schools is not the right approach. Patriotism can already be encouraged through existing subjects such as history, literature, and civics, where students learn about the country’s values, achievements, and challenges in a nuanced way. Making patriotism a compulsory focus risks crossing a line into nationalism, which can stifle critical thinking and open dialogue. Education should aim to develop independent thinkers who can engage with their country's past and present critically and constructively. Mandating patriotism may lead to one-sided narratives, marginalize diverse perspectives, and undermine the democratic values that form the core of a healthy society. Encouraging genuine appreciation for the UK should come from an understanding of its complexities, not from enforced loyalty.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph: I somewhat disagree with the idea of mandatory patriotism education in schools. While fostering a sense of national pride is valuable, making such education compulsory risks encouraging uncritical nationalism rather than thoughtful appreciation of one’s country. Schools should prioritize teaching diversity, inclusion, and global awareness to prepare students for a multicultural society. Patriotism can be encouraged through existing subjects like history and civics without the need for a separate mandatory program. It’s important that students develop their own perspectives and learn to respect different viewpoints alongside a healthy sense of national identity. For me i think its not the best idea.

proposition: The UK should withdraw its commitments to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.
paragraph: I believe the UK should maintain its commitments to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals as they represent a crucial framework for addressing the world's most pressing challenges. These goals tackle issues like poverty, inequality, climate change, and environmental degradation that transcend national borders and require coordinated international action. The UK has historically played an important leadership role in global development and sustainability efforts, and withdrawing from these commitments would undermine both its international reputation and moral standing. The SDGs also align with domestic priorities around building a sustainable economy, improving public health, and ensuring long-term prosperity. Rather than retreating from these obligations, the UK should strengthen its engagement and use its influence to drive progress on these vital global objectives that ultimately benefit both British citizens and the international community.

proposition: The UK should withdraw its commitments to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.
paragraph: I strongly disagree that the UK should withdraw from the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals. These goals serve as an essential roadmap for tackling pressing global challenges such as poverty, climate change, and social inequality. As a major world power, the UK has a responsibility to contribute to international efforts that promote sustainability and fairness. Abandoning these commitments would not only damage the UK's reputation but also hinder progress on environmental protection and social justice initiatives that are vital for the well being of future generations. Furthermore, the SDGs encourage sustainable economic growth, which benefits the UK’s economy by fostering innovation and green technologies. Staying committed to the SDGs aligns with both moral and practical interests.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: Mandating ESG policies for all UK publicly traded companies is a step I strongly support. These standards ensure businesses evaluate their environmental, social, and governance impacts, fostering accountability and uniformity across industries. A mandatory framework would level the playing field, boost investor confidence in sustainable practices, and enhance public trust. Over time, ESG adherence can stabilize operations, promote ethical decision-making, and tackle systemic issues like climate change and inequality. Such policies benefit both society and businesses, proving that responsible practices align with long-term success. The broader advantages far outweigh any perceived burdens.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: I strongly agree that the UK should mandate ESG policies for all publicly traded companies. ESG standards help ensure that companies consider their impact on the environment, society, and their internal governance practices. Making these policies mandatory would create a level playing field, holding all companies to the same expectations and encouraging accountability. It would also build public trust and attract investors who value ethical and sustainable practices. In the long term, ESG compliance can lead to more stable and responsible business operations while helping address major challenges like climate change and social inequality. These policies are not just good for society they make smart business sense too.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to limit the influence of woke culture in public institutions.
paragraph: I have significant concerns about implementing policies specifically designed to limit what is broadly termed "woke culture" in public institutions. While I believe in maintaining balanced perspectives and avoiding ideological extremes in public services, I worry that such targeted policies could undermine important progress on equality and inclusion. The term "woke culture" itself is often applied too broadly, potentially encompassing legitimate efforts to address historical inequities and promote fairness. Rather than blanket restrictions, I would prefer approaches that ensure public institutions remain professional and serve all citizens effectively, while still allowing space for ongoing conversations about social justice and reform. Heavy-handed policy interventions risk creating unnecessary culture wars and could inadvertently suppress valuable discussions about how to make our institutions more equitable and representative of diverse perspectives.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to limit the influence of woke culture in public institutions.
paragraph: Woke as a term can mean many things to many people. If you are anti racist does that make you woke? If you believe in freedom of speech does that make you woke? The real issue here is that extremism has crept into everyday life. Whether it is from the left or the right. Nobody seems to be able to hold a point of view that is acceptable to both sides. I can see good things from both right and left of centre but nowadays you have to be one or the other. Life isn't black or white there will always be grey areas. Our public institutions can continue to be fair but there central role is to serve the public not police them. I think many of them forget the role of public servant which even with a basic knowledge of English can be interpreted as serve the public. That means all the public regardless of what your personal views are.

proposition: The UK should increase funding and resources for the police force.
