There are many factories throughout this industry that would be negatively impacted by this statement and many people would be out of a job that they may have trained in and worked in for a long time. Also, nuclear energy is somewhat reliable and I would be concerned that moving away from this to more renewable energy sources would be slightly risky.

Despite this, I do agree with the statement above and believe it would be a positive thing for the UK if nuclear energy was reduced rather than completely phased out. The main positive being that it's better for the environment. There will be less toxic waste and fumes being released from this. Also, more renewable energy sources can be used such as solar and wind. Finally, these factories can sometimes be an eye sore so this would help to reduce that.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming because it would encourage more people to engage with and promote this sustainable practice. By providing monetary support, the government can incentivize farmers to adopt methods that sequester carbon, such as agroforestry or cover cropping, which would ultimately benefit the environment by mitigating climate change. Additionally, these incentives would provide farmers with an alternative income stream, helping to stabilise their finances while contributing to a greener economy. The combination of environmental benefits and economic support for farmers makes this a worthwhile investment. It aligns agricultural practices with climate goals, fostering a more sustainable future while ensuring the farming community remains resilient. Financial incentives would thus serve as a practical and impactful way to advance carbon farming, delivering long-term ecological and economic rewards.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph:
I agree with the statement above that "The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming". One reason being the financial incentives. This financial compensation will help to reach a wider demographic and encourage them to learn about and support the cause. Also, it would have benefits to the environment such as fighting climate change. Extra support to carbon farming could encourage the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The final reason I support this statement is because it will lead to an increase in revenue for farmers and the farming industry.

However, the reason I don't fully support this statement is because I think some people would only support the cause to gain the benefits of the financial incentives. People may agree to the cause without carrying out any research themselves.

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: Mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens in the UK is a necessary step to protect public health and ensure collective well-being. Vaccines have proven to be highly effective in reducing severe illness, hospitalizations, and deaths, making them a critical tool in ending the pandemic. A mandate would help achieve widespread immunity, safeguarding vulnerable populations and easing the burden on healthcare systems. While individual freedoms are important, the greater good must take precedence in a public health crisis. Exceptions can be made for those with legitimate medical exemptions, but the vast majority of eligible individuals should contribute to herd immunity. The success of vaccination programs in curbing the spread of the virus demonstrates their value, and a mandate would reinforce this progress. Ultimately, it’s a responsible measure to save lives and restore normalcy.

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: The UK should mandate COVID-9 vaccinations as this would help reduce the amount of people suffering the effects of COVID-19, with an emphasis on hospitalisations. The NHS is still recovering from the height of the pandemic and unrelated setbacks, showcasing the importance of vaccinations to relieve some stress. Other vaccinations are mandated in the UK already thus it is proven to be possible. This would not only help the individual receiving the vaccine, but also those around, especially those who cannot have the vaccine who already deal with issues of immune disorders. COVID-19 is not of the past but is still prevalent, especially during the winter months.

proposition: The UK should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions.
paragraph: I support strengthening the rights and powers of labour unions in the UK because they serve as essential guardians of worker welfare across multiple critical areas. Unions play a vital role in ensuring fair treatment for all employees, actively combating age discrimination and other forms of workplace bias that can otherwise go unchecked. They are instrumental in negotiating fair wages and reasonable working hours, helping to prevent worker exploitation and ensuring that employees receive compensation that reflects their contributions. Perhaps most importantly, unions serve as powerful advocates for health and safety standards, pushing employers to maintain safe working conditions and holding them accountable when they fall short. By strengthening union rights and powers, the UK would better protect workers from unfair practices while promoting more equitable and safer workplaces across all industries.

proposition: The UK should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions.
paragraph: The U.K should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions in order to ensure that the health and safety standards of workplaces are regulated through enforcements of codes such as proper PPE. Furthermore, labour unions keep companies in line when it comes to paying minimum wage and not setting unlawful hours for workers. Not only this but also allowing adequate sick leave and holidays throughout the year. Additionally, with limited powers labour unions are not able to enforce rights for workers when it comes to discrimination either within the workplace or upon recruitment or redundancy. Overall it is clear that labour unions are vital to the workforce and strengthening their rights and powers would serve to aid in the safety and security for workers and their families.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all new cars sold be electric vehicles by 2030.
paragraph: The UK should not mandate all new cars to be electric by 2030 as the necessary infrastructure and long-term support are not yet sufficient. Although electric vehicles have higher upfront costs compared to petrol or diesel cars, they offer lower running costs, making them more economical over time. However, the number of charging stations is currently much lower than that of petrol stations, requiring more careful journey planning. That said, a mandate could encourage the expansion of charging infrastructure. Additionally, concerns remain over the environmental impact of electric vehicle batteries, which are not recyclable, and their production often involves poor safety conditions for workers, especially as demand increases.

proposition: The UK should mandate that all new cars sold be electric vehicles by 2030.
paragraph: The UK should not mandate all new cars to be electric as the foundations and long term support is not yet available. Whilst the upfront cost of electric vehicles is more than petrol or diesel, the running costs are less meaning long term they are more cost effective. However, there are significantly less charging ports available than petrol stations so planning a journey around them is more important. Though if this is to be mandated the probability of more being installed increases. Furthermore, the battery of electric vehicles is an environmental concern as it is not recyclable and the production of them sees little safety for the workers, especially due to the increasing volume of electric vehicles.

proposition: The UK should ban internet use for under-14-year-olds.
paragraph: I believe that banning internet use for children under 14 would be a beneficial policy that prioritizes their healthy development and safety. Young children are particularly vulnerable to online risks including cyberbullying, exposure to inappropriate content, and predatory behavior, while lacking the cognitive maturity to navigate these dangers effectively. The constant stimulation and instant gratification of internet use can also interfere with crucial developmental processes like attention span building, face-to-face social skills, and genuine creative play. A ban would encourage children to engage more meaningfully with the physical world, develop deeper relationships with family and peers, and focus on foundational learning without digital distractions. While the internet offers educational benefits, these can be accessed through supervised, structured environments rather than unrestricted personal use, ensuring children gain digital literacy at an age-appropriate pace.

proposition: The UK should ban internet use for under-14-year-olds.
paragraph:
I feel that a ban on internet for kids under the age of 14 will have fundamentally positive impacts on their childhood with very little downside. Firstly, without social media, kids will be forced to use other avenues to socialise with their peers, reducing their reliance on instagram, and other social media platforms that allow them to skirt away from face to face interactions. In the digital age, and the rise in social media usage by the younger generations, has started having an impact on their social skills when face to face, and this is most likley in part due to their over reliance to use text based, emoji based communications rather than speak face to face or even via voice calls. reducing text based messaging and 'tiktok/reel' based communication could have a positive impact on their ability to express themselves and carry themselves in social situations. 

Secondly, removing socialmedia will prevent addiction cycles of doom scrolling and endless dopamine releases from just watching reels continuously. Which will be good for their brains and development. 
Lastly, no social internet access will prevent them from having exposure to harmful and radicalising websites and influencers, for exaple 4 chan, certain reddit threads, twitter and the sort. Or even bad infleuncing youtubers/streamers. This could allow the kids to grow up without a significant amount of influence which we now have today.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph: The UK should ban military drone technology because it makes engaging in war dangerously effortless by removing the human cost for military operations. When armed forces no longer risk lives, the threshold for initiating conflict lowers, potentially leading to more frequent and reckless use of military force. Additionally, such a ban is crucial to setting a global precedent; if the UK takes a stand, other nations may follow, reducing the widespread adoption of drone warfare. The unchecked proliferation of this technology increases the likelihood of public harm, as remote warfare can lead to disproportionate strikes, civilian casualties, and destabilized regions. By prohibiting military drones, the UK would prioritize ethical warfare and discourage the normalization of detached, high-risk combat that endangers global security and innocent lives.

proposition: The UK should ban the use of military drone technology.
paragraph:
Assuming we're talkin gabout military drones as in, drones that go to war and can carry out bombings or shootings.
I think UK should somewhat ban the use of military drone technology unless absolutely necessary. This is because, where there is no risk to soldiers, it allows us to get carried away and make decisions that aren't as thought out, this becomes problematic as civilians in those countries could be harmed or killed, we could have incorrect intel and we didn't verify as we're not as worried about the decision making as we should be, because we think no one on our side is going to be hurt.

Additionally,if we carry out acts in such way, it gives others a license to also act this way, which can lead to civillians in the UK be put in harms way in equally as not thought out plans, because again, the threshold for war is much lower.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph:
Mandatory diversity training is often introduced with the intention of fostering understanding and compassion between people of different backgrounds—whether related to disability, religion, or culture. The aim is to promote unity through increased awareness. However, you cannot mandate genuine empathy through legal requirements. This brings me to my next point: such training often breeds resentment between groups, rather than nurturing mutual respect. True compassion must be cultivated through positive emotions and organic experiences, not imposed rules. Mandatory inclusion training can feel like being told, “You will care after doing this tedious task,” which often leads to negative reactions instead of positive growth.

Furthermore, many people treat it as a mere checkbox exercise—something to sit through rather than engage with meaningfully. As a result, it neither promotes understanding nor changes behavior. Often, it subconsciously reinforces division or disengagement. A more effective approach is leading by example. For instance, when Mohamed Salah played for Liverpool FC, data showed a noticeable decline in Islamophobic and anti-Middle Eastern sentiment, illustrating how visibility and personal connection can subtly but powerfully shift attitudes.

proposition: The UK should require employers to implement mandatory diversity and inclusion training for all employees.
paragraph:
The reason for carrying out mandatory diversity training is to help cultures learn about each other, learn about other people from different walks of lives, be it disablity, to religious and cultural differences. The goal is to build compassion and understanding between different people in hopes it helps create unity. You cannot do that by legally mandating someone to be compassionate. This leads me onto my second point(technically third point), all it does is create resentment between groups rather than allowing for a nurturing understanding bteween them. In order to have compassion, and understanding you have to nurture it with love and positive emotions, the concept of a forced and mandatory diversity training and inclusion is akin to saying "you will love me after you do this really annoying thing" rather than have a good impact it has a negative one instead. 

Lastly, people will and do treat it as a simple checkbox exercise, that they need to complete, people don't really pay attention and just want to get it over with. So alongside it building resentment subsconsciously, it also doesn't actually build any understanding. Using positive examples is much better, for example, when Salah played for Liverpool FC, racism dropped significantly towards asians and middle easterns, and especially towards people of Muslim faith.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: I believe the UK should not abolish existing gender pay equality legislation because there are still significant disparities between genders that need to be actively addressed. These laws play a crucial role in promoting fairness and ensuring that individuals are paid equitably for equal work, regardless of gender. Removing such protections would risk reversing the progress that has been made over the years and could widen the existing pay gap. Rather than reducing the resources or focus on gender pay equality, we should be working to strengthen and enforce these measures to create a more just and inclusive workforce. Without them, the structural inequalities that lead to unequal pay are likely to persist or even worsen.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: Overall abolishing gender equality legislation would set up a step back compared to all of the progress we have made as a country. Gender equality is something that affects any country and requires extensive legislation to protect women in their personal life lives but also in the workplace. This protection usually comes as legislation and it is usually greatly beneficial for women. I think abolishing that legislation would leave women at a disadvantage again and would not help at all. I believe that legislation should be kept at all costs and even be revised to include every woman no matter where they are.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: The UK should consider reducing funding for its intelligence agencies to better balance security needs with other critical public services. While these agencies play a vital role in national security, there is room to streamline operations and prioritize efficiency without compromising safety. Overfunding can lead to bloated bureaucracies or unnecessary surveillance, which may erode public trust. Redirecting some resources to areas like healthcare, education, or social welfare could address pressing societal issues while maintaining adequate security. However, any cuts must be carefully calibrated to ensure the UK remains resilient against threats. A measured approach would allow for smarter spending, focusing on high-impact intelligence activities rather than blanket funding increases. Transparency and oversight should accompany any adjustments to ensure accountability and public confidence in how these agencies operate.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for its intelligence agencies.
paragraph: I would be in favour of keeping the budget the same and not decreasing it but I am very against increasing the intelligence budget, when there are other issues more prominent in the UK. These issues include housing cost of living crisis, university bankruptcies and council bankruptcies. I think they do a fantastic job however they are fine with the budget they have and I’m sure they would be fine on a lower budget if that money goes to an aspect that needs it. This could be used in giving housing benefits or free meals in schools, which I believe is a more pressing issue.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase its foreign aid budget for combating global hunger.
paragraph: Global hunger affects millions worldwide, transcending national boundaries and alliances. Every day, countless people die from starvation, particularly in developing nations where resources are scarce. I believe addressing this crisis represents a fundamental humanitarian obligation that the UK should prioritize through substantial resource allocation. Even though Britain may not face immediate food insecurity, demonstrating compassion and solidarity reflects our shared humanity and builds goodwill that could prove valuable if circumstances change. Current funding levels are demonstrably insufficient to tackle the scale of global hunger, making increased investment both morally imperative and strategically wise for our nation's international standing.

proposition: The UK should significantly increase its foreign aid budget for combating global hunger.
paragraph: Global hunger not only affects the UK but other ally and non allied countries. People die every second of hunger and specially in underdeveloped countries. I believe this is a major humanitarian issue that the UK should put a lot of resources into. Even if it doesn’t affect the UK in a major level it is good to practice empathy and give to others just in case one day we are in the same situation as those today. Overall I think we should increase the funding given to those causes as it is currently not enough to combat world hunger.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to actively discourage nationalism in all forms.
paragraph:
Potential restriction of freedom of speech – UK policies aimed at actively discouraging all forms of nationalism could be seen as an overreach of governmental power and a violation of individuals’ rights to freely express their views.

Sovereignty – Nationalism can foster a sense of autonomy, allowing nations to govern themselves and maintain national sovereignty. It can also play a role in encouraging citizens to engage in democratic processes and civic participation.

UK national pride and identity – Nationalism in the UK may provide a sense of pride and identity for many people. Suppressing this expression could be viewed as an attack on cultural heritage. It is important to find a balance between fostering national identity and embracing a global perspective.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to actively discourage nationalism in all forms.
paragraph:
Potential to restrict freedom of speech- The Uk policies aimed directed to discouraging nationalism in all forms could be deemed as excessive use of power/violating the rights of individuals to freely express themselves.

Sovereignty- This can encourage independence, allowing nations decide themselves, also it is important for maintaining the national sovereignty, it can encourage citizens to participate in democratic processes. 

The UK National pride and identity- The UK nationalism could provide pride and identity to many people, not allowing this to be enacted is likley to be seen as an attack on the cultural heritage, identifying a balance between promoting national pride and identity and promoting global identity is necessary.

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph: I oppose the legalization of marijuana for recreational use in the UK due to significant concerns about public welfare and safety. The health risks associated with cannabis use, including potential respiratory problems, mental health issues, and dependency, present serious medical concerns that could burden our healthcare system. I am particularly worried about the impact on youth and vulnerable populations, as easier access could lead to increased usage among adolescents whose developing brains are especially susceptible to harm. Additionally, legalization raises critical public safety issues, including impaired driving and workplace safety concerns, as we currently lack adequate infrastructure to effectively monitor and prevent cannabis-impaired activities. These combined factors suggest that the potential societal costs of legalization outweigh any proposed benefits, making it an unwise policy decision for the UK at this time.

proposition: The UK should legalise marijuana for recreational use.
paragraph:
-Health risks involved;The use of marijuana for recreational use posses serious health concerns as it potentially affects and impacts on the mental health and cognitive health of individuals. This could potentially increase terminal illnesses as well as death rates of the nation. 
-Impact on youth and vulnerable groups;  This could potentially increase the access of marijuana for minors and in turn impact on the health of the vulnerable population or groups. This could also encourage erratic behaviour  which is commonly one of the side effects of the use of marijuana.
-Safety of the public; The use of marijuana could bring about serious public safety concerns. The risks of driving under the influence of marijuana could result in unwanted accidents and threats to live of the public, also concerns about workplace safety could arise as a result of the use of marijuana.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph: The UK should absolutely implement financial incentives to promote carbon farming, as it presents a practical and sustainable solution to combat climate change while supporting the agricultural sector. Carbon farming not only reduces greenhouse gas emissions but also enhances soil health, biodiversity, and long-term agricultural productivity. By offering financial support, the government can encourage farmers to adopt these practices, which might otherwise seem risky or unprofitable in the short term. This approach aligns with the UK’s climate commitments and demonstrates leadership in environmental stewardship. Additionally, it fosters innovation in sustainable agriculture, creating jobs and economic opportunities in rural areas. The benefits extend beyond the environment, strengthening food security and resilience against climate impacts. While challenges like monitoring and implementation exist, the potential rewards make this a worthwhile investment in the nation’s future. Proactive policies like this are essential for a just and effective transition to a greener economy.

proposition: The UK should offer financial incentives to support carbon farming.
paragraph:
Economic benefits- Financial incentives can be beneficial in supporting farmers by  means of adopting sustainable practices that could potential improve their ability to withstand major economic challenges. Moreover promoting sustainable agricultural practices can assist in reducing carbon emissions in the UK.  
Bio-diversity- The incentives to support Carbon farming could support biodiversity by promoting and encouraging habitat  restoration which is essential in ecosystems services,  this well help to promote and maintain healthy and productive agricultural system. 
The Soil health- The financial incentives could help to promote practices the help boost soil health such as regenerative agriculture and reduced soil tillage. Soil health is very crucial for sustainable agriculture, by maintaining optimal soil health this will help to support plant growth and in the long run crop yields.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: I believe it is essential for the UK to implement policies that protect and promote religious freedoms for Muslim communities. In a diverse and democratic society, safeguarding the rights of all religious groups ensures social cohesion and mutual respect. Muslim communities, like all others, should be able to practice their faith freely without fear of discrimination or prejudice. Protecting religious freedoms not only upholds fundamental human rights but also reinforces the UK's commitment to equality and inclusion. Given the challenges faced by some Muslim individuals in public life, education, and employment, proactive measures can help address systemic barriers and foster a more inclusive society. By promoting understanding and supporting religious expression, the UK strengthens its social fabric and celebrates its multicultural identity.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to ensure the protection and promotion of religious freedoms for Muslim communities.
paragraph: Every community in the UK should feel safe and secure and if that means that the UK needs to implement policies that not only protect muslims but also allow freedom to practice their beliefs should be a given right. this is a basic human rights that the UK should adhere to and protect minorities such as muslims to feel more welcomed and part of the UK. muslims contribute to the society especially in the healthcare sector and as a result the UK should lead by example and protect its community to enhance cohesion and tolerance within our communities. UK media has enhance hatred to muslim communities and thus the government should protect them.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: The BBC should be defunded because it has become a biased institution that fails to serve the British public fairly. Rather than providing balanced reporting and programming, the corporation consistently demonstrates clear editorial slants that favor particular political viewpoints while marginalizing others. This bias undermines its credibility as a public service broadcaster and betrays the trust of license fee payers. Furthermore, the BBC's content, perspectives, and staffing do not adequately represent the diverse views and demographics of the UK population. The programming and editorial decisions reflect a narrow subset of British society, leaving many citizens feeling excluded and unheard. When a publicly funded broadcaster fails to maintain impartiality and representativeness, it cannot justify continued taxpayer support. These fundamental failures in its core mission make defunding the appropriate response.

proposition: The UK should defund the BBC.
paragraph: I feel sometimes the BBC does not report accurately news from all over the world and sometimes it feels biased in terms of who they are supporting at the given time, and when they get a bit of backlash they will start reporting unbiasedly. I have noticed that sometimes they do not even cover a certain topic. I think the BBC should represent what the people in UK believe in and not just the majority but also the minorities to give different aspects. It feels as if they only cover certain aspects of news or documentaries depending on what the producers believe in or who fund them.

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: "Addressing global warming is complex, requiring cooperation from all nations, yet this is challenging, especially in developing countries that often rely on polluting fuels. The UK’s contribution to global warming is relatively small compared to others, so its impact within the Paris Agreement is limited. Larger emitters face less strict rules, and the UK’s role in driving climate change remains debatable, reducing the agreement’s overall efficacy."

proposition: The UK should withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.
paragraph: it feels like to tackle global warming is a complex matter and to achieve it all countries around the world have to cooperate and deal with it but that is hard especially in developing countries where they have no choice but to use fuel that potentially leads to global warming. the UK does not contribute much to global warming compared to other countries so even if they stayed in this agreement their efficacy is low because other countries contribute more to greenhouse gasses need to have more stricter rules and the evidence that it contributes a lot to global warming is debatable.

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: "The current retirement age was promised to those now approaching it, and they have worked hard to earn that benefit. Older individuals often face declining mobility and health issues, making them less efficient at work while requiring more time and resources to manage their well-being, necessitating earlier retirement. Increasing the pension age would exacerbate inequality, as poorer individuals—who must work relentlessly to afford basics—rely on retirement to survive, unlike the wealthy, who can retire at will. Moreover, it’s unnecessary, as companies benefit more from younger workers."

proposition: The UK should increase the state pension age.
paragraph: The current age to retire is what was promised to people getting closer to it now and they have worked hard to achieve that benefit, elder people have less body mobility and start experiencing health problems along with old age so not only they would be less eficient at work but they would need more time and money to address their health issuesm which is why that kind of people need to retire soon. I think it would only increase inequality because it is poor and disadvantaged people that have to work no matter the circumstances to just afford the basic supplies, the poorer are conditioned to work until they retire to survive afterwards, this does not happen with wealthy people that might quit their jobs any time because they don't have economic problems. Also, it is an unnecessary action, companies need younger workers.

proposition: The UK should abolish the monarchy.
paragraph: The UK should abolish the monarchy because it represents an outdated and inefficient institution that no longer aligns with the principles of a modern democratic society. The monarchy relies on public funding, yet its role is largely ceremonial, offering little practical value in governance. Many countries around the world function successfully without a monarchy, demonstrating that a republic can effectively uphold democratic values while eliminating hereditary privilege. Upholding the monarchy simply because it is a long-standing tradition is not a compelling reason to maintain it. Societal and political systems should evolve based on rational considerations, not merely historical precedent. Retaining a system based on birthright undermines the ideals of equality and meritocracy. It is time for the UK to move forward by embracing a more democratic and contemporary approach to leadership, where positions of power and influence are earned rather than inherited.

proposition: The UK should abolish the monarchy.
paragraph: All of my bullet points are linked in the sense that we see other countries with similarities in economy and education to the UK that don't need monarchy to function correctly so why does it still exist in the UK? Yes I know the division of powers might differ in those contries but the same could happen here, it feels like having so many people in monarchy being supported by tax payers is worse than just having to support with taxes a few skilled workers that take their places like in normal democracies. Finally, it is just an old dusty tradition that came out of unrealistic beliefs and based on faith, why would somebody be privileged just because they were born in a golden house?

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: I have a cautiously optimistic view on the UK transitioning to 100% renewable energy by 2030. While I recognize the urgent need to address climate change and support the move toward cleaner energy sources, I have some reservations about the feasibility of achieving this goal within such a tight timeframe. The benefits are clear: reduced carbon emissions, energy independence, and potential economic opportunities in green technology sectors. However, I'm concerned about the practical challenges involved, including the massive infrastructure overhaul required, potential impacts on energy security during the transition, and the economic costs that could affect households and businesses. The 2030 target feels ambitious, perhaps overly so, and I wonder if a slightly more gradual approach might be more realistic while still demonstrating strong commitment to environmental goals.

proposition: The UK should transition to 100% renewable energy by 2030.
paragraph: I agree that the UK should transition to 100 renewable energies for the enviroment and to avoid depending on other countries's resources. I consider that by  2030 is too soon and unrealistic. The first point is that we depend on fossil fuels for many tasks that are part of everyday life so replacing them would not only be hard but it would take a long time and somethimes help from the government for the average citizen to be part of it. I mean, cars would be one of the first thing I can think of, to change the petrol thousands of houses would need to replace their vehicles, that involves costs. Also, energy chargers would need to be as frequent as gas station, this leads me to the psicological factor, people need to be convinced that depending on renewable energies would not affect their lifes, maybe even make them easier.

proposition: The UK should abolish all policies aimed at increasing diversity in the workplace.
paragraph: I believe that diversity policies in the workplace serve an important function in promoting equality, inclusivity, and fair opportunity for all individuals, regardless of their background. While these policies may not be perfect and can sometimes stir debate, abolishing them entirely would risk undoing progress made toward a more representative and balanced workforce. It's crucial to recognize that systemic barriers still exist, and targeted initiatives can help address unconscious bias and create environments where a range of perspectives are valued. Abolishing diversity policies would likely lead to a less inclusive society and reduce access to opportunities for underrepresented groups. Instead of elimination, thoughtful reform and evaluation can ensure these policies are effective and equitable, fostering meritocracy while actively working against discrimination.

proposition: The UK should abolish all policies aimed at increasing diversity in the workplace.
paragraph: I believe in diversity policies as in brings different perspectives to the workplace and helps mitigate people getting discriminated against unfairly, however what I am strongly against is it coming above merit, a recruiter and company should always pick the best pick for the job, and not source looking for specific demographics as this will always result to failure and the wrong people being hired, the ideal approach is to ensure equal opportunities for all while selection the most qualified for the role. this will naturally create a wealth of experience and diversity and as long as the recruitment process is fair protect the company from being accused of any unfair practices.

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph: The UK should protect employees from dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance, particularly when it involves expressing opinions that challenge government narratives on issues like Ukraine or COVID-19. People should not face undue harshness for their personal views, as long as they are not harmful or disruptive to the workplace. However, there must be clear boundaries: promoting hate speech, extremism, or inciting violence justifies dismissal, as such behavior can seriously harm colleagues or damage the company’s reputation. Balancing free expression with accountability is key—employees should feel safe to voice opinions without fear of retribution, but not at the expense of fostering a safe and respectful work environment. The focus should remain on job-related conduct while addressing genuine risks posed by extreme or dangerous rhetoric.

proposition: The UK should protect employees from workplace dismissal due to social media backlash unrelated to their job performance.
paragraph:
I believe people should be protected for most social media post, especially when it falls under the freedom of speech,
good examples would be when people have went against the government narrative on topical issues such as Ukraine and covid, however when it constitutes as being a crime such as hate speech, extremism or inciting violence then they should not be protected as this could massively effect colleagues and the actual company itself, potentially bringing its reputation into disrepute or worse becoming a target to attacks, also the potential financial repercussions could be huge, for example a company could lose most of its customers if the company was attached to people with extremist view.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: The government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services, as this reflects the technological demands of our era and ensures the UK remains competitive globally. Any initiatives that enhance efficiency deserve serious consideration; however, implementation must be conducted safely and systematically, without compromising security or quality through hasty execution. Technologies like blockchain exemplify how digital solutions can deliver greater transparency and speed in government operations. While transformation is essential, it should complement rather than overshadow other critical policy priorities, and I believe the government should begin this comprehensive modernization process without delay.

proposition: The UK government should prioritize and accelerate digital transformation across all public services.
paragraph: The government should certainly prioritise and accelerate digital transformation across all services, as this is the times we live in and the UK government can simply not fall behind the curve, anything which equates to more efficiency should always be considered, however it has to always be mandated and observed in a safe manner, corners cant be cut due to rushing to achieve this, blockchain and its many applications is a good example on how to make everything more transparent and faster, I don't think prioritization should come at the expensive of important issues though, I would like to see the government start transformation soon.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to actively discourage nationalism in all forms.
paragraph: Nationalism, while often framed as patriotic pride, can foster exclusionary attitudes that promote discrimination and racism. When national identity is prioritized in a way that elevates one group over others, it creates divisions that marginalize individuals who don't neatly fit into that identity, particularly immigrants and new nationals. These individuals may struggle to feel a true sense of belonging when nationalistic rhetoric implies they are outsiders. Such an environment can erode social cohesion, increase tensions between communities, and hinder the formation of a diverse and inclusive society. By actively discouraging nationalism in all its forms, the UK can take steps toward cultivating a culture that values equality, respects differences, and embraces all residents as integral members of the nation regardless of their origin. This not only benefits individuals but ultimately strengthens the country as a whole by fostering unity rather than division.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to actively discourage nationalism in all forms.
paragraph: I believe nationalism often promotes a sense of 'us' and 'them which will alienates immigrant communities even if they are naturalised citizens. This is because there is often clear messaging that 'we are better than others' and it creates conflict for immigrant communities where they have to choose their side. Additionally, it can promote racism as there can be a stereotyped look of a 'British person' and anyone who looks different is the 'other'. On the other hand, I did not score 'Strongly agree' because I think that there does need to be a sense of national pride but it needs to be monitored and modulated appropriately.

proposition: The UK should implement a complete ban on single-use plastics.
paragraph: The UK should ban all single-use plastics due to their harmful effects on the environment, including polluting landfills domestically and abroad, contaminating oceans, and damaging vital ecosystems. The shift away from plastic poses minimal downsides, as recyclable paper is often cheaper and more versatile. While some may prefer plastic for convenience, this minor inconvenience is outweighed by the environmental benefits. Overall, there are no significant drawbacks to eliminating single-use plastics.

proposition: The UK should implement a complete ban on single-use plastics.
paragraph: The Uk should ban all single use plastics because plastics have detrimental impacts on our environment from filling landfill both in the UK and other countries, filling our oceans and harming essential ecosystems and also creates additional waste. There is not really any real disadvantage to reducing this not even cost as paper which is recyclable is often cheaper than plastic and can be reformed into many products once recycled. There doesn't seem to be any real disadvantages of moving away from plastic. Some people may however feel that they do not enjoy using paper products as much but that is a small price to pay.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: I have a cautiously supportive view of implementing stricter regulations on violent video game sales to minors in the UK. While I recognize the existing age rating systems already provide some guidance, there may be room for improvement in enforcement and ensuring these games don't reach younger audiences inappropriately. I'm somewhat concerned about potential negative effects of violent content on developing minds, though I acknowledge the research on this remains mixed and debated. At the same time, I value parental responsibility and don't want overly heavy-handed government intervention that might infringe on creative expression or adult freedoms. My position leans toward supporting modest regulatory enhancements that better protect children while preserving reasonable access for appropriate age groups, rather than dramatic restrictions that could be seen as censorship.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: There is evidence based research to indicate that violence based video games can promote violent behaviour in minors as it enables them to out the violence in the game and can also deteriorate their mental health. This would have long lasting negative consequences for the minor as they progress into their adult life. On the other hand, children in the 90's for example grew up with fairly violent cartoons such as Tom and Jerry where the characters poison, skin and cook each other, yet this did not appear to incite violence. It could also be that the reason we think that shows like Tom and Jerry did not promote violence was that there is not much research on this.

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: I strongly agree that the UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza. In my opinion, sanctions are a peaceful yet powerful means for nations to hold others accountable for actions that may violate international law and human rights standards. The high number of civilian casualties and the widespread destruction in Gaza have sparked global concern and condemnation, highlighting the need for a strong and decisive response. It is essential to uphold humanitarian principles, and key international actors like the UK must act consistently when addressing violations, regardless of the country involved.

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: I strongly agree that the UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza. Sanctions are a peaceful yet powerful way for nations to hold others accountable in my opinion and also for actions that may violate international law and human rights standards. The high number of civilian casualties and widespread destruction in the Gaza region has sparked global concerns and condemnation and a firm and strong response in situations like this is essential to uphold humanitarian principles. As a way for international actors, the key international actors which are the UK must act consistently when addressing violations regardless of the country involved.

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: The UK’s legal system is bogged down by outdated and overly complex laws that are inaccessible to non-specialists, creating a bewildering "jungle" for those without legal expertise. This lack of clarity undermines public confidence and hinders compliance, as ordinary citizens struggle to understand their rights and obligations. A comprehensive reform to simplify and restructure the legal codes would make the law more intelligible and user-friendly, ensuring fairness and transparency. Modernising these frameworks would bring the legal system into the 21st century, aligning it with contemporary values of equity and accessibility. Clearer, more streamlined laws would empower individuals, reduce reliance on legal professionals for basic understanding, and foster greater trust in the justice system. Ultimately, such reform would create a fairer and more efficient legal environment for all citizens.

proposition: The UK should implement a comprehensive reform of its legal codes to ensure clarity and accessibility for all citizens.
paragraph: Honestly, in my opinion I will agree wholeheartedly that the uk needs a radical simplification of it's legal codes to make the law clearer and easier. A great many of the laws that already exist are couched in convoluted or archaic language and strewn over multiple sources, which makes them hard for the average person to comprehend. This generally expensive complication of legal assistance stands a barrier of justice and discriminates the poor reform of, their law codes will make their legal systems visible and credible and will guarantee that there is always an understanding of their right and responsibilities .

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: I believe the UK urgently needs stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and safeguard our precious rural landscapes. The relentless expansion of cities and suburban sprawl is destroying irreplaceable countryside, threatening biodiversity, and eroding the natural heritage that defines our nation's character. Rural areas provide essential environmental services, from carbon sequestration to flood management, while supporting traditional farming communities and local economies that have sustained our culture for generations. Unchecked development creates unsustainable pressure on infrastructure, increases pollution, and fragments ecosystems that wildlife depends upon. We must prioritise protecting green belts, agricultural land, and natural habitats over short-term economic gains from development. Stricter planning controls would ensure sustainable growth within existing urban boundaries, preserve our countryside for future generations, and maintain the delicate balance between human settlement and natural environment that makes Britain truly special.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to limit urbanisation and protect rural areas.
paragraph: I am strongly of the view that urbanization has to be restricted by stricter controls in order to protect rural territories. Uncontrolled urban expansion results in the destruction of natural habitats and farmlands, degrading biodiversity and food security in the nearest future in the urban and rural areas by reducing the overall living standards. By enforcing stricter planning controls the government can promote more sustainable development practices that save green cover maintain the environment and promotes more equitable regional development rural scenery is also valuable to culture and history lost with over development besides over urbanization aggravates traffic congestion overload public facilities ETC

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: I firmly believe that the UK's gender pay equality legislation serves a crucial purpose and should remain in place. These laws provide essential protections against workplace discrimination and help ensure that women receive fair compensation for their work. Abolishing such legislation would represent a significant step backward in the fight for gender equality and could lead to a resurgence of discriminatory pay practices that disadvantage women. The legal framework currently in place, including requirements for pay gap reporting and equal pay audits, creates accountability and transparency that benefits the entire workforce. While these laws may create some administrative burden for employers, this is a small price to pay for maintaining fundamental principles of fairness and equality in the workplace. Removing these protections would undermine decades of progress toward achieving genuine pay equity between men and women.

proposition: The UK should abolish existing gender pay equality legislation.
paragraph: If a company needs a person to deal with  customer service, and hires a man and a women, both have same responsabilities and help the costumer, why do men should get more money then the women or vice-versa? You are paying for the job, not paying for the gender. The difference in payment should be done for different skills and performance rather then gender. What does the man adds to this costume service because he's a man or does the women does less to the costumer service becaue she is a women? The value lies in the work not in the gender

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: "The COVID-19 vaccine was developed rapidly, which may have alarmed some people due to uncertainty about potential side effects. While the government and healthcare system should clearly communicate the vaccine’s importance in curbing the spread of the virus, the final decision should remain with individuals. If severe harm results from a mandated vaccine, who bears responsibility? How would individuals feel if forced into a decision that led to injury or death?"

proposition: The UK should mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all eligible citizens.
paragraph: The covid-19 vaccine was very new and made in record time, this possibly scared a lot of people because they were not aware of the side effects of the vaccine. On the other hand it is important that the government and healthcare system explains to people the importance of vaccination and how crucial it is to to protect against the spreading. However, people are the ones who ultimatly decide if they want to have it or not, if they have severe damages because of the vaccine who's the blame? How will they feel if the goverment mandate that and they die or get severely injured?

proposition: The UK should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions.
paragraph: I believe the UK should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions because workers deserve greater protection in the workplace. Labour unions play a vital role in ensuring fair treatment, safeguarding against exploitation, and giving employees a collective voice when negotiating with employers. Strengthening unions can lead to improved working conditions and help secure better wages, especially for those in lower-income roles. With the rising cost of living, it is crucial that workers receive fair compensation for their labour. Empowered unions can bridge the power imbalance between employers and employees, promoting a more equitable and just work environment. By enhancing the rights of unions, we can build a more resilient and inclusive workforce, which ultimately benefits society as a whole.

proposition: The UK should strengthen the rights and powers of labour unions.
paragraph:
The employees should be better protected in terms of benefits, redundancies, bullying, harassament etc
Unions play a crucial role in helping with getting better wages for the employees, better work conditions.Empowering unions helps balance the power between employers and employees, prometes workplace justice and reduces exploitation. This also encourages dialogue and resolution in some cases. A strong union encourages open dialogue  and more equitable and productive workplace. This can benefit the workers, the employers and the economy. 
At the moment people are strugling with wages because of the increase of the bills, if we have stronger unions that fight with the employees this can help to get better salarys

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel because their actions in Gaza constitute genocide and have resulted in the systematic destruction of the territory. The scale and nature of Israel's military response has gone far beyond legitimate self-defense, targeting civilian infrastructure, hospitals, schools, and residential areas in a manner that appears designed to make Gaza uninhabitable. The deliberate targeting of essential services and the creation of conditions that threaten the survival of the Palestinian population meets the definition of genocidal acts. The widespread devastation across Gaza, with entire neighborhoods reduced to rubble and hundreds of thousands displaced, demonstrates a level of destruction that cannot be justified by military necessity alone. Economic sanctions would send a clear message that such violations of international law and human rights will have consequences, and would pressure Israel to cease these destructive actions.

proposition: The UK should impose economic sanctions on Israel in response to the 2023 invasion of Gaza.
paragraph: I agree with this idea, as some retribution is needed for their genocidal campaign of mass destruction, and an economic sanction would bring in money that could be redistributed to important causes such as offering aid to those left in Gaza, helping refugees arriving here in the UK, etc. I don't think any form of punishment would truly match the damage Israel has done, but at least economic sanctions could help distribution the wealth of Israel to important international affairs, such as rebuilding Gaza, offering medical aid to those still there, funding for schools, universities, etc. Again though, there is not truly just punishment, and this importantly is not fighting violence with more violence.

proposition: The UK should eliminate all EU regulations from its legal framework.
paragraph: I'm not highly knowledgeable about EU regulations or legal frameworks, but I trust the collaborative nature of the EU and believe that its legal structures are thoughtfully developed and beneficial to both individual countries and the Union as a whole. In terms of collaboration, maintaining a framework aligned with the EU could foster stronger relationships and facilitate smoother joint efforts by reducing bureaucratic obstacles. Additionally, undertaking a complete overhaul of the current legal framework could be unnecessarily time-consuming and costly—resources that, given the economic challenges we are likely to face in the near future, would be better allocated elsewhere.

proposition: The UK should eliminate all EU regulations from its legal framework.
paragraph: I'm not too knowledgeably about EU regulations and legal frameworks, but I trust the collaborative aspect of the EU, and trust that their legal frameworks are well-thought out and beneficial for both the individual countries and the composite Union as a whole. On this idea of collaboration, I imagine that having a framework that aligns with that of the EU would allow for better relationships, and easier collaborative efforts (i.e., less bureaucratic hurdles to jump over). It could also be unnecessarily time-consuming, spending a lot of time and resources on completely uplifting the current framework we use, which, give the current economic hardship it looks like we'll be facing for the foreseeable, would not be a sensible allocation of funds.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: Mandating ESG policies for all publicly traded companies in the UK is a crucial step toward fostering sustainable and equitable economic growth. Such policies ensure companies prioritize environmental stewardship, social responsibility, and transparent governance, which are essential for long-term stability and public trust. By holding corporations accountable for their impact on climate change, labor practices, and ethical decision-making, the UK can lead by example in addressing global challenges. This approach not only aligns with the growing demand for responsible business practices but also mitigates systemic risks associated with short-term profit-driven models. While some argue that mandatory ESG policies could burden businesses, the benefits—such as attracting conscientious investors, enhancing brand reputation, and securing a healthier planet—far outweigh the costs. A regulatory framework would level the playing field, ensuring all companies contribute to a sustainable future rather than relying on voluntary measures that often lack enforcement.

proposition: The UK should mandate the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) policies for all publicly traded companies.
paragraph: I believe ESG is vital for the future, as we need all companies to look after the future of our planet, especially given the pivotal stage of the climate crisis we are currently in. If companies do not comply with environmental measures, proper punishment is required. As for the social aspect of ESG, workers rights need to be properly maintained, and a shed should be lit on any company abusing workers, not paying enough, overworking workers, child labour, etc. Again, there are not sufficient punishments, or media coverage, of companies ignoring this. For example, the fast fashion industry still remains grossly unregulated.

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph: "Countries like the USA, Russia, China, and North Korea succeed with this because patriotism is ingrained early and sustained for generations. Starting now in the UK would fail, as older generations lacked such conditioning and wouldn’t reinforce it. At best, it becomes a school ritual, like religious drills for kids—reciting prayers without meaning if families don’t practice. Without broader reinforcement, it’s just another task, forgotten outside the classroom."

proposition: The UK should implement mandatory patriotism education in schools.
paragraph: It works in countries like the USA, Russia, China, North Korea etc. because it is pushed on the children from a young age and has been an ongoing trend for decades, its too late to start now because all the generations that have missed out on that and are not patriotic would not enforce these type of behaviours, in the end it will be nothing more than just a thing kids do at school and that's it. It's like with sending a child to a religious school, they start the morning with our father but end of the day it doesnt make the child more religious or have them recite it outside of school if their family aren't practicing and enforcing it themselves.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: I believe that decreasing funding for education for disabled students would have significant negative consequences and is not the right approach. Disabled students often face unique challenges that require specialized support, resources, and accommodations in order to thrive academically and socially. Reducing financial support would undermine efforts to ensure equal educational opportunities and could widen the achievement gap. While I recognize the importance of evaluating government spending and ensuring the efficiency of public programs, I think that education for disabled students is an area where continued or even increased investment is warranted. Everyone deserves the chance to reach their full potential, and a more inclusive, well-resourced educational system benefits society as a whole. Therefore, I lean toward opposing cuts to this essential area, emphasizing the need to support all learners regardless of their abilities.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: To cut down on educational spending for these students would be extremely detrimental to everyone and not just the disabled students. First and foremost disabled students require the extra help and accomodation in school, to not send them to school because of a lack of resources is not an option not just for the disabled students but for the families sending them to school too. More often than not disabled students come from poor backgrounds so it would be a necessity to ensure they are still attending school and not being a burden on the families already. By putting them in the same class as the normal students they will be disruptive and stagger progress for the other students as teachers will need to go through lessons slower just for them, it can not happen.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: The UK should implement stricter regulations on violent video games for minors because these games are fundamentally harmful to young people's development. Video games teach children bad habits that can negatively impact their behavior and decision-making skills. Specifically, violent games actively promote aggression by rewarding players for using violence as a solution to problems, which can normalize aggressive responses in real-life situations. Additionally, these games frequently expose children to excessive profanity and inappropriate language, degrading their communication standards and potentially affecting how they interact with others. Given these concerning influences on impressionable minds, minors should not have easy access to violent video games. Stricter regulations would help protect children from content that undermines positive character development and ensures they engage with age-appropriate entertainment that supports rather than hinders their social and emotional growth.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations on the sale of violent video games to minors.
paragraph: Violent video games have a tendency to cause aggression and rage with anyone, nevermind just kids. If young kids are being given access to these video games they are at a high risk of learning these exact behavioural traits of being aggressive, raging, maybe even acting out and being disobedient in general. They also learn from the violence of the video games, whether its guns, weapons, fighting, profanity, as kids they want to play act and immitate these things, so being able to use the same language would be an issue especially if they're easily influenced. Fighting can easily escelate into other things if not being careful with who is exposed to it.

proposition: The UK should restrict the development of large language models.
paragraph: "I believe the UK should impose limits on large language models like ChatGPT. While these models are powerful and beneficial, they also pose risks if mishandled, such as spreading misinformation or violating privacy. Restrictions could ensure safety measures, like strict regulations, are implemented to prevent misuse and protect the public. However, development shouldn’t halt entirely, as AI holds significant potential for positive applications."

proposition: The UK should restrict the development of large language models.
paragraph: I think the UK should out limits on how big language models like chatGTP are developed. I think that these models are really powerful and can be very useful, but also risky if not handled carefully. For example they might cause accidental spread of false information or be used to invade people privacy. By restricting development, the UK could make sure that there are safety measure like strict rules put in place to protect people and stop the technology from being abused. At the same time though, I dont think that progress should stop completely because AI has a lot of useful potential.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I lean moderately toward supporting Scottish independence, though my position isn't strongly held. I believe Scotland has valid reasons to pursue self-governance, including the desire for greater control over its domestic policies, economic decisions, and cultural identity. The democratic will of the Scottish people should be respected if they choose independence through proper channels. However, I also recognize the significant challenges that separation would bring, including economic uncertainty, complex negotiations over shared institutions, and potential disruption to established relationships with the rest of the UK. While I see merit in Scotland's aspirations for autonomy and self-determination, I remain somewhat cautious about the practical implications and costs of independence. The decision ultimately rests with Scottish voters, and I would support whatever outcome emerges from a fair democratic process.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I think Scotland should become independent because it would mean that a lot of decisions that are made by the UK government now wouldn't focus on Scotland.  If Scotland were independent, they could make fairer policies to support workers, improve healthcare, and invest in education for children and uni students. This would help reduce inequality and make life better for more people in Scotland. Also being independent would mean Scotland would be able to push harder on green policies without interference from UK politics that might prioritise other interests. Climate change is a huge issue, and they have a lot of potential to lead in renewable energy I think.

proposition: The UK should loosen regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals.
paragraph: Loosening regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals could significantly benefit the UK healthcare system. By easing restrictions, it would become more affordable and efficient to bring in essential medicines from global markets, improving accessibility for patients. This could be especially valuable in addressing shortages or high costs of certain treatments. Additionally, reduced regulatory barriers may encourage greater competition among pharmaceutical providers, potentially driving down prices and spurring innovation. Increased market variety can stimulate the development of newer, more effective treatments as companies strive to differentiate themselves in a more open and dynamic marketplace. Overall, a more flexible approach to pharmaceutical regulation could lead to better outcomes for both consumers and the healthcare industry.

proposition: The UK should loosen regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals.
paragraph: I do think that the UK should consider loosening some regulations on the import and distribution of international pharmaceuticals. The pharmaceutical industry is constantly developing new drugs and therapies, and some of these innovations take a long time to reach the UK market because of strict regulatory processes. By easing the rules carefully, we could improve access to cutting edge treatments that could potentially save many lives. Allowing international drugs into the market would increase competition, which might reduce drug prices and make treatment more affordable. Safety and efficacy should be the main priority, so regulations should be completely removed, just adjusted to balance innovation with patient protection.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I don't think Scotland should be separate from the UK because it allows more people to contribute to the UK government. Making it an independent country would likely cause more issues for people entering and leaving Scotland for holidays and other travel. Many people living in Scotland frequently travel to places like London, so becoming a separate country could make that process harder and more time-consuming, which I don't think is a good idea. However, I'm open to hearing arguments about why it could be beneficial, as I don't know much about this issue.

proposition: Scotland should become an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom.
paragraph: I don't think Scotland should be separate to the UK because it allows more people to contribute to the UK government. Having them being an independant country will just cause more issues with people entering and existing scotland for holidays etc. A lot of people that live in scotland travel to and from for example london so them being another country would make this process hard and more time consuming which I think isn't a great idea. However, I'd be open to listening to points as to why it may be a benefit as I do not know much about this issue

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: I strongly disagree with decreasing funding for education for disabled students because such a policy would be fundamentally unfair and discriminatory. Every individual, regardless of their physical or cognitive abilities, deserves equal opportunities to access quality education and reach their full potential. Reducing financial support for disabled students would create additional barriers and put them at a significant disadvantage compared to their peers. These students often require specialized resources, adaptive technologies, and additional support services to participate effectively in educational programs. Cutting funding would not only limit their academic prospects but also perpetuate inequality and social exclusion. Instead of reducing support, we should be investing more in inclusive education systems that ensure all students have the tools and assistance they need to succeed academically and contribute meaningfully to society.

proposition: The UK should decrease funding for education for disabled students.
paragraph: I do not agree with this statement as I think every student should have equal opportunity including those that need extra help. Decreasing funding would cause more strain on the disable students and their families, which would them cause an extra problem for the goverment as their carer may need to homeschool them etc and then it would leave them not working. I also think it is not fair as everyone should be able to have the same opportunity so it would put them at a disadvantage from decreasing the funding and that would also them cause more stress for the education system if their is no funding

proposition: The UK should implement policies to incentivise higher birth rates.
paragraph: While I recognize the potential benefits of higher birth rates for addressing demographic challenges like an aging population, I’m skeptical about implementing policies to actively incentivize them. Such measures could strain public resources, disproportionately burden lower-income families, and overlook alternative solutions like immigration or productivity improvements. Additionally, encouraging higher birth rates without addressing underlying issues—such as childcare costs, work-life balance, or environmental concerns—feels shortsighted. Society should prioritize supporting existing families and creating equitable conditions for those who choose to have children, rather than pushing for more births as a blanket solution. The focus should be on quality of life and sustainability, not just population growth. While the intention may be valid, the approach risks being overly simplistic or even counterproductive if not carefully designed.

proposition: The UK should implement policies to incentivise higher birth rates.
paragraph: I don't fully agree with this point because people choose not to have as many or any children depending on their own situation. Some people may not be able to financially afford a child, living situation etc. Having an incentive may increase people to have more children without thinking of the long term if this is a good idea for them individually. I think this would cause the opposite effect of a negative situation compared to a positive situation in society. If people had kids they can't afford more strain on the government for benefits and other factors that need to be considered in this situation.

proposition: The UK should mandate the inclusion of feminist perspectives in the national literature curriculum.
paragraph: I oppose mandating feminist perspectives in the UK's national literature curriculum because contemporary feminism has overreached its original goals and become unnecessarily extreme. While early feminist movements addressed legitimate inequalities, modern feminism often promotes divisive ideologies that could be harmful to students' educational development. Forcing these perspectives into the curriculum risks exposing young minds to radical viewpoints that may foster resentment rather than genuine equality. Literature education should focus on teaching critical thinking and appreciation for great works based on their literary merit, not their adherence to particular political movements. A mandated feminist curriculum could limit intellectual freedom and create an environment where alternative viewpoints are suppressed. Instead of improving education, such requirements might politicize classrooms and undermine the broader goal of developing well-rounded, independent thinkers who can engage with diverse ideas without ideological constraints imposed by educational authorities.

proposition: The UK should mandate the inclusion of feminist perspectives in the national literature curriculum.
paragraph:
Originally, the idea of feminism was to empower women, and it allowed them to vote and do many other things that are positive. However, in the modern day, almost everything is fully equalized between both the genders, and so feminism isn't required.
Some people say feminism is just simply equality, which I would be behind - but again not really required.
Some people also say feminism is more than that. It is that all men are bad and women don't need them. Which in my opinion is wrong. Men and women thrive together and it should stay that way like it always has been.

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: Currently, I believe autonomous cars aren’t yet ready for widespread use, though I admit my knowledge is limited, hence my 30 rating. I generally think a human should oversee every vehicle, even highly automated transport, to ensure smooth operation. Cars should be no exception. While some automation, like advanced cruise control, is acceptable, fully autonomous vehicles shouldn’t be permitted on UK roads yet.

proposition: The UK should allow the use of autonomous vehicles on all public roads.
paragraph: At this current time, I do not think that autonomous cars are ready for use. However, I do not know too much about them and that is why I put them at 30. I think that generally speaking, a human should be behind every vehicle. Even some transport that is highly automated, they still require someone manning it to ensure it is running smoothly and without issues. I think this should be the same for cars. I think some cars are fine, like a bumped up version of cruise control, however, fully autonomous cars should not be allowed in the UK.

proposition: The UK should implement stricter regulations to break up corporate monopolies.
